{"uri": "8232531645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:35:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:35:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:34:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/british-open-2024-daniel-brown-212216702.html", "title": "British Open 2024: Daniel Brown birdies last for surprising lead at windy Troon Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in The Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 79 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nNo Open redux: Bryson DeChambeau (76), Rory McIlroy (78) befuddled at Royal Troon\n\nThe two players who decided the U.S. Open will be struggling to make the cut at The Open Championship.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8232464770", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:23:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:23:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:22:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.centralmaine.com/2024/07/18/british-open-daniel-brown-makes-late-birdies-for-1-shot-lead-over-shane-lowry-in-wind-challenged-first-round/", "title": "British Open: Daniel Brown makes late birdies for 1-shot lead over Shane Lowry in wind-challenged first round", "body": "Daniel Brown of England looks over his caddy's shoulder as they line up a putt on the 12th hole Thursday during his opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Scotland. Brown, playing in his first major, shot a 6-under 65 to grab a one-stroke lead. Jon Super/Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European Tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like the crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines British Open notebook: McIlroy, DeChambeau, Woods stumble badly out of the gates\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.", I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'.\n\n'No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.'\n\nRead More Escape to Manhattan, changing his phone number... how McIlroy bounced back from US Open meltdown\n\nA downbeat Rory McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run of holes around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 shots behind Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nLowry exchanged a fist bump with his caddie Darren Reynolds after a successful opener\n\nDaniel Brown trails Lowry by one shot at the close of play on Thursday evening in Scotland\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: 'I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.'\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out on an overdue fifth major title in last month's US Open, added: 'I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n'But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple of shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\n'Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n'I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.'\n\nHot off winning his second US Open, Bryson DeChambeau found himself well down the field\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\n'It was a thick lie and I tried to hit a 7-iron out, and I didn't get it high enough,' DeChambeau said.\n\n'Then I tried to fade a 5-wood and it squirted off the left side of my clubface and just shot left. I'm just glad nobody got hurt.'\n\nThomas had set the clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\nFormer world number one Justin Thomas is two shots behind Lowry and comfortable with his play on day one\n\n'I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,' Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n'I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction. I've just got to keep trying to play well.'\n\nSweden's Alex Noren, who only secured his place in the field via a tie for 10th in the Scottish Open on Sunday, was a shot off the pace alongside American Russell Henley and Ryder Cup team-mates Justin Rose and Nicolai Hojgaard.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in his {"uri": "8232775539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:41:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:41:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T03:40:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2024/jul/18/wind-makes-british-opens-first-round-tough-from/", "title": "Wind makes British Open's first round tough from start to finish", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard during the opening round of the 152nd British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise Thursday.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship tournament debut a memorable one. The 29-year-old from England birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under-par 65, giving him a one-shot lead over 2019 British Open champion Shane Lowry of Ireland with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate Brown's amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that didn't interest him anyway. There are at least 54 holes to go in the year's final major, though he was only focused on the next 18.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit,\" he said, \"and take on the job again tomorrow.\"\n\nBrown, whose lone win on the Europe-based DP World Tour came last September in Northern Ireland, arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying opportunity for this tournament; the other was the Scottish Open, where he made the cut before finishing 61st on Sunday.\n\nWeather is almost always a factor in links golf, but the wind at Royal Troon managed to stand out even for a British Open. Yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keep it together on the way back, it was tough from start to finish.\n\nFour-time major champion Rory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot a 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for reigning U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Tiger Woods won 14 major titles from 1997 to 2008 and a 15th at the 2019 Masters, but these days, every trip to one of golf's biggest four events is tough on the 48-year-old. He had a 79, his highest opening round in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start. He at least knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it. Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today\" said Lowry, five years removed from his lone major title at Northern Ireland's Royal Portrush.\n\nTwo-time PGA Championship winner Justin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if the 31-year-old American's score didn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he started the Scottish Open with a 62 at the Renaissance Club in North Berwick on the other side of the country -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Royal Troon. He was alone in third.\n\nThe group at 69 included Xander Schauffele, who won the PGA Championship in May for his first major title, and 2013 U.S. Open champ Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free -- and with greater appreciation of this British Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70 that had him tied for 11th.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" said the American star who has been atop the Official World Golf Ranking for more than a year. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 (yards) to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nChattanooga resident Stephan Jaeger, who won the Houston Open in March for his first PGA Tour victory, made his British Open debut. The 35-year-old former Baylor School and University of Tennessee at Chattanooga standout from Germany was 5 over at the turn after a trio of bogeys and a double, and while he would make two more on the 12th and 14th, they sandwiched an eagle on the 13th. Birdies on the 16th and 18th allowed him to finish off a 74, tied for 69th in the field of 156 players.\n\nHarris English, one of Jaeger's former teammates at Baylor, is playing the British Open for the fourth consecutive year and ninth time overall. He missed the cut in the past two and started this one with a 76 that left him tied for 96th.\n\nAP photo by Scott Heppell / Shane Lowry catches a golf ball as he prepares to putt on the 18th green at Royal Troon during the opening round of the British Open on Thursday in Troon, Scotland. Lowry shot a 66 and was alone in second place behind Daniel Brown.\n\nLowry hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh hole from about 10 feet and hit a wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to five feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennent's were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop, and he missed a four-foot putt and made a double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery: \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to a bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine,\" Thomas said, \"but stayed patient and kept plugging.\"\n\nHe avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, then finished with a 6-iron to eight feet for a birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much the wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of at least that many stokes.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nThe 35-year-old from Northern Ireland was hopeful of one last chance in 2024 to end his drought in the majors that has reached a decade. Now he only wants to make it to the weekend.\n\nHe took two shots to get out of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and he sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out of bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that, other options present themselves, and you start to second-guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said. \"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", "source": {"uri": "timesfreepress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "timesfreepress.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-426483632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:06:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:06:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://omaha.com/british-open-golf-brown-woods-thomas-scotland/article_aa65cf06-c425-5388-9547-f89a6220699a.html", "title": "Late birdies give Brown 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "Alexander Bjork of Sweden plays out of a bunker on the fifth hole during Thursday's opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Troon, Scotland.\n\nDOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Omaha.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Troon_Golf_Club", "https://assets-varnish.triblive.com/2024/07/7550499_web1_7550499-c4a0658140054531827a4e2c302b83ec.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9745035", "eventUri": "eng-9745035", "location": {"uri": "8232455012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:13:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:13:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:12:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/sports/dan-brown-makes-late-birdies-for-a-1-shot-lead-over-shane-lowry-in-wind/article_10b29b93-29bf-5fd5-8277-3515db2a2585.html", "title": "Dan Brown makes late birdies for a 1-shot lead over Shane Lowry in wind-challenged British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland (AP) -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-426560574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "00:54:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T00:54:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T18:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.news-journal.com/sports/brown-takes-1-shot-lead-at-british-open/article_91f5afbe-4533-11ef-875c-7778401d73e9.html", "title": "Brown takes 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nSign Up for Newsletters\n\nEmail*\n\nSelect Newsletters to Sign Up For\n\nNews Updates\n\nBreaking News\n\nSports Digest\n\nObituaries and Death Notices\n\nSubmit\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", "source": {"uri": "news-journal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Longview News-Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233023451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "07:20:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T07:20:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T07:20:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/jul/19/brown-wind-stun-in-opening-round/", "title": "Brown, wind stun in opening round", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven consecutive tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keep it together on the way back, it was tough from start to finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 79 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second consecutive week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 69 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennent's were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop, and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much the wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nHe was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now McIlroy only wants to make it to the weekend. He took two to get out of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second-guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nFormer University of Arkansas golfer Taylor Moore started with six consecutive pars, but struggled over the next 11 holes by shooting 8-over. He birdied No. 18 and finished at 7-over 78 for a tie in 129th place. John Daly (Dardanelle, Razorbacks) struggled with an 11-over par 153, including a quadruple bogey on No. 18.\n\nRory McIlroy of Northern Ireland walks with his caddy Harry Diamond on the third hole during his opening round of the British Open Golf Championships at Royal Troon golf club in Troon, Scotland, Thursday, July 18, 2024. "https://wehco.media.clients.ellingtoncms.com/img/photos/2024/07/18/1CBrown0719_t600.jpg?4326734cdb8e39baa3579048ef63ad7b451e7676", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9745035", "eventUri": "eng-9745035", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Troon"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2018-07-", "textStart": 6405, "textEnd": 6412, "freq": 9}], "sentiment": 0.1686274509803922, "wgt": 189, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8232514399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:16:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:16:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:15:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/sports/national-sports/2024/07/18/dan-brown-makes-late-birdies-for-a-1shot-lead-over-shane-lowry-in-windchallenged-british-open/", "title": "Dan Brown makes late birdies for a 1-shot lead over Shane Lowry in wind-challenged British Open - Medicine Hat News", "body": "Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland plays out of a bunker on the 17th during a practice round ahead of the British Open Golf Championships at Royal Troon golf club in Troon, Scotland, Wednesday, July 17, 2024. (AP Photo/Jon Super)TROON, Scotland (AP) - The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting. Turns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise. Daniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day. It was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway. \"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\"\u009d Brown said. A one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st. But this day was all about the wind - yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish. Rory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay. Lowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect. \"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\"\u009d Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\u009d Justin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 - he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open - and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon. The group at 69 included Mackenzie Hughes of Dundas, Ont., who ended his round with a birdie on 18, PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in. Throw in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70. \"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\"\u009d Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\u009d Corey Conners of Listowel, Ont., shot an even round of 71, while Nick Taylor and Adam Hadwin, both from Abbotsford, B.C., were at 4-over 75. Lowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\"\u009d that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole. He also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66. The applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday. \"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\"\u009d he said. \"It was late in the afternoon - a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\u009d Thomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card. His tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\"\u009d They eventually found it, but it led to bogey. \"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\"\u009d Thomas said. Indeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping - 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole. Justin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher. McIlroy broke 80, but not by much. He was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now McIlroy only wants to make it to the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind. \"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\"\u009d McIlroy said. \"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\u009d ___ AP golf:", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. {"uri": "8232491108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:50:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:50:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/40592045/england-brown-uses-late-birdie-run-grab-lead-open-lowry-1-back", "title": "England's Brown takes Open lead in major debut", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the Open Championship, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 - he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open - and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon - a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Troon_Golf_Club", {"uri": "2024-07-426516538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "23:13:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T23:13:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:05:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.wnewsj.com/2024/07/18/brown-makes-late-birdies-for-1-shot-lead-over-lowry-in-wind-challenged-british-open/", "title": "Brown makes late birdies for 1-shot lead over Lowry in wind-challenged British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland (AP) -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nHe was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now McIlroy only wants to make it to the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", "source": {"uri": "wnewsj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Wilmington News Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "wgt": 99}], "image": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Daniel-Brown-1160x773.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9745035", "eventUri": "eng-9745035", "location":
