{"uri": "2024-07-426532161", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "23:51:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T23:51:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T23:10:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/daniel-brown-makes-late-birdies-for-a-1-shot-lead-over-shane-lowry-in-wind/article_aaec9161-b0cf-5481-9ee7-3ec3f1261adb.html", "title": "Daniel Brown makes late birdies for a 1-shot lead over Shane Lowry in wind-challenged British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland (AP) -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keep it together on the way back, it was tough from start to finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 79 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 69 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennent's were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop, and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much the wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nHe was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now McIlroy only wants to make it to the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second-guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": Listowel, Ont., native Corey Conners closed his round even par, while Abbotsford, B.C., natives Nick Taylor and Adam Hadwin laboured to 4-over finishes.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. {"uri": "8233287074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "10:15:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T10:15:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T10:13:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.westhawaiitoday.com/2024/07/19/sports/shane-lowry-cards-66-at-open-championship-as-rory-mcilroy-struggles/", "title": "Shane Lowry cards 66 at Open Championship as Rory McIlroy struggles - West Hawaii Today", "body": "Shane Lowry made the ideal start to his bid for a second Open title as Rory McIlroy effectively wrote off his chances of doing the same at Royal Troon in Scotland.\n\nShane Lowry made the ideal start to his bid for a second Open title as Rory McIlroy effectively wrote off his chances of doing the same at Royal Troon in Scotland.\n\nLowry carded a 66, good for second place and a two-shot lead over former world No. 1 Justin Thomas. McIlroy struggled to an opening 78. England's Daniel Brown birdied two of his last three holes to card a six-under 65.\n\nIt was a contrast that immediately brought to mind the 2019 Open at Royal Portrush, when Lowry started with a 67 on his way to the Claret Jug and McIlroy's chances were blown away with a 79.\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" Lowry, who made birdies on the fourth, seventh, eighth, 11th and 18th, told Sky Sports.\n\n\"I got off to a bit of an iffy start and holed a couple of nice par putts early on and then I was off and running.\n\n\"I try not to think about it [2019] too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nMcIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run of holes around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was even par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind, McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven-over par, 12 shots behind Lowry.\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nThe 35-year-old, who missed out on a fifth major title in last month's U.S. Open, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple of shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second U.S. Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\n\"It was a thick lie and I tried to hit a 7-iron out, and I didn't get it high enough,\" DeChambeau said.\n\n\"Then I tried to fade a 5-wood and it squirted off the left side of my clubface and just shot left. I'm just glad nobody got hurt.\"\n\nThomas had set the clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\n\"I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,\" Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n\"I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction. I've just got to keep trying to play well.\"\n\nSweden's Alex Noren, who only secured his place in the field via a tie for 10th in the Scottish Open on Sunday, was a shot off the pace alongside American Russell Henley and Ryder Cup teammates Justin Rose and Nicolai Hojgaard.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in his bogey-free 69.\n\nTiger Woods, three-time Open champion, struggled to an 8-over 79.", "source": {"uri": "westhawaiitoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "West Hawaii Today"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8234102062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:18:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:18:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:18:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/shane-lowry-keeps-calm-and-carries-british-open-lead-at-troon/article_78357c40-7040-552e-92fc-0a6a39c2bfd8.html", "title": "Shane Lowry keeps calm and carries British Open lead at Troon", "body": "Tiger Woods of the United States with compatriots Xander Schauffele and Patrick Cantlay line up their putts on the first green during their second round of the British Open Golf Championships at Royal Troon golf club in Troon, Scotland, Friday, July 19, 2024.\n\nTROON, Scotland (AP) -- Shane Lowry found himself in a familiar position in the British Open, even if it required a detour that could have rattled him on a wild day Friday at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry took what seemed like an eternity to make a double bogey on the 11th hole. He recovered with two birdies over the final three holes for a 2-under 69, giving him a two-shot lead as the second round headed for a conclusion.\n\nAnd now he gets to wait even longer before he plays again, a product of being in the lead and among the late starters on the weekend with the silver claret jug he won five years ago at Royal Portrush coming more into view.\n\nHe was at 7-under 135, two shots ahead of surprise 18-hole leader Daniel Brown of England (72) and Justin Rose (68). Lowry shared the 36-hole lead when he won at Portrush in 2019.\n\n\"Look, I'm going to have a very late tee time tomorrow. I'm not going to be playing for another 24 hours. I know what that's about,\" Lowry said. \"I know tomorrow is going to be a long day, but I've done it before.\n\n\"For me, it's just about going out and playing my own game, shooting the best score I can. Try not to worry about what other people are doing and just trying to take care of your own personal stuff.\"\n\nIt was best to keep blinders on at Royal Troon. There were some harrowing scenes.\n\nJustin Thomas, who opened with a 68 to get himself in the mix, shot a 45 on the front nine and played his best golf from there to salvage a 78 and make sure he at least made the cut.\n\nRobert MacIntyre had an even tougher start. Scotland's biggest star after winning his national Open last week, MacIntyre was stuck in pot bunkers and high grass. He was 8 over for his round through four holes -- four holes! -- and then put together a big fight on the back nine in a bid to make the weekend.\n\nAguri Iwasaki had them all beat. He took a 9 on consecutive holes and shot 52 on the back nine for a 91. One of those 9s was on the par-3 14th, where he took four shots out of two bunkers and once had to go backward toward the fairway.\n\nTiger Woods missed another cut in a major -- that was one of the few surprises because he opened with a 79 -- but left his mark by tying his own mark with his highest 36-hole score as a pro with 156. The only time he had a higher 36-hole score was at Bay Hill in 1994 when he was a senior in high school.\n\nWoods had company in leaving early. Rory McIlroy, who started with a 78, needed a good start and got a triple bogey on the par-5 fourth hole. He barely moved it from high grass, chipped from more rough into a bunker and missed a 4-foot putt.\n\nMasters champion Scottie Scheffler missed all that calamity. He put together another steady round of 70 -- three birdies, two bogeys and the rest pars -- and joined the group at 2-under 140. He was five shots behind Lowry as he chases his second major of the year.\n\nJoaquin Niemann of Chile managed another 71 despite taking a quintuple-bogey 8 on the par-3 eighth hole -- the Postage Stamp -- that measures a mere 123 yards. He was in three bunkers around the tiny green and three-putted when he finally got out of them. Niemann also made six birdies in a most remarkable round of level par.\n\nSo much chaos across the century-old links, and it looked for a brief moment like Lowry might take part. It took so long to play the 11th hole that Jordan Spieth in the group behind him walked over to the side of the fairway and sat down near a gorse bush to wait.\n\nLowry at least kept it in play, though it was in the rough to the right. He was distracted by a photographer and angry at himself for not backing off the shot that he tugged left toward a clump of gorse.\n\nFiguring it would be lost in the prickly mess, Lowry hit a provisional for a lost ball onto the green, a terrific shot. One problem. Someone found the ball. It was no longer lost, so the provisional ball was not in play.\n\nLowry took a penalty drop from the bush, going back to find a place where he had a swing, put it short of the green, chipped on and salvaged a double bogey 6.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6. It wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament,\" Lowry said.\n\nHe made five birdies on the day, and yet nothing felt better than a par. That came on the 12th, one of the toughest holes into the wind. He hit driver and 4-iron to 30 feet, two putts for a most beautiful, calming par.\n\n\"The best shots I've hit all week,\" Lowry said. \"From then on, it was playing quite difficult, but I felt like you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.\"\n\nAnd now comes a big opportunity for Lowry to reclaim that claret jug, for Rose to become the first player in the modern era of exemptions to come through 36-hole qualifying, and for Brown to become one of the biggest surprises since Ben Curtis in 2003 at Royal St. George's.\n\nAnd so many others are very much in the mix, starting with Scheffler, golf's best player.\n\n\"I've played two solid rounds and it put me five shots back, and I'll continue to try to execute and just continue to try to hit good shots and hit good putts,\" Scheffler said, making it all sound so simple on a day when nothing felt easy.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf\n\nSo much calamity, and it looked for a brief mome", "source": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9745035", "eventUri": "eng-9745035", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2019-07-", "textStart": 245, "textEnd": 252}], "sentiment": {"uri": "8232513624", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:15:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:15:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:14:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.tricitynews.com/world-news/dan-brown-makes-late-birdies-for-a-1-shot-lead-over-shane-lowry-in-wind-challenged-british-open-9240157", "title": "Dan Brown makes late birdies for a 1-shot lead over Shane Lowry in wind-challenged British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland (AP) -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 69 included Mackenzie Hughes of Dundas, Ont., who ended his round with a birdie on 18, PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nCorey Conners of Listowel, Ont., shot an even round of 71, while Nick Taylor and Adam Hadwin, both from Abbotsford, B.C., were at 4-over 75.\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nHe was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now McIlroy only wants to make it to the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\n___\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf\n\nDoug Ferguson, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "tricitynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Tri-City {"uri": "8234057042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:32:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:32:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T19:32:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/19/british-open-lowry-emerges-from-chaos-with-two-stroke-lead/", "title": "British Open: Lowry emerges from chaos with two-stroke lead", "body": "Shane Lowry of Ireland throws his ball into the stands Friday after completing his second round at the British Open in Troon, Scotland. Lowry was at 7 under overall, two strokes ahead of Justin Rose and Daniel Brown. Scott Heppell/Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Shane Lowry found himself in a familiar position in the British Open, even if it required a detour that could have rattled him on a wild day Friday at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry took what seemed like an eternity to make a double bogey on the 11th hole. He recovered with two birdies over the final three holes for a 2-under 69, giving him a two-shot lead as the second round headed for a conclusion.\n\nAnd now he gets to wait even longer before he plays again, a product of being in the lead and among the late starters on the weekend, with the silver claret jug he won five years ago at Royal Portrush coming more into view.\n\nHe was at 7-under 135, two shots ahead of Justin Rose (68) and surprise 18-hole leader Daniel Brown of England (72). Lowry shared the 36-hole lead when he won at Portrush in 2019.\n\n\"Look, I'm going to have a very late tee time tomorrow. I'm not going to be playing for another 24 hours. I know what that's about,\" Lowry said. \"I know tomorrow is going to be a long day, but I've done it before.\n\n\"For me, it's just about going out and playing my own game, shooting the best score I can. Try not to worry about what other people are doing and just trying to take care of your own personal stuff.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIt was best to keep blinders on at Royal Troon. There were some harrowing scenes.\n\nJustin Thomas, who opened with a 68 to get himself in the mix, shot a 45 on the front nine and played his best golf from there to salvage a 78 and make sure he at least was inside the cut line.\n\nRobert MacIntyre had an even tougher start. Scotland's biggest star after winning his national Open last week, MacIntyre was stuck in pot bunkers and high grass. He was 8 over for his round through four holes, and then was 4 under the rest of the way to make it to the weekend.\n\nAguri Iwasaki took a 9 on consecutive holes and shot 52 on the back nine for a 91. One of those 9s was on the par-3 14th, where he needed four shots out of two bunkers and once had to go backward toward the fairway.\n\nTiger Woods missed another cut in a major - that was one of the few surprises, because he opened with a 79 - and tied his highest 36-hole score as a pro at 156. The only time he had a higher 36-hole score was at Bay Hill in 1994 when he was a senior in high school.\n\nWoods had company in leaving early. Rory McIlroy, who started with a 78 on Thursday, made a triple bogey on the par-5 fourth hole. He barely moved the ball from high grass, chipped from more rough into a bunker and missed a 4-foot putt.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMasters champion Scottie Scheffler avoided all that calamity. He put together another steady round of 70 - three birdies, two bogeys - and was tied for fourth at 2-under 140 as he chases his second major of the year. Billy Horschel and Dean Burmester were also at 2 under.\n\nJoaquin Niemann of Chile managed another 71 despite taking a quintuple-bogey 8 on the par-3 eighth hole - the Postage Stamp - that measures a mere 123 yards. He was in three bunkers around the tiny green and three-putted when he finally got out of them. Niemann also made six birdies in a most remarkable round.\n\nThere was so much chaos across the century-old links, and for a brief moment, Lowry was involved. It took so long to play the 11th hole that Jordan Spieth in the group behind him walked over to the side of the fairway and sat down near a gorse bush to wait.\n\nLowry at least kept his ball in play, though it was in the rough to the right. He was distracted by a photographer and angry at himself for not backing off a shot that he tugged left toward a clump of gorse.\n\nFiguring it would be lost in the prickly mess, Lowry hit a provisional for a lost ball onto the green, a terrific shot. One problem: Someone found his ball. It was no longer lost, so the provisional ball was not in play.\n\nLowry took a penalty drop from the bush, going back to find a place where he had a swing, put it short of the green, chipped on, and salvaged a double bogey 6.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6. It wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament,\" Lowry said.\n\nHe made five birdies, and yet nothing felt better than a par on the 12th, one of the toughest holes into the wind. He hit driver and 4-iron to 30 feet, and needed two putts for a most beautiful, calming par.\n\n\"The best shots I've hit all week,\" Lowry said. \"From then on, it was playing quite difficult, but I felt like you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.\"\n\nAnd now comes a big opportunity for Lowry to reclaim that claret jug, for Rose to become the first player in the modern era of exemptions to come through 36-hole qualifying and win, and for Brown to become one of the biggest surprises since Ben Curtis in 2003 at Royal St. George's.\n\nAnd so many others are very much in the mix, starting with Scheffler, golf's best player.\n\n\"I've played two solid rounds and it put me five shots back, and I'll continue to try to execute and just continue to try to hit good shots and hit good putts,\" Scheffler said, making it all sound so simple on a day when nothing felt easy.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nRelated Stories Latest {"uri": "8234018038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:54:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:54:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:53:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/sports/lowry-takes-british-open-lead-as-torrid-tiger-1845429.html", "title": "Lowry Takes British Open Lead As Torrid Tiger Misses Cut - UrduPoint", "body": "Shane Lowry moved into the lead of the 152nd British Open at seven under par after his second round at Royal Troon on Friday as a tame Tiger Woods limped to 14 over to miss the cut\n\nTroon, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 19th Jul, 2024) Shane Lowry moved into the lead of the 152nd British Open at seven under par after his second round at Royal Troon on Friday as a tame Tiger Woods limped to 14 over to miss the cut.\n\nWoods is not the only big name to struggle in the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast as Rory McIlroy will begin his second round at seven over and likely needing an under par round to make the weekend.\n\nLowry had been usurped at the top of the leaderboard late on Thursday by unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown, who posted a six under 65.\n\nHowever, the Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\nLowry leads by two shots from Brown, who showed little sign of nerves under the spotlight in his first major, with a steady 72 to sit at five under.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster,\" said Lowry on his travails at 11.\n\n\"To be leading this tournament after two days, it's why you come here.\"\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world number 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share of fourth at two under despite dropping a shot at 18.\n\nScheffler has already won six times this year, including his second Masters title in April.\n\nA monster putt at the 14th and a birdie on the par-five 16th took the American within striking range before a costly bogey on the last left him still five adrift of Lowry.\n\n- Woods' worst ever Open -\n\nWoods' tournament came to a sorry end after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\n\"I just need to keep progressing like that and then eventually start playing more competitively and start getting into kind of the competitive flow again,\" he said.\n\nBut the three-time British Open champion cut a sorry figure as he trudged around the Troon links with his two-round score leaving him in 149th out of the 154 players still active in the tournament.\n\nHis score of 156 over two rounds matches his worst ever at a major with the 2015 US Open and is his poorest at a British Open by three shots.\n\nStrong winds ensured low scoring remained difficult with the sixth, which had been the longest hole in British Open history on Thursday at 623 yards, reduced by 20 yards due to the conditions.\n\nAttention later turns to McIlroy's attempt to recover from a disastrous opening round of 78 with the projected cut sitting at four over.\n\nScottish Open champion Bob MacIntyre's dreams of a first major on home soil unravelled as he dropped eight shots in his first four holes to drop to nine over.", It was late in the afternoon and a few pints of Tennent's were had out there. It felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\n\n\"The walk down 18 was actually pretty cool. I said to Billy Foster (Matt Fitzpatrick's caddie) that it's the greatest walk in golf and I got to do it on a Sunday afternoon with a full house. That's the plan, to try to get to do that again.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again. I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again and that's why I'm here this week.\n\nShane Lowry chips out of a bunker on the 16th during day one of The Open at Royal Troon (Owen Humphreys/PA)\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nA downbeat McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 behind his great friend Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nSpectators search for Rory McIlroy\u00b4s ball after he drove out of bounds on the 11th (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out the US Open title last month, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\nThomas had set the early clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\n\"I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,\" Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n\"I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction.\"\n\nFormer supermarket delivery driver Joe Dean was part of a seven-way tie for fourth place on two under par which included US PGA winner Xander Schauffele and Ryder Cup team-mates Nicolai Hojgaard and Justin Rose.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in a bogey-free 69.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-426674226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "04:36:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T04:36:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:25:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.nine.com.au/sport/golf/british-open-championship-2024-romain-langasque-rage-quitting-video-leaderboard-scores-highlights-20240719-p5juxh.html", "title": "'I'm out': British Open golfer quits mid round", "body": "Langasque was 4-over par through the first seven holes when he hit his tee shot on the par-3 eighth - the shortest par-3 in the Open rotation - only 76m, still 33m short of the hole.\n\nWhile his tee shot wasn't broadcast, his second shot from the long fescue rough was. It wasn't pretty - he hit it thin and it shot like a bullet straight across the other side of the green.\n\nMicrophones captured a reaction most weekend hacks can relate too. He then took his hat off, muttered \"f--- it, I'm out,\" shook his playing partner's hands, and walked off Royal Troon.\n\nThe Frenchman later took to social media to explain it was a back injury that forced him out, rather than a rage quit.\n\n\"Hurt my back on hole 4 and it became (worse and worse) after it ... see you next year,\" he said on X.\n\nLangasque had bogeyed the first, but bounced back with a birdie on the second. He made par on the third, but bogeyed three of the next four holes before pulling the pin.\n\nAt the top of the leaderboard, Daniel Brown had a major debut he won't soon forget.\n\nHe birdied two of the last three holes to card a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for US Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 US Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" he said.\n\n\"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said.\n\n\"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No.2 today, I had (151m) to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about (187m). It went probably $141m) at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 112m hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a near 8m putt on the 10th, before holing a six metre birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4-under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only the first round.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said.\n\n\"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4-under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\"\n\nThey eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 8m on the 419m closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years.\n\nNow he's hopeful of just sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course,\" McIlroy explained.\n\n\"Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nAdam Scott is best of the Aussies in a tie for 11th five shots back at 1-under. Min Woo Lee is a shot further behind at even par. Jason Day is at 2-over.\n\nElvis Smylie (5-over), amateur Jasper Stubbs (9-over) and Smith (9-over) will all battle to make the cut, which right now would be at 4-over.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8233697572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:43:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:43:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T14:40:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.espn.ph/golf/story/_/id/40592045/england-brown-uses-late-birdie-run-grab-lead-open-lowry-1-back", "title": "England's Brown takes Open lead in major debut", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the Open Championship. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start to finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 79 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 69 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like the crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Troon_Golf_Club", him", "body": "Open leader Shane Lowry ready to deal with whatever Royal Troon throws at him\n\nPhil Casey, PA Golf Correspondent\n\n19 July 2024 at 9:28 pm\n\nShane Lowry believes he is ready to take whatever is thrown at him \"on the chin\" after keeping his bid for a second Open title firmly on track at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry added a second round of 69 to his opening 66 for a halfway total of seven under par and two-shot lead over English duo Justin Rose and Dan Brown, who both came through 36-hole final qualifiers earlier this month.\n\nWith a strong wind sending scores soaring for the later starters, Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy, Bryson DeChambeau, Ludvig Aberg and Tommy Fleetwood all missed the cut, but home favourite Robert MacIntyre and Justin Thomas fought back from horror starts to make the weekend.\n\nLowry also recovered from a double bogey on the 11th with birdies on the 16th and 18th as he bids to lift the Claret Jug for a second time following his triumph at Royal Portrush in 2019.\n\nSurprise overnight leader Brown, who had completed a flawless 65 at 9.33pm on Thursday, battled to a second round of 72, while Rose returned a superb 68 and has dropped just one shot in 36 holes.\n\nLowry felt he had \"done the hard part\" on the 11th by getting his tee shot in play, but was distracted by a cameraman on his second shot and pulled it into the gorse.\n\nAfter taking a penalty drop Lowry hit his fourth shot to around 10 feet to give himself a chance to salvage a bogey, only for his original ball to be found by a spectator.\n\nThat meant it was still in play and, after a long delay while it was determined where he could best take a drop, Lowry hit his approach just short of the green and eventually completed a double-bogey six.\n\nFormer Ryder Cup player David Howell, the on-course commentator with Lowry's group for Sky Sports, said the spectator who found the ball was \"being a little sheepish\" when he realised Lowry's intentions, adding: \"He's feeling awful.\"\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry explained. \"The referee asked me going down (the fairway) did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was OK.\n\n\"Then we get down there and somebody had found it, so apparently you have to go and identify it. I felt through that whole process of that 20 minutes of seeing where I could drop I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing.\n\n\"And Darren (Reynolds, his caddie) did a great job too. He kept telling me we have loads of time, we don't need to rush this.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster. I have felt quite calm and composed the last couple of days. I've felt really in my comfort zone.\n\n\"Sometimes you are in a frame of mind where you get on with it better than other times. This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. If I give myself a chance on Sunday I know I can do it and that's as good as a position to be in as any.\"\n\nBrown might have been expected to come back down to earth with a bump after his Thursday heroics, but the 29-year-old from Northallerton delivered an impressive sequel on his major debut.\n\n\"I've always been quite laid back really,\" Brown said. \"I think I am a bit of a realist as well.\n\n\"I know I'm not going to start getting ahead of myself and thinking, 'Oh my God, I'm leading the Open' or 'I'm second in the Open' or whatever.\n\n\"There's still 36 holes left. I might have a good round tomorrow and then I might have a stinky round on Sunday. You just don't know.\"\n\nRose's round drew high praise from six-time major winner Sir Nick Faldo, the last English winner of the Open in 1992, during a commentary stint on Sky Sports.\n\n\"Maybe the best 68 of his whole career on a day like today in this wind,\" Faldo said.\n\nSpeaking about his chance to make history, Rose said: \"When I won the US Open (in 2013) it was like 'First since Tony Jacklin' and they are nice moments when they come together, but you are never thinking of it.\n\n\"In the moment you are just trying to get the job done.\"\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler, Billy It was late in the afternoon and a few pints of Tennent's were had out there. It felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\n\n\"The walk down 18 was actually pretty cool. I said to Billy Foster (Matt Fitzpatrick's caddie) that it's the greatest walk in golf and I got to do it on a Sunday afternoon with a full house. That's the plan, to try to get to do that again.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again. I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again and that's why I'm here this week.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nA downbeat McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 behind his great friend Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out the US Open title last month, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\nThomas had set the early clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\n\"I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,\" Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n\"I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction.\"\n\nFormer supermarket delivery driver Joe Dean was part of a seven-way tie for fourth place on two under par which included US PGA winner Xander Schauffele and Ryder Cup team-mates Nicolai Hojgaard and Justin Rose.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in a bogey-free 69.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13652937/Open-leader-Shane-Lowry-ready-deal-Royal-Troon-throws-him.html", "title": "Open leader Shane Lowry ready to deal with whatever Royal Troon...", "body": "Shane Lowry believes he is ready to take whatever is thrown at him \"on the chin\" after keeping his bid for a second Open title firmly on track at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry added a second round of 69 to his opening 66 for a halfway total of seven under par and two-shot lead over English duo Justin Rose and Dan Brown, who both came through 36-hole final qualifiers earlier this month.\n\nWith a strong wind sending scores soaring for the later starters, Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy, Bryson DeChambeau, Ludvig Aberg and Tommy Fleetwood all missed the cut, but home favourite Robert MacIntyre and Justin Thomas fought back from horror starts to make the weekend.\n\nLowry also recovered from a double bogey on the 11th with birdies on the 16th and 18th as he bids to lift the Claret Jug for a second time following his triumph at Royal Portrush in 2019.\n\nSurprise overnight leader Brown, who had completed a flawless 65 at 9.33pm on Thursday, battled to a second round of 72, while Rose returned a superb 68 and has dropped just one shot in 36 holes.\n\nLowry felt he had \"done the hard part\" on the 11th by getting his tee shot in play, but was distracted by a cameraman on his second shot and pulled it into the gorse.\n\nAfter taking a penalty drop Lowry hit his fourth shot to around 10 feet to give himself a chance to salvage a bogey, only for his original ball to be found by a spectator.\n\nThat meant it was still in play and, after a long delay while it was determined where he could best take a drop, Lowry hit his approach just short of the green and eventually completed a double-bogey six.\n\nFormer Ryder Cup player David Howell, the on-course commentator with Lowry's group for Sky Sports, said the spectator who found the ball was \"being a little sheepish\" when he realised Lowry's intentions, adding: \"He's feeling awful.\"\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry explained. \"The referee asked me going down (the fairway) did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was OK.\n\nIreland\u00b4s Shane Lowry reacts as he plays a shot from the rough on the 11th during day two at Royal Troon (Owen Humphreys/PA)\n\n\"Then we get down there and somebody had found it, so apparently you have to go and identify it. I felt through that whole process of that 20 minutes of seeing where I could drop I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing.\n\n\"And Darren (Reynolds, his caddie) did a great job too. He kept telling me we have loads of time, we don't need to rush this.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster. I have felt quite calm and composed the last couple of days. I've felt really in my comfort zone.\n\nAnything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on Shane Lowry\n\n\"Sometimes you are in a frame of mind where you get on with it better than other times. This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. If I give myself a chance on Sunday I know I can do it and that's as good as a position to be in as any.\"\n\nBrown might have been expected to come back down to earth with a bump after his Thursday heroics, but the 29-year-old from Northallerton delivered an impressive sequel on his major debut.\n\n\"I've always been quite laid back really,\" Brown said. \"I think I am a bit of a realist as well.\n\nEngland\u00b4s Daniel Brown remains in contention (Zac Goodwin/PA)\n\n\"I know I'm not going to start getting ahead of myself and thinking, 'Oh my God, I'm leading the Open' or 'I'm second in the Open' or whatever.\n\n\"There's still 36 holes left. I might have a good round tomorrow and then I might have a stinky round on Sunday. You just don't know.\"\n\nRose's round drew high praise from six-time major winner Sir Nick Faldo, the last English winner of the Open in 1992, during a commentary stint on Sky Sports.\n\n\"Maybe the best 68 of his whole career on a day like today in this wind,\" Faldo said.\n\nSpeaking about his chance to make history, Rose said: \"When I won the US Open (in 2013) it was like 'First since Tony Jacklin' and they are nice moments when they come together, but you are never thinking of it.\n\n\"In the moment you are just trying to get the job done.\"\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler, Billy {"uri": "8232371720", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "19:54:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T19:54:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:53:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/sport/uk-sport/2024/07/18/shane-lowry-cards-flawless-66-to-lead-open-as-rory-mcilroy-hopes-all-but-ended/", "title": "Shane Lowry cards flawless 66 to lead Open as Rory McIlroy hopes all but ended", "body": "Lowry was five under after the opening day with McIlroy 12 shots adrift after a 78.\n\nShane Lowry made the ideal start to his bid for a second Open title as Rory McIlroy effectively wrote off his chances of doing the same at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry carded a flawless 66 to hold a two-shot lead over former world number one Justin Thomas after McIlroy struggled to an opening 78.\n\nIt was a contrast which immediately brought to mind the 2019 Open at Royal Portrush, when Lowry started with a 67 on his way to the Claret Jug and McIlroy's chances were blown away with a 79.\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" Lowry, who made birdies on the fourth, seventh, eighth, 11th and 18th, told Sky Sports.\n\n\"I got off to a bit of an iffy start and holed a couple of nice par putts early on and then I was off and running.\n\n\"I try not to think about it [2019] too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 shots behind Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out on an overdue fifth major title in last month's US Open, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple of shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\n\"It was a thick lie and I tried to hit a 7-iron out, and I didn't get it high enough,\" DeChambeau said.\n\n\"Then I tried to fade a 5-wood and it squirted off the left side of my clubface and just shot left. I'm just glad nobody got hurt.\"\n\nThomas had set the clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\n\"I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,\" Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n\"I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction. I've just got to keep trying to play well.\"\n\nSweden's Alex Noren, who only secured his place in the field via a tie for 10th in the Scottish Open on Sunday, was a shot off the pace alongside American Russell Henley and Ryder Cup team-mates Justin Rose and Nicolai Hojgaard.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in his bogey-free 69.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Guernsey Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rory_McIlroy", "type": I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nShane Lowry chips out of a bunker on the 16th during day one of The Open at Royal Troon (Owen Humphreys/PA)\n\nA downbeat Rory McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run of holes around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 shots behind Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nSpectators search for Rory McIlroy\u00b4s ball after he drove out of bounds on the 11th (Jane Barlow/PA)\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out on an overdue fifth major title in last month's US Open, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple of shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\n\"It was a thick lie and I tried to hit a 7-iron out, and I didn't get it high enough,\" DeChambeau said.\n\n\"Then I tried to fade a 5-wood and it squirted off the left side of my clubface and just shot left. I'm just glad nobody got hurt.\"\n\nThomas had set the clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\n\"I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,\" Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n\"I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction. I've just got to keep trying to play well.\"\n\nSweden's Alex Noren, who only secured his place in the field via a tie for 10th in the Scottish Open on Sunday, was a shot off the pace alongside American Russell Henley and Ryder Cup team-mates Justin Rose and Nicolai Hojgaard.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in his {"uri": "8232400377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "20:21:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T20:21:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T20:20:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/golf/shane-lowry-leads-open-championship-33277463", "title": "Shane Lowry leads the Open Championship after flawless five-under-par 66", "body": "Shane Lowry made the ideal start to his bid for a second Open title as Rory McIlroy effectively wrote off his chances of doing the same at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry carded a flawless 66 to hold a two-shot lead over former world number one Justin Thomas after McIlroy struggled to an opening 78.\n\nIt was a contrast which immediately brought to mind the 2019 Open at Royal Portrush, when Lowry started with a 67 on his way to the Claret Jug and McIlroy's chances were blown away with a 79.\n\nREAD MORE: Shane Lowry backed to last distance at The Open but Offaly man not getting carried away\n\nREAD MORE: Patrick Cantlay shows Rory McIlroy how to do it at The Open after moment of misery\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" Lowry, who made birdies on the fourth, seventh, eighth, 11th and 18th, told Sky Sports.\n\n\"I got off to a bit of an iffy start and holed a couple of nice par putts early on and then I was off and running.\n\n\"I try not to think about it [2019] too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. It was late in the afternoon and a few pints of Tennent's were had out there. It felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\n\n\"The walk down 18 was actually pretty cool. I said to Billy Foster (Matt Fitzpatrick's caddie) that it's the greatest walk in golf and I got to do it on a Sunday afternoon with a full house. That's the plan, to try to get to do that again.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again. I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again and that's why I'm here this week.\n\nA downbeat McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 behind his great friend Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out the US Open title last month, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left.
