{"uri": "2024-07-426475886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:51:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:51:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/british-open-golf-brown-woods-thomas-scotland/article_f7edac62-d556-555a-b5db-858c1c796ec9.html", "title": "Late birdies give Brown 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "Alexander Bjork of Sweden plays out of a bunker on the fifth hole during Thursday's opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Troon, Scotland.\n\nDOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nJohn Deere will lay off an undetermined number of salaried workers beginning next week One dead in early morning shooting in Hudson Interstate traffic shut down for person on bridge Four injured in wrong-way crash Waterloo day care operator charged with three counts of child endangerment NEW DETAILS: John Deere announces another 345 layoffs at Waterloo facilities Iowa restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi Colleagues remember Waverly-Shell Rock principal Suz SmolikHagen Apartment hit in weekend shooting UPDATE WITH NAME: One dead in tanker crash south of Hudson High School Baseball: Don Bosco wins substate thriller over Saint Ansgar Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Kathyrn Koob: Remarkable journey from farm girl to diplomat and esteemed educator One arrested in downtown shooting Waterloo council votes 4-2 to allow for construction of tiny home\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and {"uri": "2024-07-426402272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "19:55:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T19:55:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:42:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/shane-lowry-cards-flawless-66-194232324.html", "title": "Shane Lowry cards flawless 66 to lead Open as Rory McIlroy hopes all but ended", "body": "Shane Lowry cards flawless 66 to lead Open as Rory McIlroy hopes all but ended\n\nPhil Casey, PA Golf Correspondent\n\n18 July 2024 at 9:42 pm\n\nShane Lowry made the ideal start to his bid for a second Open title as Rory McIlroy effectively wrote off his chances of doing the same at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry carded a flawless 66 to hold a two-shot lead over former world number one Justin Thomas after McIlroy struggled to an opening 78.\n\nIt was a contrast which immediately brought to mind the 2019 Open at Royal Portrush, when Lowry started with a 67 on his way to the Claret Jug and McIlroy's chances were blown away with a 79.\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" Lowry, who made birdies on the fourth, seventh, eighth, 11th and 18th, told Sky Sports.\n\n\"I got off to a bit of an iffy start and holed a couple of nice par putts early on and then I was off and running.\n\n\"I try not to think about it [2019] too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nA downbeat Rory McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run of holes around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 shots behind Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out on an overdue fifth major title in last month's US Open, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple of shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\n\"It was a thick lie and I tried to hit a 7-iron out, and I didn't get it high enough,\" DeChambeau said.\n\n\"Then I tried to fade a 5-wood and it squirted off the left side of my clubface and just shot left. I'm just glad nobody got hurt.\"\n\nThomas had set the clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\n\"I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,\" Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n\"I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction. I've just got to keep trying to play well.\"\n\nSweden's Alex Noren, who only secured his place in the field via a tie for 10th in the Scottish Open on Sunday, was a shot off the pace alongside American Russell Henley and Ryder Cup team-mates Justin Rose and Nicolai Hojgaard.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in his bogey-free 69.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "phil_casey@aol.co.uk", "name": "Phil Casey", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], {"uri": "2024-07-427502533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:03:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:03:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T14:52:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-07-19/shane-lowry-keeps-calm-and-carries-british-open-lead-at-troon", "title": "Shane Lowry Keeps Calm and Carries British Open Lead at Troon", "body": "TROON, Scotland (AP) -- Shane Lowry found himself in a familiar position in the British Open, even if it required a detour that could have rattled him on a wild day Friday at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry took what seemed like an eternity to make a double bogey on the 11th hole. He recovered with two birdies over the final three holes for a 2-under 69, giving him a two-shot lead as the second round headed for a conclusion.\n\nAnd now he gets to wait even longer before he plays again, a product of being in the lead and among the late starters on the weekend with the silver claret jug he won five years ago at Royal Portrush coming more into view.\n\nHe was at 7-under 135, two shots ahead of surprise 18-hole leader Daniel Brown of England (72) and Justin Rose (68). Lowry shared the 36-hole lead when he won at Portrush in 2019.\n\n\"Look, I'm going to have a very late tee time tomorrow. I'm not going to be playing for another 24 hours. I know what that's about,\" Lowry said. \"I know tomorrow is going to be a long day, but I've done it before.\n\n\"For me, it's just about going out and playing my own game, shooting the best score I can. Try not to worry about what other people are doing and just trying to take care of your own personal stuff.\"\n\nIt was best to keep blinders on at Royal Troon. There were some harrowing scenes.\n\nJustin Thomas, who opened with a 68 to get himself in the mix, shot a 45 on the front nine and played his best golf from there to salvage a 78 and make sure he at least made the cut.\n\nRobert MacIntyre had an even tougher start. Scotland's biggest star after winning his national Open last week, MacIntyre was stuck in pot bunkers and high grass. He was 8 over for his round through four holes -- four holes! -- and then put together a big fight on the back nine in a bid to make the weekend.\n\nAguri Iwasaki had them all beat. He took a 9 on consecutive holes and shot 52 on the back nine for a 91. One of those 9s was on the par-3 14th, where he took four shots out of two bunkers and once had to go backward toward the fairway.\n\nTiger Woods missed another cut in a major -- that was one of the few surprises because he opened with a 79 -- but left his mark by tying his own mark with his highest 36-hole score as a pro with 156. The only time he had a higher 36-hole score was at Bay Hill in 1994 when he was a senior in high school.\n\nWoods had company in leaving early. Rory McIlroy, who started with a 78, needed a good start and got a triple bogey on the par-5 fourth hole. He barely moved it from high grass, chipped from more rough into a bunker and missed a 4-foot putt.\n\nMasters champion Scottie Scheffler missed all that calamity. He put together another steady round of 70 -- three birdies, two bogeys and the rest pars -- and joined the group at 2-under 140. He was five shots behind Lowry as he chases his second major of the year.\n\nJoaquin Niemann of Chile managed another 71 despite taking a quintuple-bogey 8 on the par-3 eighth hole -- the Postage Stamp -- that measures a mere 123 yards. He was in three bunkers around the tiny green and three-putted when he finally got out of them. Niemann also made six birdies in a most remarkable round of level par.\n\nSo much chaos across the century-old links, and it looked for a brief moment like Lowry might take part. It took so long to play the 11th hole that Jordan Spieth in the group behind him walked over to the side of the fairway and sat down near a gorse bush to wait.\n\nLowry at least kept it in play, though it was in the rough to the right. He was distracted by a photographer and angry at himself for not backing off the shot that he tugged left toward a clump of gorse.\n\nFiguring it would be lost in the prickly mess, Lowry hit a provisional for a lost ball onto the green, a terrific shot. One problem. Someone found the ball. It was no longer lost, so the provisional ball was not in play.\n\nLowry took a penalty drop from the bush, going back to find a place where he had a swing, put it short of the green, chipped on and salvaged a double bogey 6.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6. It wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament,\" Lowry said.\n\nHe made five birdies on the day, and yet nothing felt better than a par. That came on the 12th, one of the toughest holes into the wind. He hit driver and 4-iron to 30 feet, two putts for a most beautiful, calming par.\n\n\"The best shots I've hit all week,\" Lowry said. \"From then on, it was playing quite difficult, but I felt like you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.\"\n\nAnd now comes a big opportunity for Lowry to reclaim that claret jug, for Rose to become the first player in the modern era of exemptions to come through 36-hole qualifying, and for Brown to become one of the biggest surprises since Ben Curtis in 2003 at Royal St. George's.\n\nAnd so many others are very much in the mix, starting with Scheffler, golf's best player.\n\n\"I've played two solid rounds and it put me five shots back, and I'll continue to try to execute and just continue to try to hit good shots and hit good putts,\" Scheffler said, making it all sound so simple on a day when nothing felt easy.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Woods is not the only big name to struggle in the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast as Rory McIlroy will begin his second round at seven over and likely needing an under par round to make the weekend. Lowry had been usurped at the top of the leaderboard late on Thursday by unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown, who posted a six under 65.\n\nHowever, the Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\nLowry leads by two shots from Brown, who showed little sign of nerves under the spotlight in his first major, with a steady 72 to sit at five under.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster,\" said Lowry on his travails at 11.\n\n\"To be leading this tournament after two days, it's why you come here.\"\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world number 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share of fourth at two under despite dropping a shot at 18.\n\nScheffler has already won six times this year, including his second Masters title in April.\n\nA monster putt at the 14th and a birdie on the par-five 16th took the American within striking range before a costly bogey on the last left him still five adrift of Lowry.\n\nWoods' tournament came to a sorry end after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\n\"I just need to keep progressing like that and then eventually start playing more competitively and start getting into kind of the competitive flow again,\" he said.\n\nBut the three-time British Open champion cut a sorry figure as he trudged around the Troon links with his two-round score leaving him in 149th out of the 154 players still active in the tournament.\n\nHis score of 156 over two rounds matches his worst ever at a major with the 2015 US Open and is his poorest at a British Open by three shots.\n\nStrong winds ensured low scoring remained difficult with the sixth, which had been the longest hole in British Open history on Thursday at 623 yards, reduced by 20 yards due to the conditions.\n\nAttention later turns to McIlroy's attempt to recover from a disastrous opening round of 78 with the projected cut sitting at four {"uri": "2024-07-426503327", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:43:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:43:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:55:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_1902844d-7d40-5376-b182-af7c9b42eeeb.html", "title": "Brown takes shock British Open lead as McIlroy, Woods suffer nightmare starts", "body": "Shane Lowry makes a birdie putt on the 18th green to finish the opening day at Troon one shot off the lead\n\nUnheralded Englishman Daniel Brown shot into a shock lead of the British Open at six under par as Rory McIlroy was among the big names to struggle on day one of the 152nd British Open at Royal Troon.\n\nBrown, the world number 272, birdied two of the last three holes to lead by one from 2019 winner Shane Lowry.\n\n\"I'm going to try and sort of keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" said Brown, who is competing at his first major.\n\nMcIlroy posted a seven over par round of 78 with his hopes of ending a 10-year wait to win a major floundering as most of the field struggled in the wet and windy conditions on Scotland's west coast.\n\nOf the 156 players in the field to complete their rounds, only 17 posted a score under par.\n\nLowry, who won his sole major at the British Open five years ago, made the most of the calm late afternoon conditions with three birdies in five holes around the turn and picked up another at the 18th.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again,\" said Lowry.\n\n\"It's great, but there's three rounds left. If I don't play well the next three rounds, it doesn't matter what I shot today. I'm fully aware that I have a job to do over the next three days.\"\n\nTwo-time major winner Justin Thomas is lurking at three under, while recently crowned USPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is among a group of seven on two under that also includes Justin Rose.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler cut a frustrated figure on the greens but is still in the mix after a one under round that featured four birdies and three bogeys.\n\nMcIlroy was aiming to get over his heartbreak at the US Open last month, where he missed two short putts to blow the lead as Bryson DeChambeau claimed his second major by one shot.\n\nHowever, the Northern Irishman's round, and probably championship, was blown off course at the postage stamp 120-yard eighth.\n\nMcIlroy was unfortunate as his near-perfect tee shot slipped off the green into a bunker, which he took two attempts to escape, to post a double bogey five.\n\nAnother double bogey followed at the 11th. He also dropped shots at the 10th, 15th and 18th.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" said McIlroy.\n\n\"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance.\"\n\n- Woods wobbles -\n\nDeChambeau had been the form player in the majors so far this year, despite his defection to the breakaway LIV Tour.\n\nThe American finished sixth at the Masters and runner-up in the USPGA Championship before claiming his second US Open.\n\nHowever, his struggles with the windy conditions of links golf continued as he was six over par for his opening nine holes.\n\nDeChambeau battled back on the back nine as an eagle on the 17th helped him to a 76.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today,\" said DeChambeau.\n\n\"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home'. But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. I'm excited for the challenge.\"\n\nThomas recovered from his own double bogey at the 12th to post a 68, which was 14 shots better than his opening round at Royal Liverpool 12 months ago.\n\nWorld number three Schauffele continued his fine form in recent months as he dropped just one shot to put himself among the chasing pack.\n\nTiger Woods had hit back at suggestions from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire, but the 15-time major champion failed to prove he can still be competitive with a 79.\n\n\"I didn't do a whole lot of things right today,\" said Woods. \"I had three 3-putts today. I didn't hit my irons very close, and I didn't give myself a whole lot of looks today.\"\n\nCameron Smith, champion at St. Andrews two years ago, fared even worse with an 80.\n\nWorld number four Ludvig Aberg was another of the big names to falter in his first ever round at a British Open with a four-over round of 75.\n\nkca/pi/ea/pb", "source": {"uri": "ccenterdispatch.com", "dataType": a two-under 69 on Friday morning to move to seven under and bolster his hopes of a second Open victory, five years on from his impressive breakthrough success at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry's closest challenge comes from former world No 1 Justin Rose and fellow Englishman Dan Brown, who led after the opening round of his major debut, while world No 1 Scottie Scheffler is within five of the lead and in tied-fourth as he chases a seventh win in 11 starts.\n\nThe Open: Leaderboard after R2\n\n-7 Shane Lowry (Irl); -5 Dan Brown (Eng), Justin Rose (Eng); -2 Billy Horschel (USA), Scottie Scheffler sand at the par-three fifth but birdied the Postage Stamp to reach the turn two ahead, which remained his cushion until he racked up a double-bogey at the 11th after pulling his approach into an unplayable lie in a gorse bush.\n\nPlease use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player\n\nLowry ended up with a double bogey on a dramatic 11th hole after being told he wasn't able to use his birdie the par-five 16th, before capping off an impressive round by draining a 20-footer at the last to secure a 36-hole major lead for the first time in his career.\n\nBrown was within one of the lead until a penultimate-hole bogey dropped him back to five under, while Rose was the standout performer in the afternoon wave and is also tied-second after mixing four birdies with a lone dropped {"uri": "8234066739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:43:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:43:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T19:43:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/sport/uk-sport/2024/07/19/open-leader-shane-lowry-ready-to-deal-with-whatever-royal-troon-throws-at-him/", "title": "Open leader Shane Lowry ready to deal with whatever Royal Troon throws at him", "body": "Lowry has a two-shot lead after adding a second-round 69 to his opening 66 at a blustery Royal Troon.\n\nShane Lowry believes he is ready to take whatever is thrown at him \"on the chin\" after keeping his bid for a second Open title firmly on track at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry added a second round of 69 to his opening 66 for a halfway total of seven under par and two-shot lead over English duo Justin Rose and Dan Brown, who both came through 36-hole final qualifiers earlier this month.\n\nWith a strong wind sending scores soaring for the later starters, Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy, Bryson DeChambeau, Ludvig Aberg and Tommy Fleetwood all missed the cut, but home favourite Robert MacIntyre and Justin Thomas fought back from horror starts to make the weekend.\n\nLowry also recovered from a double bogey on the 11th with birdies on the 16th and 18th as he bids to lift the Claret Jug for a second time following his triumph at Royal Portrush in 2019.\n\nSurprise overnight leader Brown, who had completed a flawless 65 at 9.33pm on Thursday, battled to a second round of 72, while Rose returned a superb 68 and has dropped just one shot in 36 holes.\n\nLowry felt he had \"done the hard part\" on the 11th by getting his tee shot in play, but was distracted by a cameraman on his second shot and pulled it into the gorse.\n\nAfter taking a penalty drop Lowry hit his fourth shot to around 10 feet to give himself a chance to salvage a bogey, only for his original ball to be found by a spectator.\n\nThat meant it was still in play and, after a long delay while it was determined where he could best take a drop, Lowry hit his approach just short of the green and eventually completed a double-bogey six.\n\nFormer Ryder Cup player David Howell, the on-course commentator with Lowry's group for Sky Sports, said the spectator who found the ball was \"being a little sheepish\" when he realised Lowry's intentions, adding: \"He's feeling awful.\"\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry explained. \"The referee asked me going down (the fairway) did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was OK.\n\n\"And Darren (Reynolds, his caddie) did a great job too. He kept telling me we have loads of time, we don't need to rush this.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster. I have felt quite calm and composed the last couple of days. I've felt really in my comfort zone.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. If I give myself a chance on Sunday I know I can do it and that's as good as a position to be in as any.\"\n\nBrown might have been expected to come back down to earth with a bump after his Thursday heroics, but the 29-year-old from Northallerton delivered an impressive sequel on his major debut.\n\n\"I've always been quite laid back really,\" Brown said. \"I think I am a bit of a realist as well.\n\n\"There's still 36 holes left. I might have a good round tomorrow and then I might have a stinky round on Sunday. You just don't know.\"\n\nRose's round drew high praise from six-time major winner Sir Nick Faldo, the last English winner of the Open in 1992, during a commentary stint on Sky Sports.\n\n\"Maybe the best 68 of his whole career on a day like today in this wind,\" Faldo said.\n\nSpeaking about his chance to make history, Rose said: \"When I won the US Open (in 2013) it was like 'First since Tony Jacklin' and they are nice moments when they come together, but you are never thinking of it.\n\n\"In the moment you are just trying to get the job done.\"\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler, Billy Horschel and Dean Burmester were five shots off the lead on two under par, with Jason Day, Xander Schauffele, Patrick Cantlay and Corey Conners all one under.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", {"uri": "8232563091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "23:17:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T23:17:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T23:15:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/first-timer-brown-survives-challenging-wind-takes-one-shot-lead-over-lowry-at-british-open-5689470", "title": "First-Timer Brown Survives Challenging Wind, Takes One-Shot Lead Over Lowry at British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- The wind at the British Open caught just about everyone off guard Thursday. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major-championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago, and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason, I felt like the crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop, and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine, but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th, and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nHe was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now McIlroy only wants to make it to the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course,\" McIlroy said. \"Then when the wind is like that, other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"", {"uri": "8232509626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:12:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:12:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:11:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://lethbridgenewsnow.com/2024/07/18/dan-brown-makes-late-birdies-for-a-1-shot-lead-over-shane-lowry-in-wind-challenged-british-open/", "title": "Dan Brown makes late birdies for a 1-shot lead over Shane Lowry in wind-challenged British Open", "body": "\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 69 included Mackenzie Hughes of Dundas, Ont., who ended his round with a birdie on 18, PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nCorey Conners of Listowel, Ont., shot an even round of 71, while Nick Taylor and Adam Hadwin, both from Abbotsford, B.C., were at 4-over 75.\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nHe was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. {"uri": "2024-07-426594663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "02:11:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T02:11:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T02:09:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.news18.com/sports/daniel-brown-takes-shock-british-open-lead-as-rory-mcilroy-tiger-woods-suffer-nightmare-starts-8970995.html", "title": "Daniel Brown Takes Shock British Open Lead as Rory McIlroy, Tiger Woods Suffer Nightmare Starts", "body": "Daniel Brown, the world number 272, birdied two of the last three holes to lead by one from 2019 winner Shane Lowry.\n\nUnheralded Englishman Daniel Brown shot into a shock lead of the British Open at six under par as Rory McIlroy was among the big names to struggle on day one of the 152nd British Open at Royal Troon.\n\nBrown, the world number 272, birdied two of the last three holes to lead by one from 2019 winner Shane Lowry.\n\n\"I'm going to try and sort of keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" said Brown, who is competing at his first major.\n\nAlso Read: Japanese Gymnast Sent Home From Paris For Smoking\n\nMcIlroy posted a seven over par round of 78 with his hopes of ending a 10-year wait to win a major floundering as most of the field struggled in the wet and windy conditions on Scotland's west coast.\n\nOf the 156 players in the field to complete their rounds, only 17 posted a score under par.\n\nLowry, who won his sole major at the British Open five years ago, made the most of the calm late afternoon conditions with three birdies in five holes around the turn and picked up another at the 18th.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again,\" said Lowry.\n\n\"It's great, but there's three rounds left. If I don't play well the next three rounds, it doesn't matter what I shot today. I'm fully aware that I have a job to do over the next three days.\"\n\nTwo-time major winner Justin Thomas is lurking at three under, while recently crowned USPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is among a group of seven on two under that also includes Justin Rose.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler cut a frustrated figure on the greens but is still in the mix after a one under round that featured four birdies and three bogeys.\n\nMcIlroy was aiming to get over his heartbreak at the US Open last month, where he missed two short putts to blow the lead as Bryson DeChambeau claimed his second major by one shot.\n\nHowever, the Northern Irishman's round, and probably championship, was blown off course at the postage stamp 120-yard eighth.\n\nMcIlroy was unfortunate as his near-perfect tee shot slipped off the green into a bunker, which he took two attempts to escape, to post a double bogey five.\n\nAnother double bogey followed at the 11th. He also dropped shots at the 10th, 15th and 18th.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" said McIlroy.\n\n\"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance.\"\n\n- Woods wobbles -\n\nDeChambeau had been the form player in the majors so far this year, despite his defection to the breakaway LIV Tour.\n\nThe American finished sixth at the Masters and runner-up in the USPGA Championship before claiming his second US Open.\n\nHowever, his struggles with the windy conditions of links golf continued as he was six over par for his opening nine holes.\n\nDeChambeau battled back on the back nine as an eagle on the 17th helped him to a 76.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today,\" said DeChambeau.\n\n\"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home'. But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. I'm excited for the challenge.\"\n\nThomas recovered from his own double bogey at the 12th to post a 68, which was 14 shots better than his opening round at Royal Liverpool 12 months ago.\n\nWorld number three Schauffele continued his fine form in recent months as he dropped just one shot to put himself among the chasing pack.\n\nTiger Woods had hit back at suggestions from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire, but the 15-time major champion failed to prove he can still be competitive with a 79.\n\n\"I didn't do a whole lot of things right today,\" said Woods. \"I had three 3-putts today. I didn't hit my irons very close, and I didn't give myself a whole lot of looks today.\"\n\nCameron Smith, champion at St. Andrews two years ago, fared even worse with an 80.\n\nWorld number four {"uri": "2024-07-426497145", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:30:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:30:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:08:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/shane-lowry-open-championship-career-best-good-omen", "title": "Shane Lowry career-best Open Championship start a good omen", "body": "Shane Lowry posted one of the best opening rounds at the Open Championship, carding a 5-under 66 Thursday.\n\nShane Lowry is known for having a good time, on and off the golf course. Following Thursday's opening round of the 152nd Open Championship, he surely is in good spirits.\n\nLowry, part of the afternoon wave, walked off the course posting a 5-under 66. That is the lowest opening round score of his Open Championship career. As he strolled off 18, he held the lead. Ultimately, Daniel Brown (ranked 272nd in the world), passed him at 6-under.\n\nNevertheless, Lowry played flawless golf on a day where the proved incredibly difficult. Of the 156 golfers that competed, only 17 finished under par.\n\nMeanwhile, some of the game's best like Rory McIlroy, Wyndham Clark, Max Homa and Bryson DeChambeau struggled mightily. The legend himself, Tiger Woods, also had a rough go Thursday. He finished 8-over par and is staring at an early exit from Royal Troon.\n\nFollowing his opening 18, Lowry maintained composure and put his great start into perspective.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy, but it's only one day. We've got three more days. I kept telling myself that out there because for some reason I felt like the crowd were getting very excited out there. It was late in the afternoon. A few points the attendance were high out there, I'd say. They were quite excitable out there, and it felt more like the weekend,\" Lowry said.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nHandled himself is quite the understatement.\n\nLowry was one of only three players to turn in a clean card, with five birdies and zero bogeys. The aforementioned Brown and Justin Rose did so also.\n\nShane Lowry looking to repeat history at The Open\n\nThe last time Shane Lowry shot under par to begin The Open was in 2019 at Royal Portrush. He would go on to win his first and only major three days later. But the 2019 Golfer of the Year is not putting any stock into that.\n\n\"Yeah. I mean, that doesn't mean anything. That was five years ago,\" said Lowry.\n\nFollowing a couple years with some tumultuous play, the Irishman seems to have found proper form. He, alongside teammate and fellow Irishman Rory McIroy, won the Zurich Classic earlier this year. He followed that up with a T6 at the PGA Championship, a top 20 finish at the U.S. Open and closed in ninth at his last tournament, the Travelers Championship.\n\nIndeed, there is a lot of golf left to play this week. The 37-year-old pro took advantage of the afternoon wave that saw lower winds and better scores. Can he replicate that Friday? He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nPeople are also reading... Highways flood and close. Illinois delegate caught in RNC commotion involving McCarthy, Gaetz Flick Fact: The LeRoy man who set an Illinois State Police record? Trump picks Sen. JD Vance of Ohio, a once-fierce critic turned loyal ally, as his GOP running mate Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Flick Fact: Is there really a river under Normal? Trump heads to convention as authorities investigate motive, security in assassination attempt\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use If I don't play well the next three rounds, it doesn't matter what I shot today. I'm fully aware that I have a job to do over the next three days.\"\n\nTwo-time major winner Justin Thomas is lurking at three under, while recently crowned USPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is among a group of seven on two under that also includes Justin Rose.\n\nWorld No 1 Scottie Scheffler cut a frustrated figure on the greens but is still in the mix after a one under round that featured four birdies and three bogeys.\n\nMcIlroy was aiming to get over his heartbreak at the US Open last month, where he missed two short putts to blow the lead as Bryson DeChambeau claimed his second major by one shot.\n\nHowever, the Northern Irishman's round, and probably championship, was blown off course at the postage stamp 120-yard eighth.\n\nNear-perfect shot slips off\n\nMcIlroy was unfortunate as his near-perfect tee shot slipped off the green into a bunker, which he took two attempts to escape, to post a double bogey five.\n\nAnother double bogey followed at the 11th. He also dropped shots at the 10th, 15th and 18th.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" said McIlroy.\n\n\"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance.\"\n\nWoods wobbles\n\nDeChambeau had been the form player in the majors so far this year, despite his defection to the breakaway LIV Tour.\n\nThe American finished sixth at the Masters and runner-up in the USPGA Championship before claiming his second US Open.\n\nHowever, his struggles with the windy conditions of links golf continued as he was six over par for his opening nine holes.\n\nDeChambeau battled back on the back nine as an eagle on the 17th helped him to a 76.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today,\" said DeChambeau.\n\n\"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home'. But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. I'm excited for the challenge.\"\n\nThomas recovered from his own double bogey at the 12th to post a 68, which was 14 shots better than his opening round at Royal Liverpool 12 months ago.\n\nSchauffele's continues fine form\n\nWorld No 3 Schauffele continued his fine form in recent months as he dropped just one shot to put himself among the chasing pack.\n\nTiger Woods had hit back at suggestions from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire, but the 15-time major champion failed to prove he can still be competitive with a 79.\n\n\"I didn't do a whole lot of things right today,\" said Woods. \"I had three 3-putts today. I didn't hit my irons very close, and I didn't give myself a whole lot of looks today.\"\n\nCameron Smith, champion at St. Andrews two years ago, fared even worse with an 80.\n\nWorld No 4 Ludvig Aberg was another of the big names to falter in his first ever round at a British Open with a four-over round of 75.", "source": {"uri": "gulfnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GULF NEWS"}, {"uri": "8234105531", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:23:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:23:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:22:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/lowry-takes-british-open-lead-as-mcilroy-woods-miss-cut/article_e0176e57-6632-5833-9cab-93596a83345c.html", "title": "Lowry takes British Open lead as McIlroy, Woods miss cut", "body": "Rory McIlroy's decade-long wait for a major goes on after missing the cut at the British Open\n\nShane Lowry moved into the lead of the 152nd British Open at seven under par after his second round at Royal Troon on Friday as Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods were among the star names to miss the cut.\n\nOnly 10 of the 154 players left in the field are under par as the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast wreaked havoc with five of the world's top 10 failing to make the weekend.\n\nLowry leads by two from Justin Rose, who came through qualifying to book his place in Troon, and unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown on his major debut.\n\nThe Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\n\"To be leading this tournament after two days, it's why you come here,\" said Lowry.\n\n\"The job tomorrow as well is to try to put myself in a position to win this tournament on Sunday.\"\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world number 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share of fourth at two under despite dropping a shot at 18.\n\nScheffler has already won six times this year, including his second Masters title in April.\n\nA monster putt at the 14th and a birdie on the par-five 16th took the American within striking range before a costly bogey on the last left him still five adrift of Lowry.\n\nUSPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is also well in the running at one under.\n\n- Woods' worst ever Open -\n\nMcIlroy's decade-long wait for a major will extend into 2025 at least after a disastrous two days to finish on 11 over.\n\nThe world number two needed an under par round after shooting 78 on Thursday but carded a triple bogey eight at the fourth in a run of six dropped shots in four holes.\n\nWoods was one of the few players to finish below McIlroy on 14 over after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\n\"I just need to keep progressing like that and then eventually start playing more competitively and start getting into kind of the competitive flow again,\" he said.\n\nThe three-time British Open champion's score of 156 over two rounds matches his worst ever at a major with the 2015 US Open and was his poorest at this event by three shots.\n\nUS Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, Ludvig Aberg, Wyndham Clark and Viktor Hovland were the other top-10 players to miss the cut.\n\nThey were joined by 2022 champion Cam Smith, Tommy Fleetwood and Sahith Theegala.\n\nScottish Open champion Bob MacIntyre bounced back from dropping eight shots in later starters.\n\nThe 2019 champion recovered from a double bogey on the 11th with birdies on the 16th and 18th to hold a two-shot lead over the English duo of Justin Rose and Dan Brown, who both had to come through 36-hole final qualifiers earlier this month.\n\nSurprise overnight leader Brown, who had completed a flawless 65 at 9.33pm on Thursday, battled to a second round of 72, while Rose returned a superb 68 and has amazingly dropped just one shot in 36 holes.\n\nLowry felt he had \"done the hard part\" on the 11th, named 'The Railway' due to the adjacent Glasgow to Ayr train line, by getting his tee shot in play, but was distracted by a cameraman on his second shot and pulled it into the gorse.\n\nAfter taking a penalty drop Lowry hit his fourth shot to around 10 feet to give himself a chance to salvage a bogey, only for his original ball to be found by a spectator.\n\nThat meant it was still in play and, after a long delay while it was determined where he could best take a drop, Lowry hit his approach just short of the green and eventually completed a double-bogey six.\n\nFormer Ryder Cup player David Howell, the on-course commentator with Lowry's group for Sky {"uri": "8232516297", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:18:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:18:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:17:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/golf/2024/7/18/24201462/the-open-shane-lowry-scorching-hot-putter-career-first", "title": "The Open: Shane Lowry's scorching hot putter leads to career first", "body": "Shane Lowry looked unbeatable at Royal Troon on Thursday at the Open Championship.\n\nThe 2019 Open Champion carded a bogey-free, 5-under 66 in brutal conditions. He trails Daniel Brown, who fired off a bogey-free 6-under 65, by one shot as he sits in solo second.\n\nOnly 17 players fired under-par scores during the first round, a testament to the 25-mile-per-hour winds that blew across Royal Troon. Very few players kept a clean scorecard, too.\n\nBut Lowry's preparation for this tournament is why he is towards the top of the leaderboard after day one. He played many practice rounds early and took advantage of his later tee time.\n\n\"I'm very happy. I went out there -- lucky I watched a lot of golf this morning and saw that the golf course was not playing easy,\" Lowry said.\n\n\"I tried to go out, play my game, hit some good shots, and hole a few putts. I did that, and I'm pretty happy.\"\n\nThe Irishman had 25 putts after the first round, tied for first among the field. He made three birdies in six holes on the front nine to turn in 33 shots, a 3-under par score.\n\nLowry made another par-breaker on the 11th, and his final birdie came on the 18th.\n\nHe explained that a trip to Royal Troon two weeks ago helped him adjust to these greens.\n\n\"Sometimes I struggle when I come back from playing a season on the PGA Tour with the speed of the greens,\" Lowry said.\n\n\"I got here, and I played a couple of practice rounds here, and I was really happy with how my speed was... I wasn't struggling to get the ball to the hole because sometimes I can be like that. My speed control was very good, and I saw my lines great. I feel like links greens when you start to see your lines, the hole feels quite big, so it felt like that today, and long may it continue.\"\n\nThis 66 marks his lowest first-round score in a major championship. In 2019, at Royal Portrush, Lowry shot a 67 that first day. While he was happy with the score, the 37-year-old stayed realistic.\n\n\"It's only one day. We've got three more days,\" Lowry said.\n\n\"I kept telling myself that out there because, for some reason, I felt like the crowd was getting very excited. They were quite excitable, and it felt more like the weekend. I kept telling myself there's a lot more to do, and there's a few days left, so I stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nLowry said he would give anything to win this tournament again but does not want to look ahead. This first-round score will mean nothing if he does not play well in the next three days.\n\nSo, it appears the Irishman will keep himself grounded, as 54 holes remain Normally, Lowry likes to have an early round on Thursday and a late one on Friday, but he has the opposite this week. It is a quick turnaround that will allow him to get after it.\n\nThe conditions will be similar at The Open for Friday's round, too.\n\n\"If they are, it's not going to be easy, and pars are going to be good. That's kind of the game plan,\" Lowry said.\n\nLowry tees off at 4:47 a.m. ET for the second round with Cameron Smith and Matt Fitzpatrick. {"uri": "8233766149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "15:29:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T15:29:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:28:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/lowry-takes-british-open-lead-as-torrid-tiger-misses-cut/", "title": "Lowry takes British Open lead as torrid Tiger misses cut | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "Shane Lowry moved into the lead of the 152nd British Open at seven under par after his second round at Royal Troon on Friday as a tame Tiger Woods limped to 14 over to miss the cut.\n\nWoods is not the only big name to struggle in the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast as Rory McIlroy will begin his second round at seven over and likely needing an under par round to make the weekend.\n\nLowry had been usurped at the top of the leaderboard late on Thursday by unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown, who posted a six under 65.\n\nHowever, the Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\nHe leads by two shots from Brown, who showed little sign of nerves under the spotlight in his first major, with a steady first 14 holes to sit at five under.\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world number 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share of fourth at two under despite dropping a shot at 18.\n\nScheffler has already won six times this year, including his second Masters title in April.\n\nThe American was not blown off track as the winds strengthened through Friday afternoon with 11 pars in his opening 13 holes before a monster putt at the 14th and a birdie on the par-five 16th took him within striking range.\n\nHowever, a costly bogey on the last left him still four adrift of Lowry.\n\nUSPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is also in the mix after a one over par round was enough to keep him in the top 10 at one under.\n\n- Woods' worst ever Open -\n\nWoods' tournament came to a sorry end after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\nBut the three-time British Open champion cut a sorry figure as he trudged around the Troon links with his two-round score a tie for 149th out of the 154 players still active in the tournament.\n\nHis score of 156 over two rounds matches his worst ever at a major with the 2015 US Open and is his poorest at a British Open by three shots.\n\nStrong winds ensured low scoring remained difficult with the sixth, which had been the longest hole in British Open history on Thursday at 623 yards, reduced by 20 yards due to the conditions.\n\nAttention later turns to McIlroy's attempt to recover from a disastrous opening round of 78 with the projected cut sitting at four over.\n\nThe Northern Irishman's chances of ending a decade-long drought to win British Open lead as torrid Tiger misses cut", "body": "World number one Scottie Scheffler closed to within four shots of the lead at the British Open\n\nShane Lowry moved into the lead of the 152nd British Open at seven under par after his second round at Royal Troon on Friday as a tame Tiger Woods limped to 14 over to miss the cut.\n\nWoods is not the only big name to struggle in the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast as Rory McIlroy will begin his second round at seven over and likely needing an under par round to make the weekend.\n\nLowry had been usurped at the top of the leaderboard late on Thursday by unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown, who posted a six under 65.\n\nHowever, the Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\nHe leads by two shots from Brown, who showed little sign of nerves under the spotlight in his first major, with a steady first 14 holes to sit at five under.\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world number 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share of fourth at two under despite dropping a shot at 18.\n\nScheffler has already won six times this year, including his second Masters title in April.\n\nThe American was not blown off track as the winds strengthened through Friday afternoon with 11 pars in his opening 13 holes before a monster putt at the 14th and a birdie on the par-five 16th took him within striking range.\n\nHowever, a costly bogey on the last left him still four adrift of Lowry.\n\nUSPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is also in the mix after a one over par round was enough to keep him in the top 10 at one under.\n\n- Woods' worst ever Open -\n\nWoods' tournament came to a sorry end after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\nBut the three-time British Open champion cut a sorry figure as he trudged around the Troon links with his two-round score a tie for 149th out of the 154 players still active in the tournament.\n\nHis score of 156 over
