{"uri": "2024-07-426467347", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:37:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:37:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:36:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/golf/news/12176/13180526/the-open-daniel-brown-leads-shane-lowry-after-opening-day-at-royal-troon-as-rory-mcilroy-tiger-woods-struggle", "title": "The Open: Daniel Brown leads Shane Lowry after opening day at Royal Troon as Rory McIlroy, Tiger Woods struggle", "body": "Highlights from the first round of The 152nd Open where Daniel Brown leads by one shot over Shane Lowry as Rory McIlroy had a tough day at Royal Troon\n\nMajor debutant Daniel Brown topped the leaderboard after an eventful opening round at The 152nd Open, as Shane Lowry made a fast start and Rory McIlroy's hopes suffered a setback at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry - who lifted the Claret Jug in 2019 - carded the lowest round of his major career after a five-under 66, with the fast start also his first bogey-free round at The Open since day three of his major success at Royal Portrush.\n\nThe Irishman looked destined for the first-round lead until Brown - playing in the penultimate group - birdied two of his last four holes to close a stunning six-under 65 and snatch top spot, on a day where many of the field struggled in windy conditions on the Scottish coast.\n\nUS Open champion Bryson DeChambeau stuttered to a five-over 76 and McIlroy's hopes of ending his major drought appear all-but over after an opening-round 78, while Tiger Woods is in danger of a third consecutive missed cut following an eight-over 79.\n\nHow Brown edged ahead of Lowry in Scotland\n\nLowry scrambled pars on each of his first three holes by following a 10-foot birdie at the par-five fourth by making back-to-back gain from the seventh, with an up and down from off the ninth green seeing him save par and reach the turn in 33.\n\nThe world No 33 holed from 25 feet to salvage an unlikely par at the tenth and converted from a few feet closer to take advantage of the par-four next, lifting him into the solo lead, with Lowry capping off a brilliant day by firing his approach at the last to inside six feet to set up a closing birdie.\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" Lowry told Sky Sports. \"I got off to a bit of an iffy start and holed a couple of nice par putts early on and then I was off and running.\n\n\"I try not to think about it [2019] too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'. No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nLowry's closest challenge came from Brown, playing in the penultimate group, who charged up the leaderboard after carding a front-nine 34 and then adding successive birdies from the tenth to get within one of the lead.\n\nBrown got up and down from a tough lie at the par-five 16th to make a birdie to move alongside Lowry, before grabbing the solo advantage after rolling in from eight feet to pick up a shot at the last - in near-darkness - and move to six under.\n\nTwo-time PGA champion Justin Thomas set the initial target after a birdie-birdie finish gave him a three-under 68, leaving him three strokes back in third, while Alex Noren, Justin Rose and reigning PGA champion Xander Schauffele are among the group in tied-fourth on two under.\n\nWorld No 1 Scottie Scheffler began his bid for a seventh victory in 11 starts with a one-under 70, leaving him in the group tied-11th also containing five-time major champion Brooks Koepka, Matt Fitzpatrick and Matt Wallace, with just 17 of the 158 players ending the day under par.\n\nDeChambeau needed a 55-foot eagle at the par-five 16th to stay within 11 shots of the lead, while McIlroy admitted his focus was simply making the cut rather than challenging for the Claret Jug after carding one of the highest opening rounds of his major career.\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, having double-bogeyed the Postage Stamp as part of five dropped shots in four holes, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nWoods made a great start when he holed a long-range putt for a birdie at the third, only to add just one more in a round containing six bogeys and two double bogeys. {"uri": "8232490630", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:50:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:50:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:49:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/british-open-golf-brown-woods-thomas-scotland/article_76ede15b-c9eb-51e2-a7cd-09e2f635d461.html", "title": "Late birdies give Brown 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "Tiger Woods of the United States waits to putt on the 18th green during Thursday's opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Troon, Scotland.\n\nDOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nPeople are also reading... Despite fame and fortune, Loggins was \"still from Bristol\" HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster BHC GIRLS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Funk found redemption at Eastside BHC BOYS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Bearcats reload, reach first state finals in 64 years BHC GIRLS BASKETBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: It was love at first bounce for McAmis Bristol's Loggins had a massive musical impact Virginia man stopped woman from opening plane's emergency door Kilgore remembered as \"larger than life\" trailblazer HIGH SCHOOL ATHLETICS: Southern Gap Eagles coming soon when Buchanan schools consolidate Man suffers Friday morning gunshot wound Shanghai Restaurant remains a downtown landmark Bristol Casino records solid $14.35M month during June Blood Eagle to offer unique, fine dining experience Southern Gap Outdoor Adventure Unveils New Entrance Sign\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to {"uri": "8233967709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:08:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:08:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:07:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.si.com/golf/shane-lowry-double-bogey-rules-confusion-but-recovers-british-open", "title": "Shane Lowry Makes Double Bogey After Rules Confusion but Recovers to Lead British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- The rail line that borders the 11th hole at Royal Troon is daunting enough for what is already the hardest hole on the course. Shane Lowry got past that part.\n\nBut it was his second shot from the right rough that potentially caused him a great deal of angst on Friday afternoon, one that led to a provisional he couldn't use, a ruling, a drop and a double bogey that he was actually happy to achieve.\n\nLowry, the Irishman who won the 2019 British Open at Royal Portrush, put himself in position to get a crack at another Claret Jug this weekend with a second-round 69 that included him bouncing back from near-disaster at the par-4 11th to lead by two over 2013 U.S. Open champion Justin Rose and first-time major participant Daniel Brown.\n\n\"I did the hard part. I hit my drive where you could find it, which is obviously a hard thing to do on that hole,\" Lowry said of the tee shot that preceded all the drama.\n\n\"I got a little bit distracted on the right just as I was over the shot, and I kind of lost a bit of train of thought. You're so afraid of going right there that I just snagged the club and went left.\"\n\nLowry smother-hooked the shot from the right rough into gorse left of the fairway and behind the spectator line. The ball flew into it and the situation appeared dire. Lowry took a drop, believing his ball would be declared lost. It meant hitting his fourth to the green.\n\n\"Then from there, I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry said. \"The referee asked me going down, did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was O.K. Then we get down there, and somebody had found it. So apparently we have to find it then, or you have to go and identify it, which I thought, if you declared it lost before it was found, that you didn't, you didn't have to go and identify it.\"\n\nAh, but he did. Under Rule 18.3c (3), if the original ball is found, it must be played as it lies. That was not possible, so Lowry needed to take a penalty. The provisional was on longer in use.\n\n\"I felt like through that whole process of that 20 minutes, it was whatever it was, of taking the drop, seeing where I could drop, and I felt like I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing, and I felt like Darren (his caddie) did a great job too just kind of -- he kept telling me, we have loads of time,\" Lowry said. \"We don't need to rush this. We just need to do the right thing here.\n\nWith his fourth shot after the drop from left of the fairway, Lowry advanced to the front of the green then got up-and-down for double bogey.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6,\" Lowry said. \"It was not like -- it wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament.\"\n\nLowry came back to par four straight holes before birdies at the 16th and 18th holes helped him regain those two dropped shots.\n\n\"I think the 12th hole for me was key,\" said Lowry, 37, a six-time winner in Europe and a three-time winner on the PGA tour. \"Twelve was playing very difficult, straight into the wind. I hit driver, 4-iron there, the best shots I've hit all week and made par there. From then on, I felt like it was playing quite difficult, but I felt you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.\"", "source": {"uri": "si.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8232481643", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:41:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:41:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:40:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/british-open-golf-brown-woods-thomas-scotland/article_0a90d824-258c-52dc-bb89-3b8c7c0e2acd.html", "title": "Late birdies give Brown 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "Alexander Bjork of Sweden plays out of a bunker on the fifth hole during Thursday's opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Troon, Scotland.\n\nDOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nPeople are also reading... La Crosse woman arrested after Onalaska traffic stop on drug trafficking charges Steve Cahalan: New South Side Aldi store to open July 25 in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Melrose gets an event center; La Crosse Aldi store opening date set UW-La Crosse faculty committee recommends Joe Gow to be fired from tenured position on campus Police standoff with 33-year-old man wanted for child sexual assault ends peacefully with arrest RNC: Trump campaign upset with empty Wisconsin delegate floor seats One dead after head-on collision on Highway 93 near Arcadia Anti-war protester arrested after confrontation with US Rep. Derrick Van Orden in Milwaukee Massive expansion of MSP airport will bring with it years of demolitions and disruptions UPDATE: Motorcyclist who died in rural De Soto crash identified Baseball: Viroqua community mourns loss of legendary coach Pete Swanson Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead 'She would be proud': New Campbell dog park honors late resident and beloved pet on French Island Farm ordered to pay $210K for wastewater permit violations; owner disputes Monroe County court ruling Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use {"uri": "2024-07-426500098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:35:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:35:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:55:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/brown-takes-shock-british-open-lead-as-mcilroy-woods-suffer-nightmare-starts/article_e703386f-ba50-58c0-98d1-96d0ffbc8766.html", "title": "Brown takes shock British Open lead as McIlroy, Woods suffer nightmare starts", "body": "Shane Lowry makes a birdie putt on the 18th green to finish the opening day at Troon one shot off the lead\n\nUnheralded Englishman Daniel Brown shot into a shock lead of the British Open at six under par as Rory McIlroy was among the big names to struggle on day one of the 152nd British Open at Royal Troon.\n\nBrown, the world number 272, birdied two of the last three holes to lead by one from 2019 winner Shane Lowry.\n\n\"I'm going to try and sort of keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" said Brown, who is competing at his first major.\n\nMcIlroy posted a seven over par round of 78 with his hopes of ending a 10-year wait to win a major floundering as most of the field struggled in the wet and windy conditions on Scotland's west coast.\n\nOf the 156 players in the field to complete their rounds, only 17 posted a score under par.\n\nLowry, who won his sole major at the British Open five years ago, made the most of the calm late afternoon conditions with three birdies in five holes around the turn and picked up another at the 18th.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again,\" said Lowry.\n\n\"It's great, but there's three rounds left. If I don't play well the next three rounds, it doesn't matter what I shot today. I'm fully aware that I have a job to do over the next three days.\"\n\nTwo-time major winner Justin Thomas is lurking at three under, while recently crowned USPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is among a group of seven on two under that also includes Justin Rose.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler cut a frustrated figure on the greens but is still in the mix after a one under round that featured four birdies and three bogeys.\n\nMcIlroy was aiming to get over his heartbreak at the US Open last month, where he missed two short putts to blow the lead as Bryson DeChambeau claimed his second major by one shot.\n\nHowever, the Northern Irishman's round, and probably championship, was blown off course at the postage stamp 120-yard eighth.\n\nMcIlroy was unfortunate as his near-perfect tee shot slipped off the green into a bunker, which he took two attempts to escape, to post a double bogey five.\n\nAnother double bogey followed at the 11th. He also dropped shots at the 10th, 15th and 18th.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" said McIlroy.\n\n\"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance.\"\n\n- Woods wobbles -\n\nDeChambeau had been the form player in the majors so far this year, despite his defection to the breakaway LIV Tour.\n\nThe American finished sixth at the Masters and runner-up in the USPGA Championship before claiming his second US Open.\n\nHowever, his struggles with the windy conditions of links golf continued as he was six over par for his opening nine holes.\n\nDeChambeau battled back on the back nine as an eagle on the 17th helped him to a 76.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today,\" said DeChambeau.\n\n\"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home'. But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. I'm excited for the challenge.\"\n\nThomas recovered from his own double bogey at the 12th to post a 68, which was 14 shots better than his opening round at Royal Liverpool 12 months ago.\n\nWorld number three Schauffele continued his fine form in recent months as he dropped just one shot to put himself among the chasing pack.\n\nTiger Woods had hit back at suggestions from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire, but the 15-time major champion failed to prove he can still be competitive with a 79.\n\n\"I didn't do a whole lot of things right today,\" said Woods. \"I had three 3-putts today. I didn't hit my irons very close, and I didn't give myself a whole lot of looks today.\"\n\nCameron Smith, champion at St. Andrews two years ago, fared even worse with an 80.\n\nWorld number four Ludvig Aberg was another of the big names to falter in his first ever round at a British Open with a four-over round of 75.\n\nkca/pi/ea/pb\n\nMore from this section\n\nFoundation for a Drug-Free World Drug Prevention Nonprofit Earns Consultative Status to the UN\n\nHow to Unlock a Disabled iPhone without iTunes? {"uri": "2024-07-426545800", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "00:21:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T00:21:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:42:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/sports/20240718-brown-takes-shock-british-open-lead-as-mcilroy-woods-suffer-nightmare-starts", "title": "Brown takes shock British Open lead as McIlroy, Woods suffer nightmare starts", "body": "Troon (United Kingdom) (AFP) - Unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown shot into a shock lead of the British Open at six under par as Rory McIlroy was among the big names to struggle on day one of the 152nd British Open at Royal Troon.\n\nBrown, the world number 272, birdied two of the last three holes to lead by one from 2019 winner Shane Lowry.\n\n\"I'm going to try and sort of keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" said Brown, who is competing at his first major.\n\nMcIlroy posted a seven over par round of 78 with his hopes of ending a 10-year wait to win a major floundering as most of the field struggled in the wet and windy conditions on Scotland's west coast.\n\nOf the 156 players in the field to complete their rounds, only 17 posted a score under par.\n\nLowry, who won his sole major at the British Open five years ago, made the most of the calm late afternoon conditions with three birdies in five holes around the turn and picked up another at the 18th.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again,\" said Lowry.\n\n\"It's great, but there's three rounds left. If I don't play well the next three rounds, it doesn't matter what I shot today. I'm fully aware that I have a job to do over the next three days.\"\n\nTwo-time major winner Justin Thomas is lurking at three under, while recently crowned USPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is among a group of seven on two under that also includes Justin Rose.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler cut a frustrated figure on the greens but is still in the mix after a one under round that featured four birdies and three bogeys.\n\nMcIlroy was aiming to get over his heartbreak at the US Open last month, where he missed two short putts to blow the lead as Bryson DeChambeau claimed his second major by one shot.\n\nHowever, the Northern Irishman's round, and probably championship, was blown off course at the postage stamp 120-yard eighth.\n\nMcIlroy was unfortunate as his near-perfect tee shot slipped off the green into a bunker, which he took two attempts to escape, to post a double bogey five.\n\nAnother double bogey followed at the 11th. He also dropped shots at the 10th, 15th and 18th.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" said McIlroy.\n\n\"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance.\"\n\nWoods wobbles\n\nDeChambeau had been the form player in the majors so far this year, despite his defection to the breakaway LIV Tour.\n\nThe American finished sixth at the Masters and runner-up in the USPGA Championship before claiming his second US Open.\n\nHowever, his struggles with the windy conditions of links golf continued as he was six over par for his opening nine holes.\n\nDeChambeau battled back on the back nine as an eagle on the 17th helped him to a 76.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today,\" said DeChambeau.\n\n\"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home'. But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. I'm excited for the challenge.\"\n\nThomas recovered from his own double bogey at the 12th to post a 68, which was 14 shots better than his opening round at Royal Liverpool 12 months ago.\n\nWorld number three Schauffele continued his fine form in recent months as he dropped just one shot to put himself among the chasing pack.\n\nTiger Woods had hit back at suggestions from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire, but the 15-time major champion failed to prove he can still be competitive with a 79.\n\n\"I didn't do a whole lot of things right today,\" said Woods. \"I had three 3-putts today. I didn't hit my irons very close, and I didn't give myself a whole lot of looks today.\"\n\nCameron Smith, champion at St. Andrews two years ago, fared even worse with an 80.\n\nWorld number four Ludvig Aberg was another of the big names to falter in his first ever round at a British Open with a four-over round of 75.", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "RFI"}, Open lead as torrid Tiger Woods misses cut", "body": "Troon: Shane Lowry moved into the lead of the 152nd British Open at seven under par after his second round at Royal Troon on Friday as a tame Tiger Woods limped to 14 over to miss the cut.\n\nGet exclusive content with Gulf News WhatsApp channel\n\nWoods is not the only big name to struggle in the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast as Rory McIlroy will begin his second round at seven over and likely needing an under par round to make the weekend.\n\nLowry had been usurped at the top of the leaderboard late on Thursday by unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown, who posted a six under 65.\n\nSign of nerves\n\nHowever, the Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\nHe leads by two shots from Brown, who showed little sign of nerves under the spotlight in his first major, with a steady first 14 holes to sit at five under.\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world No 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nCostly miss\n\nWorld No 1 Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share of fourth at two under despite dropping a shot at 18.\n\nScheffler has already won six times this year, including his second Masters title in April.\n\nThe American was not blown off track as the winds strengthened through Friday afternoon with 11 pars in his opening 13 holes before a monster putt at the 14th and a birdie on the par-five 16th took him within striking range.\n\nHowever, a costly bogey on the last left him still four adrift of Lowry.\n\nUSPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is also in the mix after a one over par round was enough to keep him in the top 10 at one under.\n\nWoods' worst ever Open\n\nWoods' tournament came to a sorry end after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\n\"I'd like to have played more, but I just wanted to make sure that I was able to play the major championships this year,\" Woods told reporters after his second round the west coast of Scotland.\n\n\"I've gotten better, even though my results really haven't shown it, but physically I've gotten better, which is great.\n\n\"I just need to keep progressing like that and then eventually start playing more competitively and start getting into kind of the competitive flow again.\"\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\nBut the three-time British Open champion cut a sorry figure as he trudged around the Troon links with his two-round score a tie for 149th out of the 154 players still active in the tournament.\n\nHis score of 156 over two rounds matches his worst ever at a major with the 2015 US Open and is his poorest at a British Open by three shots.\n\nStrong winds\n\nStrong winds ensured low scoring remained difficult with the sixth, which had been the longest hole in British Open history on Thursday at 623 yards, reduced by 20 yards due to the conditions.\n\nAttention later turns to McIlroy's attempt to recover from a disastrous opening round of 78 with the projected cut sitting at four over.\n\nThe Northern Irishman's chances of ending a decade-long drought to win a major already appear gone.\n\nBut the world number two has only failed to make the cut once in his last 14 majors.\n\nUS Open champion Bryson DeChambeau also has {"uri": "2024-07-427472629", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:18:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:18:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:22:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.espn.co.uk/golf/story/_/id/40597073/shane-lowry-moves-cameraman-distraction-lead-open", "title": "Lowry regroups after lost-ball ruling, leads Open", "body": "Senior college football writer Author of seven books on college football Graduate of the University of Georgia\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Shane Lowry holds a two-shot lead at the 152nd Open Championship, but only after he survived a debacle involving a photographer and a spectator on the 11th hole at Royal Troon Golf Club on Friday.\n\nLowry, who started the round one stroke behind Daniel Brown, had a two-stroke lead over the relatively unknown qualifier and 2018 Open runner-up Justin Rose after posting a 2-under 69 to move to 7 under after 36 holes.\n\nLowry had a two-stroke lead over Brown, who shot a 1-over 72 on Friday, when he stepped to the 11th hole, which is known as \"The Railway\" and is considered the most difficult on the course because of the railroad running down the right side of the fairway and thick gorse protecting the left.\n\nAfter safely hitting his tee shot 301 yards down the right side, Lowry was left with 176 yards to the pin. As Lowry prepared to hit his approach shot, he noticed a photographer standing several yards in front of him.\n\n\"There was a cameraman there and he was walking up, and I asked him to stop or move back, and he just kind of stayed there,\" said Lowry, who is looking for his second major title after winning the 2019 Open Championship.\n\nThe photographer raised his camera, and the movement distracted Lowry, he said, causing him to smother his shot out of the high fescue. His ball shot across the fairway and landed in gorse on the left.\n\nLowry turned his frustration to the photographer, telling him, \"Just get outta the way. Just get back there. F---'s sake.\"\n\n\"I did the hard part,\" Lowry said. \"I hit my drive where you could find it, which is obviously a hard thing to do on that hole. I had a nice lie in the rough. I got a little bit distracted on the right just as I was over the shot, and I kind of lost a bit of train of thought. You're so afraid of going right there that I just snagged the club and went left.\"\n\nLowry informed the R&A rules official walking with his group that he was hitting a provisional shot in case his ball was lost. He hit a new ball onto the green, about 15 feet past the hole.\n\nThat's when the real drama ensued. As Lowry was walking up the fairway, he was informed that a spectator had found his original ball in the gorse. Since his ball wasn't actually lost, he had to take an unplayable lie and identify an acceptable spot to hit from.\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry said. \"The referee asked me going down, did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was OK. Then we get down there and somebody had found it. So apparently we have to find it then or you have to go and identify it. I thought if you declared it lost before it was found, you didn't have to go and identify it.\"\n\nLowry asked for a second official to confirm the ruling. After a 20-minute delay, he took a one-stroke penalty for an unplayable lie and dropped his original ball on trampled rough, two club lengths from the previous spot in the gorse bush. His view of the 11th green was obstructed, and his fourth shot landed short of the green. Lowry two-putted from 33 feet.\n\nThe double-bogey 6 dropped Lowry into a first-place tie with Brown at 5 under.\n\n\"I felt like through that whole process of that 20 minutes of taking the drop, seeing where I could drop, I felt like I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing,\" Lowry said. \"I felt like [caddie] Darren [Reynolds] did a great job too. He kept telling me, 'We have loads of time. We don't need to rush this. We just need to do the right thing here.'\"\n\nLowry carded pars on each of the next four holes. He reached the par-5 16th green in two shots and two-putted from 58 feet for a birdie. A 20\u00bd-foot birdie on the par-4 18th extended his lead over Brown to two shots.\n\n\"I felt like I went out there, I was in control of my ball [and] did all the right things for a lot of the round,\" Lowry said. \"Then when I got in a bit of trouble, I feel like I really finished the round well. I'm pretty happy with the day. To be leading this tournament after two days, it's why you come here, it's why we're here.\"\n\nRose, who finished second in 2018 at Carnoustie Golf Links, had to go through final qualifying to make the field this year. He is making the most of his opportunity, carding a 3-under 68 on Friday, including a 41\u00bd-footer on No. 18 to get to 5 under and tie Brown for second.\n\nIt's Rose's best 36-hole position in a major since he had a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the 2021 Masters. He finished seventh at Augusta National that year.\n\nAn Englishman hasn't won The Open since Nick Faldo in 1992. When Rose captured the 2013 U.S. Open, he was the first golfer from England to do it since Tony Jacklin in 1970.\n\n\"Those are nice moments when it comes together and you can share the story of what it means, but you're never thinking of it, and we are pretty selfish from that point of view,\" Rose said. \"Like we want it for us, and obviously it's great to share it with everybody that it's meaningful to, but in the moment you're just trying to get the job done.\"\n\nWorld No. 1 Scottie Scheffler was five shots behind Lowry after posting a 1-under 70 for the second straight round. Scheffler's caddie, Ted Scott, labored through the round after battling a stomach illness Thursday night. He was seen lying on the ground and sitting between holes Friday.\n\n\"He seemed to feel better as the day went on,\" Scheffler said. \"The doc here took good care of him, but he did not sleep very much last night apparently. We didn't know if he was going to be able to go this morning, but he fought it out. You saw him laying down probably quite a bit out there, which was pretty funny.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mark_schlabach@espn.co.uk", "name": "Mark Schlabach", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulex", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Ulex"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-stroke_engine", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Two-stroke engine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_football", "type": {"uri": "8234090175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:06:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:06:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:05:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5647761/2024/07/19/justin-rose-open-championship-round-2/", "title": "Shane Lowry leads, Justin Rose tied for second after Round 2 of Open Championship", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- By the time 30 mile per hour gusts of the Firth of Clyde destroyed golf rounds through much of Friday afternoon, Shane Lowry and Daniel Brown stood atop the Open Championship field ready to play in the final group Saturday.\n\nThey still will, but it was 43-year-old Justin Rose who fought through brutal conditions to shoot a 3-under-par 68 to tie Brown and get within two of the leader, Lowry at 7 under par. Playing in the tougher tee time window in both rounds, Rose went 29 holes before his first bogey and has just one bogey through 36 holes.\n\nLowry, the 2019 Open Champion, shot 69 to jump Brown for the solo second-round lead Friday. He did it despite a dramatic double-bogey on the 11th hole that included disagreements with R&A officials and a 20-minute delay.\n\nLowry, coming off a first-round 66 in which he led the field in putting, led the tournament in ball striking Friday with five birdies. The Irishman attacked pins all day and took the lead despite missing three putts inside 10 feet.\n\nJust behind him are Rose and 29-year-old English journeyman Brown, who shot a 1-over-par 72 to stay in a strong position after a first-round leading 65 on Thursday. Brown, ranked No. 272 in the world, entered the Scottish Open last week coming off six straight missed cuts. He finished 61st last week, but now he's in the final group at The Open.\n\nLowry entered that 11th hole 7 under with a two-shot lead, but when hitting his second shot from a good lie in the rough, he shanked it into the thick gorse bushes and hit a provisional.\n\n\"I hit a great provisional. The referee asked me going down, 'Did I want to find my first one?'\" Lowry recalled. \"And I said no. So I assumed that was okay. Then we get down there, and somebody had found it. So apparently we have to find it then, or you have to go and identify it, which I thought, if you declared it lost before it was found, that you didn't, you didn't have to go and identify it.\"\n\nAfter 20 minutes of deliberation, Lowry finally took his unplayable lie penalty and hit his shot. He double bogeyed the hole.\n\nR&A rules official Charlie Maran explained: \"You can declare a ball lost, but when it's actually found, it is the ball in play. The provisional ball that he did play now becomes a wrong ball. So, he has to take his options with his original ball.\"\n\nLowry then finished with birdies on 16 and 18 to regain the solo lead into the weekend.\n\nBilly Horschel had only one career major top-10 finish entering 2024. He then finished T8 at the PGA Championship in May, and Friday he shot a bogey-free 68 to put himself in the mix. He's tied for fourth with LIV golfer Dean Burmester and world No. 1 Scottie Scheffler, who has shot consecutive 70s to stay afloat.\n\nTiger Woods finished 14 over but still committed to playing in The Open next year, in addition to the other majors. He said he will not play again until his Hero World Challenge event in the Bahamas in November.\n\nMany other top stars missed the cut at Royal Troon, which closed at 6 over par. That included Bryson DeChambeau, Rory McIlroy, Sahith Theegala, Wyndham Clark, Viktor Hovland, Tony Finau, Ludvig Aberg and Tommy Fleetwood.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8232492867", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:53:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:53:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:52:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/british-open-golf-brown-woods-thomas-scotland/article_f2d851f2-8b5d-551d-b3c3-3d6be1b99efa.html", "title": "Late birdies give Brown 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "Alexander Bjork of Sweden plays out of a bunker on the fifth hole during Thursday's opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Troon, Scotland.\n\nDOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nPeople are also reading... McDowell leaders seek land for new animal shelter McDowell County to host country, bluegrass festivals in August Picasso Keaton, a former WSSU football player, dies in a car crash McDowell High athlete appointed to NC Student-Athlete Advisory Council Roaming Buffalo Outpost moving from Rutherford Road to Marion's North Main Street McDowell County man charged with three counts of extortion Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report McDowell County Schools moving principals at West Middle, Eastfield and Foothills school McDowell ministry launches program to improve health of those in need Nebo man charged with meth possession Asheville hospital performs new heart procedure NC high school student on robotics trip drowns at Ocean Isle Beach Marion councilman is delegate to Republican convention in Milwaukee McDowell softball player Sage Young commits to Lenoir-Rhyne What is DEI? Former Lenoir-Rhyne administrator talks about diversity, inclusion at university\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to {"uri": "8232636647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "00:51:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T00:51:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T00:51:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/golf/daniel-brown-takes-shock-british-open-lead-as-rory-mcilroy-tiger-woods-suffer-nightmare-starts", "title": "Daniel Brown takes shock British Open lead as Rory McIlroy, Tiger Woods suffer nightmare starts", "body": "TROON, Scotland - Unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown shot into a shock lead of the British Open at six under par as Rory McIlroy was among the big names to struggle on day one of the 152nd British Open at Royal Troon.\n\nBrown, the world No. 272, birdied two of the last three holes to lead by one from 2019 winner Shane Lowry.\n\n\"I'm going to try and sort of keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" said Brown, who is competing in his first Major.\n\nMcIlroy posted a seven over par round of 78 with his hopes of ending a 10-year wait to win a Major floundering as most of the field struggled in the wet and windy conditions on Scotland's west coast.\n\nOf the 156 players in the field to complete their rounds, only 17 posted a score under par.\n\nLowry, who won his sole major at the British Open five years ago, made the most of the calm late afternoon conditions with three birdies in five holes around the turn and picked up another at the 18th.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again,\" said Lowry.\n\n\"It's great, but there's three rounds left. If I don't play well the next three rounds, it doesn't matter what I shot today. I'm fully aware that I have a job to do over the next three days.\"\n\nTwo-time major winner Justin Thomas is lurking at three under, while recently crowned USPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele is among a group of seven on two under that also includes Justin Rose.\n\nWorld No. 1 Scottie Scheffler cut a frustrated figure on the greens but is still in the mix after a one under round that featured four birdies and three bogeys.\n\nMcIlroy was aiming to get over his heartbreak at the US Open last month, where he missed two short putts to blow the lead as Bryson DeChambeau claimed his second major by one shot.\n\nHowever, the Northern Irishman's round, and probably championship, was blown off course at the postage stamp 120-yard eighth.\n\nMcIlroy was unfortunate as his near-perfect tee shot slipped off the green into a bunker, which he took two attempts to escape, to post a double bogey five.\n\nAnother double bogey followed at the 11th. He also dropped shots at the 10th, 15th and 18th.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" said McIlroy.\n\n\"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance.\"\n\nDeChambeau had been the form player in the majors so far this year, despite his defection to the breakaway LIV Tour.\n\nThe American finished sixth at the Masters and runner-up in the USPGA Championship before claiming his second US Open.\n\nHowever, his struggles with the windy conditions of links golf continued as he was six over par for his opening nine holes.\n\nDeChambeau battled back on the back nine as an eagle on the 17th helped him to a 76.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today,\" said DeChambeau.\n\n\"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home'. But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. I'm excited for the challenge.\"\n\nThomas recovered from his own double bogey at the 12th to post a 68, which was 14 shots better than his opening round at Royal Liverpool 12 months ago.\n\nWorld No. 3 Schauffele continued his fine form in recent months as he dropped just one shot to put himself among the chasing pack.\n\nTiger Woods had hit back at suggestions from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire, but the 15-time major champion failed to prove he can still be competitive with a 79.\n\n\"I didn't do a whole lot of things right today,\" said Woods. \"I had three three-putts today. I didn't hit my irons very close, and I didn't give myself a whole lot of looks today.\"\n\nCameron Smith, champion at St. Andrews two years ago, fared even worse with an 80.\n\nWorld No. 4 Ludvig Aberg was another of the big names to falter in his first ever round at a British Open with a four-over round of 75. {"uri": "8232839588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "04:45:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T04:45:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T04:45:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/sports/daniel-brown-makes-late-birdies-for-a-1-shot-lead-over-shane-lowry-in-wind/article_100687b6-456b-11ef-91fc-37c39e11e475.html", "title": "Daniel Brown makes late birdies for a 1-shot lead over Shane Lowry in wind-challenged British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keep it together on the way back, it was tough from start to finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 79 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said.\n\n\"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 69 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under.", "source": {"uri": "virginislandsdailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Virgin {"uri": "2024-07-427394057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:40:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:40:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:39:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/golf/news/12176/13181067/the-open-shane-lowry-takes-nightmare-hole-on-the-chin-after-grabbing-halfway-lead-at-royal-troon", "title": "The Open: Shane Lowry takes nightmare hole 'on the chin' after grabbing halfway lead at Royal Troon", "body": "Shane Lowry spoke to Sky Sports following his second round at The Open as he posted a two-under-par 69 to lead by two at Royal Troon\n\nShane Lowry was proud of his major resilience after battling back from a nightmare hole to move back top of the leaderboard at the halfway stage of The 152nd Open.\n\nLowry followed the lowest opening round of his major career, a five-under 66, with an impressive two-under 69 on Friday morning at Royal Troon to move to seven under and bolster his hopes of winning The Open for the second time in five years.\n\nThe Irishman reached the turn two ahead after a front-nine 34 before losing his outright advantage with a double-bogey at the par-four 11th, only to recover with two birdies in his last four holes to hold the halfway lead at The Open for the first time since his 2019 win.\n\n\"Sometimes you are in a frame of mind where you get on with it better than other times,\" Lowry said. \"This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. I just have to deal with it and try and make the best of it and see where it leads me.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy with how things have gone. The job tomorrow is to try to put myself in a position to win this tournament on Sunday, and that's what I'll try and do.\"\n\nExplained: Lowry's double-bogey chaos at the 11th\n\nLowry held a two-shot advantage when he sent his tee shot at the 11th into the rough, but he felt he had \"done the hard part\" on the hole named \"The Railway\" due to its proximity to the train line.\n\nHe was distracted by a cameraman and pulled it way left into a bush, then hit his fourth shot to around 10 feet before his original ball was found by a spectator and made the provisional void.\n\nThere was a lengthy delay to decide where Lowry would take his drop, where he then finished short of the green with his approach and needed to get up and down to limit the damage.\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry said. \"The referee asked me going down [the fairway] did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was okay. Then we get down there and somebody had found it, so apparently you have to go and identify it.\n\n\"I thought if you declared it lost before it was found, that you didn't. [But] through that whole process of 20 minutes of seeing where I could drop, I felt like I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing.\n\n\"And I felt like Darren [Reynolds, his caddie] did a great job too, he kept telling me that we have loads of time, we don't need to rush this. We just need to do the right thing here.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament. I have felt quite calm and composed the last couple of days. I've felt really in my comfort zone.\"\n\nLowry holds a two-shot lead over Brown, who stayed in contention with a one-over 72, while Justin Rose and world No 1 Scottie Scheffler are among the chasing pack heading into the final two rounds.\n\n\"I'm not sure Scottie Scheffler is too worried about anyone with the form he's in,\" Lowry joked. \"He's obviously on the leaderboard, and he's one person that people are going to be talking about. There's some other guys there as well.\n\n\"I see Justin Rose going well, and this guy Daniel Brown, I've never played with him, but obviously he had a great day yesterday and looks to be going all right today. I think if I give myself a chance on Sunday, I know I can do it. That's as good a position to be in as any.\"", "source": {"uri": "skysports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SkySports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": takes British Open lead as torrid Tiger misses cut", "body": "World number one Scottie Scheffler closed to within four shots of the lead at the British Open\n\nShane Lowry moved into the lead of the 152nd British Open at seven under par after his second round at Royal Troon on Friday as a tame Tiger Woods limped to 14 over to miss the cut.\n\nWoods is not the only big name to struggle in the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast as Rory McIlroy will begin his second round at seven over and likely needing an under par round to make the weekend.\n\nLowry had been usurped at the top of the leaderboard late on Thursday by unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown, who posted a six under 65.\n\nHowever, the Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\nHe leads by two shots from Brown, who showed little sign of nerves under the spotlight in his first major, with a steady first 14 holes to sit at five under.\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world number 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share of fourth at two under despite dropping a shot at 18.\n\nScheffler has already won six times this year, including his second Masters title in April.\n\nThe American was not blown off track as the winds strengthened through Friday afternoon with 11 pars in his opening 13 holes before a monster putt at the 14th and a birdie on the par-five 16th took him within striking range.\n\nHowever, a costly bogey on the last left him still four adrift of Lowry.\n\nMore from this section 'He will not be bullied.' came to a sorry end after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\nBut the three-time British Open champion cut a sorry figure as he trudged around the Troon links with his two-round score a tie for 149th out of the 154 players still active in the tournament.\n\nHis score of 156 over two rounds matches his worst ever at a major with the 2015 US Open and is his poorest at a British Open by three shots.\n\nStrong winds ensured low scoring remained difficult with the sixth, which had been the longest hole in British Open history on Thursday at 623 yards, reduced by 20 yards due to the conditions.\n\nAttention later turns to McIlroy's attempt to recover from a disastrous opening round of 78 with the projected cut sitting at four over.\n\nThe Northern Irishman's chances of ending a decade-long drought to win a major already appear gone.\n\nBut the world number two has only failed to make the cut once in his last 14 majors.\n\nUS Open champion Bryson DeChambeau also has work to do to hang around for the weekend as he begins his second round at five over.\n\nkca/jc", "source": {"uri": The gap could've been even wider had he not made a double-bogey 6 on the difficult 11th hole at Royal Troon on Friday.\n\nLowry, after hitting his tee shot into the native area, fired his approach shot into the gorse left of the green. Immediately following the wayward approach, the 2019 Open champion was heard expressing some of his frustrations towards a camera operator.\n\nTake a listen:\n\n\"As I was over the ball I could just see you putting your f -- kin' camera up. Just get outta the way. Just get back there. incident with the photographer on the 11th hole has continued to be the main storyline surrounding the longtime PGA Tour golfer on Friday.\n\n\"I was a Shane Lowry guy until the last 25 minutes, no {"uri": "8234112011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:30:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:30:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:28:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.westmeathindependent.ie/2024/07/19/open-leader-shane-lowry-ready-to-deal-with-whatever-royal-troon-throws-at-him/", "title": "Open leader Shane Lowry ready to deal with whatever Royal Troon throws at him | Westmeath Independent", "body": "Open leader Shane Lowry ready to deal with whatever Royal Troon throws at him RSS Syndicated Content Published: Fri 19 Jul 2024, 8:54 PM Last updated: Fri 19 Jul 2024, 9:24 PM\n\nBy Phil Casey, PA Golf Correspondent\n\nShane Lowry believes he is ready to take whatever is thrown at him \"on the chin\" after keeping his bid for a second Open title firmly on track at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry added a second round of 69 to his opening 66 for a halfway total of seven under par and two-shot lead over English duo Justin Rose and Dan Brown, who both came through 36-hole final qualifiers earlier this month.\n\nWith a strong wind sending scores soaring for the later starters, Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy, Bryson DeChambeau, Ludvig Aberg and Tommy Fleetwood all missed the cut, but home favourite Robert MacIntyre and Justin Thomas fought back from horror starts to make the weekend.\n\nLowry also recovered from a double bogey on the 11th with birdies on the 16th and 18th as he bids to lift the Claret Jug for a second time following his triumph at Royal Portrush in 2019.\n\nSurprise overnight leader Brown, who had completed a flawless 65 at 9:33pm on Thursday, battled to a second round of 72, while Rose returned a superb 68 and has dropped just one shot in 36 holes.\n\nLowry felt he had \"done the hard part\" on the 11th by getting his tee shot in play, but was distracted by a cameraman on his second shot and pulled it into the gorse.\n\nAfter taking a penalty drop, Lowry hit his fourth shot to around 10 feet to give himself a chance to salvage a bogey, only for his original ball to be found by a spectator.\n\nThat meant it was still in play and, after a long delay while it was determined where he could best take a drop, Lowry hit his approach just short of the green and eventually completed a double-bogey six.\n\nFormer Ryder Cup player David Howell, the on-course commentator with Lowry's group for Sky Sports, said the spectator who found the ball was \"being a little sheepish\" when he realised Lowry's intentions, adding: \"He's feeling awful.\"\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry explained. \"The referee asked me going down (the fairway) did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was OK.\n\n\"Then we get down there and somebody had found it, so apparently you have to go and identify it. I felt through that whole process of that 20 minutes of seeing where I could drop I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing.\n\n\"And Darren (Reynolds, his caddie) did a great job too. He kept telling me we have loads of time, we don't need to rush this.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster. I have felt quite calm and composed the last couple of days. I've felt really in my comfort zone.\n\n\"Sometimes you are in a frame of mind where you get on with it better than other times. This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. If I give myself a chance on Sunday I know I can do it and that's as good as a position to be in as any.\"\n\nBrown might have been expected to come back down to earth with a bump after his Thursday heroics, but the 29-year-old from Northallerton delivered an impressive sequel on his major debut.\n\n\"I've always been quite laid back really,\" Brown said. \"I think I am a bit of a realist as well.\n\n\"I know I'm not going to start getting ahead of myself and thinking, 'Oh my God, I'm leading the Open' or 'I'm second in the Open' or whatever.\n\n\"There's still 36 holes left. I might have a good round tomorrow and then I might have a stinky round on Sunday. You just don't know.\"\n\nRose's round drew high praise from six-time major winner Sir Nick Faldo, the last English winner of the Open in 1992, during a commentary stint on Sky Sports.\n\n\"Maybe the best 68 of his whole career on a day like today in this wind,\" Faldo said.\n\nSpeaking about his chance to make history, Rose said: \"When I won the US Open (in 2013) it was like 'First since Tony Jacklin' and they are nice moments when they come together, but you are never thinking of it.\n\n\"In the moment you are just trying to get the job done.\"\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler, Billy Horschel and Dean Burmester were five shots off the lead on two under par, with Jason Day, Xander Schauffele, Patrick Cantlay and Corey Conners all one under.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Fri
