I hit my drive where you could find it, which is obviously a hard thing to do on that hole,\" Lowry said of the 11, which runs parallel to railroad tracks. \"I had a nice lie in the rough. I got a little bit distracted on the right [by a cameraman] just as I was over the shot, and I kind of lost a bit of train of thought. You're so afraid of going right there that I just snagged the club and went left.\"\n\n'Just get back there!' Open leader Shane Lowry gets off rails at 11 with lengthy, crazy double\n\nLowry was leading The Open by two shots until he ran into trouble at the 11th hole.\n\nLowry's shot wasn't just left; it landed in the gorse. Fearing it lost, he hit a provisional ball onto the green. When asked if he wanted to search for the wayward shot or take the penalty and play the provisional, he told the official not to look for the ball.\n\n\"Then we get down there, and somebody had found it. So, apparently you have to go and identify it, which I thought, if you declared it lost before it was found, that you didn't, you didn't have to go and identify it,\" said Lowry, who was forced to play his original ball and eventually took a penalty drop after a complicated ruling that took nearly 20 minutes.\n\nLowry made a double bogey on No. 11 to fall into a share of the lead with Daniel Brown, but it was how he responded to that miscue that gave him confidence the rest of the round.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6. It wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament,\" he said. \"I think the 12th hole, for me, was key. [No.] 12 was playing very difficult, straight into the wind. I hit driver, 4-iron there, too, the best shots I've hit all week, to about 30 feet and made par there. From then on, I felt like [the wind being] down out of the left coming in, it was playing quite difficult, but I felt like you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.\"\n\nLowry played his last seven holes in 2 under, including a birdie at No. 18, for a 69 and two-stroke lead at 7 under over Brown (72) and Justin Rose (68).", "source": {"uri": the field are under par as the blustery conditions on Scotland's west coast wreaked havoc with five of the world's top 10 failing to make the weekend.\n\nLowry leads by two from Justin Rose, who came through qualifying to book his place in Troon, and unheralded Englishman Daniel Brown on his major debut.\n\nThe Irishman, who won his sole major at the British Open in 2019, recovered from a dramatic double bogey on the 11th that threatened to derail his charge to post a two under par round of 69.\n\n\"To be leading this tournament after two days, it's why you come here,\" said Lowry.\n\n\"The job tomorrow as well is to try to put myself in a position to win this tournament on Sunday.\"\n\nLowry was on the charge as he hit the turn in 34 thanks to birdies on the first, fifth and eighth.\n\nThe world number 33, though, was rocked as after a wayward tee shot at the 11th, he veered way left into thick bushes.\n\nRemarkably Lowry's ball was found, but deemed unplayable forcing him to play a drop and lose two shots.\n\nHe bounced back impressively picking up two shots in the final three holes.\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler has Lowry in his sights as the American moved into a share at the fourth in a run of six dropped shots in four holes.\n\nWoods was one of the few players to finish below McIlroy on 14 over after two rounds that will do little to quell doubts over whether he should continue to put a battered body through the strain of looking to add to his 15 major titles.\n\nThe 48-year-old hit back at suggestions earlier in the week from former European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie that he should retire to preserve his status as one of the sport's all-time legends.\n\nWoods has stressed he feels physically better of late as he continues to fight back from the severe leg injuries he suffered in a car crash in 2021.\n\n\"I just need to keep progressing like that and then eventually start playing more competitively and start getting into kind of the competitive flow again,\" he said.\n\nThe three-time British Open champion's score of 156 over two rounds matches his worst ever at a major with the 2015 US Open and was his poorest at this event by three shots.\n\nUS Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, Ludvig Aberg, Wyndham Clark and Viktor Hovland were the other top-10 players to miss the cut.\n\nThey were joined by 2022 champion Cam Smith, Tommy Bryson DeChambeau, Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods all struggling to make the cut at Royal Troon; Watch the second round live on Friday from 6.30am on Sky Sports Golf\n\nMajor debutant Daniel Brown topped the leaderboard after an eventful opening round at The 152nd Open, as Shane Lowry made a fast start and Rory McIlroy's hopes suffered a setback at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry - who lifted the Claret Jug in 2019 - carded the lowest round of his major career after a five-under 66, with the fast start also his first bogey-free round at The Open since day three of his major success at Royal Portrush.\n\nThe Irishman looked destined for the first-round lead until Brown - playing in the penultimate group - birdied two of his last four holes to close a stunning six-under 65 and snatch top spot, on a day where many of the field struggled in windy conditions on the Scottish coast.\n\nUS Open champion Bryson DeChambeau stuttered to a five-over 76 and McIlroy's hopes of ending his major drought appear all-but over after an opening-round 78, while Tiger Woods is in danger of a third consecutive missed cut following an eight-over 79.\n\nLowry scrambled pars on each of his first three holes by following a 10-foot birdie at the par-five fourth by making back-to-back gain from the seventh, with an up and down from off the ninth green seeing him save par and reach the turn in 33.\n\nThe world No 33 holed from 25 feet to salvage an unlikely par at the tenth and converted from a few feet closer to take advantage of the par-four next, lifting him into the solo lead, with Lowry capping off a brilliant day by firing his approach at the last to inside six feet to set up a closing birdie.\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" Lowry told Sky Sports. \"I got off to a bit of an iffy start and holed a couple of nice par putts early on and then I was off and running.\n\n\"I try not to think about it [2019] too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'. No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nLowry's closest challenge came from Brown, playing in the penultimate group, who charged up the leaderboard after carding a front-nine 34 and then adding successive birdies from the tenth to get within one of the lead.\n\nBrown got up and down from a tough lie at the par-five 16th to make a birdie to move alongside Lowry, before grabbing the solo advantage after rolling in from eight feet to pick up a shot at the last - in near-darkness - and move to six under.\n\nTwo-time PGA champion Justin Thomas set the initial target after a birdie-birdie finish gave him a three-under 68, leaving him three strokes back in third, while Alex Noren, Justin Rose and reigning PGA champion Xander Schauffele are among the group in tied-fourth on two under.\n\nWorld No 1 Scottie Scheffler began his bid for a seventh victory in 11 starts with a one-under 70, leaving him in the group tied-11th also containing five-time major champion Brooks Koepka, Matt Fitzpatrick and Matt Wallace, with just 17 of the 158 players ending the day under par.\n\nDeChambeau needed a 55-foot eagle at the par-five 16th to stay within 11 shots of the lead, while McIlroy admitted his focus was simply making the cut rather than challenging for the Claret Jug after carding one of the highest opening rounds of his major career.\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, having double-bogeyed the Postage Stamp as part of five dropped shots in four holes, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nWoods made a great start when he holed a long-range putt for a birdie at the third, only to add just one more in a round containing six bogeys and two double bogeys. Lowry shared the 36-hole lead when he won at Portrush in 2019.\n\n\"Look, I'm going to have a very late tee time tomorrow. I'm not going to be playing for another 24 hours. I know what that's about,\" Lowry said. \"I know tomorrow is going to be a long day, but I've done it before.\n\n\"For me, it's just about going out and playing my own game, shooting the best score I can. Try not to worry about what other people are doing and just trying to take care of your own personal stuff.\"\n\nIt was best to keep blinders on at Royal Troon. There were some harrowing scenes.\n\nJustin Thomas, who opened with a 68 to get himself in the mix, shot a 45 on the front nine and played his best golf from there to salvage a 78 and make sure he at least made the cut.\n\nRobert MacIntyre had an even tougher start. Scotland's biggest star after winning his national Open last week, MacIntyre was stuck in pot bunkers and high grass. He was 8 over for his round through four holes -- four holes! -- and then put together a big fight on the back nine in a bid to make the weekend.\n\nAguri Iwasaki had them all beat. He took a 9 on consecutive holes and shot 52 on the back nine for a 91. One of those 9s was on the par-3 14th, where he took four shots out of two bunkers and once had to go backward toward the fairway.\n\nTiger Woods missed another cut in a major -- that was one of the few surprises because he opened with a 79 -- but left his mark by tying his own mark with his highest 36-hole score as a pro with 156. The only time he had a higher 36-hole score was at Bay Hill in 1994 when he was a senior in high school.\n\nWoods had company in leaving early. Rory McIlroy, who started with a 78, needed a good start and got a triple bogey on the par-5 fourth hole. He barely moved it from high grass, chipped from more rough into a bunker and missed a 4-foot putt.\n\nMasters champion Scottie Scheffler missed all that calamity. He put together another steady round of 70 -- three birdies, two bogeys and the rest pars -- and joined the group at 2-under 140. He was five shots behind Lowry as he chases his second major of the year.\n\nJoaquin Niemann of Chile managed another 71 despite taking a quintuple-bogey 8 on the par-3 eighth hole -- the Postage Stamp -- that measures a mere 123 yards. He was in three bunkers around the tiny green and three-putted when he finally got out of them. Niemann also made six birdies in a most remarkable round of level par.\n\nSo much chaos across the century-old links, and it looked for a brief moment like Lowry might take part. It took so long to play the 11th hole that Jordan Spieth in the group behind him walked over to the side of the fairway and sat down near a gorse bush to wait.\n\nLowry at least kept it in play, though it was in the rough to the right. He was distracted by a photographer and angry at himself for not backing off the shot that he tugged left toward a clump of gorse.\n\nFiguring it would be lost in the prickly mess, Lowry hit a provisional for a lost ball onto the green, a terrific shot. One problem. Someone found the ball. It was no longer lost, so the provisional ball was not in play.\n\nLowry took a penalty drop from the bush, going back to find a place where he had a swing, put it short of the green, chipped on and salvaged a double bogey 6.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6. It wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament,\" Lowry said.\n\nHe made five birdies on the day, and yet nothing felt better than a par. That came on the 12th, one of the toughest holes into the wind. He hit driver and 4-iron to 30 feet, two putts for a most beautiful, calming par.\n\n\"The best shots I've hit all week,\" Lowry said. \"From then on, it was playing quite difficult, but I felt like you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.\"\n\nAnd now comes a big opportunity for Lowry to reclaim that claret jug, for Rose to become the first player in the modern era of exemptions to come through 36-hole qualifying, and for Brown to become one of the biggest surprises since Ben Curtis in 2003 at Royal St. George's.\n\nAnd so many others are very much in the mix, starting with Scheffler, golf's best player.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8232542641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "22:50:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T22:50:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T22:47:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/british-open-golf-brown-woods-thomas-scotland/article_7e9c74a3-dbc6-54ca-ae88-dbf01e6b298e.html", "title": "Late birdies give Brown 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "Alexander Bjork of Sweden plays out of a bunker on the fifth hole during Thursday's opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Troon, Scotland.\n\nDOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- The wind caught just about everyone off guard Thursday in the British Open. It came from the opposite direction off the Irish Sea, accompanied by occasional rain, and made Royal Troon a tougher test than anyone was expecting.\n\nTurns out that wasn't even the biggest surprise.\n\nDaniel Brown made his major championship debut a memorable one. He birdied two of the last three holes for a 6-under 65, giving him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry with just enough spectators left in the Scottish twilight to celebrate his amazing day.\n\nIt was getting too dark to take a photo of his name atop the leaderboard, and that doesn't interest the 29-year-old from England, anyway.\n\n\"I'm going to try and keep my feet on the ground a bit and take on the job again tomorrow,\" Brown said.\n\nPeople are also reading... Sioux City school district settles student injury lawsuit for $175,000 High school softball: Sioux City West snaps 12-year postseason drought with win UPDATED: Okoboji lakes fall below target for lifting boat speeding limits Dan Greenwell to pay $52.7K in attorney fees to former Sioux City superintendent Paul Gausman Hinton man wins $100K in Iowa Lottery scratch game City of Okoboji urges governor to increase releases from Iowa Great Lakes Sioux City Career Academy house sells for $150,000 to couple impacted by flooding 2 arrested after I-29 pursuit in Woodbury County State seeks to use Dakota Dunes homicide suspect's confession at trial Sioux City woman claims $300,000 lottery prize Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 14, 2024 High school baseball: McCarty leading successful, youthful MOC-FV squad into playoffs Iowa restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi Woodbury County Court Report for July 15, 2024\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only a good start and three more rounds were ahead of him. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nMcIlroy broke 80, but not by much.\n\nHe was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now McIlroy only wants to make it to the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that {"uri": "8234027386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:03:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:03:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T19:02:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/shane-lowry-keeps-calm-and-carries-british-open-lead-at-troon/67VU5J7MGRBN5A4EYJDWGGKJOY/", "title": "Shane Lowry keeps calm and carries British Open lead at Troon", "body": "And now he gets to wait even longer before he plays again, a product of being in the lead and among the late starters on the weekend with the silver claret jug he won five years ago at Royal Portrush coming more into view.\n\nHe was at 7-under 135, two shots ahead of surprise 18-hole leader Daniel Brown of England (72) and Justin Rose (68). Lowry shared the 36-hole lead when he won at Portrush in 2019.\n\n\"Look, I'm going to have a very late tee time tomorrow. I'm not going to be playing for another 24 hours. I know what that's about,\" Lowry said. \"I know tomorrow is going to be a long day, but I've done it before.\n\n\"For me, it's just about going out and playing my own game, shooting the best score I can. Try not to worry about what other people are doing and just trying to take care of your own personal stuff.\"\n\nIt was best to keep blinders on at Royal Troon. There were some harrowing scenes.\n\nJustin Thomas, who opened with a 68 to get himself in the mix, shot a 45 on the front nine and played his best golf from there to salvage a 78 and make sure he at least made the cut.\n\nRobert MacIntyre had an even tougher start. Scotland's biggest star after winning his national Open last week, MacIntyre was stuck in pot bunkers and high grass. He was 8 over for his round through four holes -- four holes! -- and then put together a big fight on the back nine in a bid to make the weekend.\n\nAguri Iwasaki had them all beat. He took a 9 on consecutive holes and shot 52 on the back nine for a 91. One of those 9s was on the par-3 14th, where he took four shots out of two bunkers and once had to go backward toward the fairway.\n\nTiger Woods missed another cut in a major -- that was one of the few surprises because he opened with a 79 -- but left his mark by tying his own mark with his highest 36-hole score as a pro with 156. The only time he had a higher 36-hole score was at Bay Hill in 1994 when he was a senior in high school.\n\nWoods had company in leaving early. Rory McIlroy, who started with a 78, needed a good start and got a triple bogey on the par-5 fourth hole. He barely moved it from high grass, chipped from more rough into a bunker and missed a 4-foot putt.\n\nMasters champion Scottie Scheffler missed all that calamity. He put together another steady round of 70 -- three birdies, two bogeys and the rest pars -- and joined the group at 2-under 140. He was five shots behind Lowry as he chases his second major of the year.\n\nJoaquin Niemann of Chile managed another 71 despite taking a quintuple-bogey 8 on the par-3 eighth hole -- the Postage Stamp -- that measures a mere 123 yards. He was in three bunkers around the tiny green and three-putted when he finally got out of them. Niemann also made six birdies in a most remarkable round of level par.\n\nSo much chaos across the century-old links, and it looked for a brief moment like Lowry might take part. It took so long to play the 11th hole that Jordan Spieth in the group behind him walked over to the side of the fairway and sat down near a gorse bush to wait.\n\nLowry at least kept it in play, though it was in the rough to the right. He was distracted by a photographer and angry at himself for not backing off the shot that he tugged left toward a clump of gorse.\n\nFiguring it would be lost in the prickly mess, Lowry hit a provisional for a lost ball onto the green, a terrific shot. One problem. Someone found the ball. It was no longer lost, so the provisional ball was not in play.\n\nLowry took a penalty drop from the bush, going back to find a place where he had a swing, put it short of the green, chipped on and salvaged a double bogey 6.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6. It wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament,\" Lowry said.\n\nHe made five birdies on the day, and yet nothing felt better than a par. That came on the 12th, one of the toughest holes into the wind. He hit driver and 4-iron to 30 feet, two putts for a most beautiful, calming par.\n\n\"The best shots I've hit all week,\" Lowry said. \"From then on, it was playing quite difficult, but I felt like you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.\"\n\nAnd now comes a big opportunity for Lowry to reclaim that claret jug, for Rose to become the first player in the modern era of exemptions to come through 36-hole qualifying, and for Brown to become one of the biggest surprises since Ben Curtis in 2003 at Royal St. George's.\n\nAnd so many others are very much in the mix, starting with Scheffler, golf's best player.\n\n\"I've played two solid rounds and it put me five shots back, and I'll continue to try to execute and just continue to try to hit good shots and hit good putts,\" Scheffler said, making it all sound so simple on a day when nothing felt easy.", "source": {"uri": "daytondailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dayton Daily News"}, "authors": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/clubhouse-leader-shane-lowry-ready-175517946.html", "title": "Clubhouse leader Shane Lowry ready for anything as wind causes chaos at Open", "body": "Clubhouse leader Shane Lowry ready for anything as wind causes chaos at Open\n\nPhil Casey, PA Golf Correspondent\n\n19 July 2024 at 7:55 pm\n\nShane Lowry believes he is ready to take whatever is thrown at him \"on the chin\" after keeping his bid for a second Open title firmly on track on a blustery day at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry added a second round of 69 to his opening 66 for a halfway total of seven under par which always looked insurmountable due to a strengthening wind causing havoc for the later starters.\n\nThe 2019 champion recovered from a double bogey on the 11th with birdies on the 16th and 18th to hold a two-shot lead over the English duo of Justin Rose and Dan Brown, who both had to come through 36-hole final qualifiers earlier this month.\n\nSurprise overnight leader Brown, who had completed a flawless 65 at 9.33pm on Thursday, battled to a second round of 72, while Rose returned a superb 68 and has amazingly dropped just one shot in 36 holes.\n\nLowry felt he had \"done the hard part\" on the 11th, named 'The Railway' due to the adjacent Glasgow to Ayr train line, by getting his tee shot in play, but was distracted by a cameraman on his second shot and pulled it into the gorse.\n\nAfter taking a penalty drop Lowry hit his fourth shot to around 10 feet to give himself a chance to salvage a bogey, only for his original ball to be found by a spectator.\n\nThat meant it was still in play and, after a long delay while it was determined where he could best take a drop, Lowry hit his approach just short of the green and eventually completed a double-bogey six.\n\nFormer Ryder Cup player David Howell, the on-course commentator with Lowry's group for Sky Sports, said the spectator who found the ball was \"being a little sheepish\" when he realised Lowry's intentions, adding: \"He's feeling awful.\"\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry explained. \"The referee asked me going down [the fairway] did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was OK.\n\n\"Then we get down there and somebody had found it, so apparently you have to go and identify it. I felt through that whole process of that 20 minutes of seeing where I could drop I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing.\n\n\"And Darren [Reynolds, his caddie] did a great job too. He kept telling me we have loads of time, we don't need to rush this.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. It wasn't a disaster. I have felt quite calm and composed the last couple of days. I've felt really in my comfort zone.\n\n\"Sometimes you are in a frame of mind where you get on with it better than other times. This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. If I give myself a chance on Sunday I know I can do it and that's as good as a position to be in as any.\"\n\nBrown might have been expected to come back down to earth with a bump after his Thursday heroics, but the 29-year-old from Northallerton delivered an impressive sequel on his major debut.\n\n\"I've always been quite laid back really,\" Brown said. \"I think I am a bit of a realist as well.\n\n\"I know I'm not going to start getting ahead of myself and thinking, 'Oh my God, I'm leading the Open' or 'I'm second in the Open' or whatever.\n\n\"There's still 36 holes left. I might have a good round tomorrow and then I might have a stinky round on Sunday. You just don't know.\"\n\nRose's round drew high praise from six-time major winner Sir Nick Faldo, the last English winner of the Open in 1992, during a commentary stint on Sky Sports.\n\n\"Maybe the best 68 of his whole career on a day like today in this wind,\" Faldo said.\n\n\"When I won the US Open it was likem 'First since Tony Jacklin' and they are nice moments when they come together, but you are never thinking of it,\" Rose said of his chance to make history.\n\n\"In the moment you are just trying to get the job done.\"\n\nWorld number one Scottie Scheffler, Billy Horschel and Dean {"uri": "8232476076", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:33:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:33:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:33:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.ayradvertiser.com/sport/24461841.highs-lows-day-one-open-royal-troon/", "title": "Lowry and Brown flawless as Rory McIlroy flounders in first round at Royal Troon", "body": "Lowry carded five birdies in a bogey-free 66 that was only surpassed at 9.33pm by England's Daniel Brown, the world number number 272 returning a brilliant 65 to claim a shock lead on his Open debut.\n\nBrown, who won his maiden DP World Tour title in Northern Ireland 11 months ago, took advantage of calmer conditions for the later starters to birdie the third, fifth, 10th, 11th, 16th and 18th.\n\n\"I'm very excited but you have to keep your feet on the ground,\" said the 29-year-old from Northallerton, who finished 61st in the Scottish Open on Sunday after a run of six missed cuts and a withdrawal in his last seven starts.\n\n\"I am just going to try and go out and do the best I can.\"\n\nThe contrast between Lowry's 66 and the 78 of McIlroy immediately brought to mind the 2019 Open at Royal Portrush, when Lowry started with a 67 on his way to the Claret Jug and McIlroy's chances were blown away with a 79.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy, but it's only one day,\" Lowry said. \"We've got three more days.\n\n\"I kept telling myself that out there because for some reason I felt like the crowd were getting very excited. It was late in the afternoon and a few pints of Tennent's were had out there. It felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\n\n\"The walk down 18 was actually pretty cool. I said to Billy Foster (Matt Fitzpatrick's caddie) that it's the greatest walk in golf and I got to do it on a Sunday afternoon with a full house. That's the plan, to try to get to do that again.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again. I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again and that's why I'm here this week.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nA downbeat McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 behind his great friend Lowry.\n\nAccording to statistician Justin Ray, lead data analyst at KPMG Performance Insights, 87 per cent of Open winners since 1960 have been within four shots of the lead after the first round.\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out the US Open title last month, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 included a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth, where he could only advance his second shot a few yards from heavy rough before hitting his next onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\nThomas had set the early clubhouse target on three under par thanks to birdies on the 17th and 18th, the two-time major winner's 68 representing a 14-shot improvement on his opening round at Hoylake last year.\n\n\"I couldn't even tell you what I was thinking or how it was then,\" Thomas said when asked to compare the two rounds.\n\n\"I'm just worried about how I am now, and I'm very pleased with my game and know things are continuing to work in the right direction.\"\n\nFormer supermarket delivery driver Joe Dean was part of a seven-way tie for fourth place on two under par which included US PGA winner Xander Schauffele and Ryder Cup team-mates Nicolai Hojgaard and Justin Rose.\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in a bogey-free 69.", "source": {"uri": "ayradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8233874105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:50:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:50:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:49:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5647498/2024/07/19/shane-lowry-open-championship-lead/", "title": "The duality of the Irishman leading this Open Championship", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- Every little bit of Shane Lowry is always right there in front of you, the good and the bad, the aggravating and the inspiring. He lets you know when he's crying in the Carnoustie car park in 2018 as \"golf wasn't my friend at the time,\" just like he runs along the gallery in Rome riling up European crowds and exchanging expletives with Joe LaCava at the Ryder Cup. He tells you when he feels like he can't make a putt for his life, and he tells you when you're in his way.\n\nShane Lowry is golf's great open vein. He's a big-bearded, 225-pound Irishman with a career of monumental highs and sickening lows whose vulnerability is his greatest calling card and the trait that might rub some the wrong way.\n\nSo there's Shane Lowry, shanking a ball deep into Royal Troon's wicked gorse bushes on the 11th hole and immediately unleashing on a cameraman.\n\n\"As I was over the ball, I could just see you with the f -- ing camera up!\" Lowry frustratedly told the cameraman. \"Just get back there! (Expletive) sake!\"\n\nAt that moment, the 152nd Open Championship could have gotten away from him. After somebody found the ball he certainly didn't want to find, after a lengthy disagreement with officials over whether he could use his provisional, after a delay that lasted closer to 30 minutes than 20 and held up the tournament, Lowry's two-shot lead evaporated with a double bogey. Suddenly, he was tied with Englishman Dan Brown going into the difficult back nine.\n\nBut there was that emotion again. Lowry walked off the 18th green with a fist in the air as his 20-foot putt fell. The 37-year-old closed with birdies on 16 and 18 to enter the weekend with a two-shot lead while fighting for his second Claret Jug.\n\nSo a reporter asked Lowry a simple question: \"Are you a good frontrunner?\"\n\nLowry paused for a few moments.\n\n\"I wouldn't say I'm a good runner,\" he countered to a room full of hearty laughs.\n\nThe contrasts between Lowry's high and low emotions match well with the rollercoaster elements of his career. He's gone from being dismissed as Rory McIlroy's lifelong sidekick to becoming a two-time Ryder Cupper deserving your respect. He collapsed at the 2016 U.S. Open, giving away a two-shot lead with a Sunday 76, but he also ran away with the 2019 Open Championship at Royal Portrush. During stretches of a great 2022 season, DataGolf ranked him No. 7 in the world. Ten months later, he dropped to No. 67, causing many to want him off the Ryder Cup team.\n\nWhen he teamed up with McIlroy again at the Zurich Classic in April, they were two golfers in need of a reset. McIlroy was tense and having a tough start to the year. Lowry was in a horrible putting slump ranking toward the bottom of the field each week. The duo won the PGA Tour's lone team event that week in New Orleans, and even then, amid the celebration, Lowry somberly implied that McIlroy carried him to victory.\n\nSince then, though, Lowry has reminded the world he is one of golf's great survivors. He tied the all-time major record with a Saturday 62 at the PGA Championship to finish T6. He went T19 at the U.S. Open and shot another 62 at the Travelers before finishing T9.\n\nLowry is lovable. He's funny and good with fans and would go to war for his mates. He also runs a little hot, the way we saw with the cameraman Friday or at the Ryder Cup in Rome. Nobody is just one thing, and viewers should enjoy the ride that is Shane Lowry at the Open Championship. If you do, you will see creativity and emotion and pure links golf at its best.\n\nYou will have fun.\n\n\"I can get a bit down on myself and a bit hot-headed at times,\" Lowry said, \"but I really feel like that's why I've had the career I've had. I've spoken to people, my coach and my team about this at times, and if I go out there and try to be somebody I'm not, you're just not going to be successful. That's how I feel.\"'\n\nWhat bodes well for Lowry is that he's in this two-shot lead playing two opposite rounds. Thursday, he shot 66 thanks to an epic day with his putter. He didn't aim at pins or make highlight-reel shots. He generally kept himself out of trouble, put himself in position and led the field in putting.\n\nSo on Friday, Lowry had better control of his swing and instead led the morning wave in strokes gained in approach. Aside from the mess he made of No. 11, Lowry hit sick iron shots while controlling the ball through Troon's difficult winds and left himself constant birdie chances. If anything, Lowry left many shots out there -- he lost strokes putting.\n\nHe went out in 34 before his second shot went into that gorse on the par-4 11th. Lowry said an official asked him if he wanted to find the ball and Lowry declared no, in his eyes meaning it was settled and he'd play his provisional. That provisional was up on the green, at a makeable distance for bogey.\n\n\"Then we get down there, and somebody had found it,\" Lowry recalled \"So apparently we have to find it then, or you have to go and identify it, which I thought, if you declared it lost before it was found, that you didn't, you didn't have to go and identify it.\n\nR&A rules official Charlie Maran said: \"You can declare a ball lost, but when it's actually found, it is the ball in play.The provisional ball that he did play now becomes a wrong ball. So, he has to take his options with his original ball.\"\n\nLowry actually took pride in the way he stayed calm throughout the endeavor. He walked over to the 12th fairway and settled down. When it was over, he said he was happy to get out of there with a 6 and continue his round. He played the final seven holes in 2-under par.\n\nThere is a long way to go at this Open Championship, and every player in the field will be well aware of world No. 1 Scottie Scheffler lurking at 2-under, but Lowry has a chance to change the way we discuss his career.\n\nIt would be extremely dismissive to call Lowry a one-hit wonder. He is not. A win this week certainly cements Lowry as one of the great competitors in European golf. It would mean two Claret Jugs on top of two Ryder Cups and 19 major finishes of T25 or better.\n\nYet Lowry is the one downplaying any such talk. Saturday is going to be a long day of waiting for the field trying to catch him. His goal is to ignore it.\n\n\"Try not to worry about what other people are doing and just trying to take care of your own personal stuff,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8232485882", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:45:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:45:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:44:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/british-open-golf-brown-woods-thomas-scotland/article_b2d4f5d9-f2bb-5cae-94d2-62130121f6cd.html", "title": "Late birdies give Brown 1-shot lead at British Open", "body": "Tiger Woods of the United States waits to putt on the 18th green during Thursday's opening round of the British Open at Royal Troon in Troon, Scotland.\n\nDOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nTROON, Scotland -- Daniel Brown had a major championship debut he won't soon forget. He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. One was the final qualifying to earn a spot in his first major, the other at the Scottish Open when he made the cut and finished 61st.\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa's new caf\u00e9 and bakery Ryan Seacrest's Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Fight between Le Petit Elephant and Alta Heights neighbors gets personal Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa City Council votes to sell Dwight Murray Plaza, other downtown land to developers Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Why is that? Here's the lowdown on some Napa head-scratchers Napa County, Hoopes winery file closing arguments in legal clash Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life One lane of southbound Highway 221 closing in south Napa for Soscol Junction work Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive\n\nBut this day was all about the wind -- yes, it was fierce, but it was different. Instead of players trying to make a score on the downwind front nine and keeping it together on the way back, it was tough from start-to-finish.\n\nRory McIlroy certainly found that to be the case. He shot 78 with a pair of double bogeys. Ditto for U.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau, who went out in 42 on his way to a 76. Every major is tough on 48-year-old Tiger Woods, who had a 78 for his highest start in a major since an 80 in the 2015 U.S. Open at Chambers Bay.\n\nLowry motored along, putting as well as he has all year, soaking up the warm applause all while reminding himself it was only one day. But he sure knew what to expect.\n\n\"Fortunately enough, I came here two weeks ago and I played this wind on the second day that I played here. I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it,\" Lowry said. \"Yeah, I guess that was a good thing to do, and it's out there paying off a little bit today.\"\n\nJustin Thomas is off to another great start for the second straight week in Scotland, even if his score doesn't look that way. He had a 68 -- he shot 62 last week in the Scottish Open -- and feels as though he played better because the misses are more severely punished at Troon.\n\nThe group at 68 included PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Justin Rose, who also played bogey-free with greater appreciation of this Open because he had to endure 36-hole final qualifying just to get in.\n\nThrow in the occasional rain, and Masters champion Scottie Scheffler found it plenty difficult after battling his way to a 70.\n\n\"I don't know if confusing is the right word, just challenging, especially when you get the rain involved,\" Scheffler said. \"When you get a wet ball into the wind, it's amazing how short it goes. I think it was No. 2 today, I had 165 to the pin off a slight upslope, and I hit a hold 5-iron, which for me usually goes about 205. It went probably 155 at the most. And I striped it.\"\n\nLowry, the Open champion at Royal Portrush five years ago, hit his stride around the turn. He birdied the seventh from about 10 feet and hit wedge to 10 feet at the par-3 eighth, the famed \"Postage Stamp\" that caused so much damage for a 123-yard hole.\n\nHe also made two big pars, including a 25-foot putt on the 10th, before holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 11th to reach 4 under. Lowry ended his round with a wedge to 5 feet for his 66.\n\nThe applause kept getting louder, and Lowry kept reminding himself it was only Thursday.\n\n\"For some reason I felt like he crowd were getting very excited out there,\" he said. \"It was late in the afternoon -- a few pints of Tennents were had out there ... and it felt more like the weekend. I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do and there's a few days left, so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\"\n\nThomas played earlier in the day and was at 4 under through 11. He just had to work hard to keep a good score on his card.\n\nHis tee shot landed in a bush on the tough 12th hole that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of 12 rounds of 80 or higher.\n\nThat included John Daly, who made 8 on the last hole. It also included Cameron Smith, the Open champion from two years ago at St. Andrews.\n\nThe back is longer and typically plays into a strong wind. It was the opposite direction for the early going and still caused its share of problems.\n\nIt was a nightmare for McIlroy, who was hopeful of one last chance this year to end his drought in the majors that dates 10 years. Now he's hopeful of sticking around for the weekend. He took two to get of a bunker on the Postage Stamp, and then sent his drive on the 11th over the railroad tracks and out-of-bounds. He couldn't solve the wind.\n\n\"You play your practice rounds, and you try to come up with a strategy that you think is going to get you around the golf course. Then when the wind is like that other options present themselves, and you start to second guess yourself a little bit,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to {"uri": "8234118027", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:36:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:36:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:35:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/open-championship-hot-headed-shane-195850677.html", "title": "Open Championship: 'Hot headed' Shane Lowry shrugs off cameraman clash to roar ahead but Rory McIlroy flames out", "body": "Rivals and cameramen, make way - Shane Lowry is coming through at the Open Championship.\n\nThe Irishman lifted the red mist that momentarily descended upon him at Royal Troon in Scotland to wrestle control of the major, as his second round two-under 69 on Friday sent him into the weekend with a two shot lead.\n\nAfter opening with a bogey-free 66 on Thursday, 2019 champion Lowry had been motoring along smoothly at the summit before his advantage was derailed by a disastrous 30-minute saga on the notorious par-four 11th \"Railway\" hole.\n\nHaving narrowly survived sending his tee shot onto the train tracks that run alongside the 488-yard hole, the world No. 33 went from frying pan to fire as his subsequent effort from the rough went careening left into the thick gorse across the other side of the fairway.\n\nA visibly disgruntled Lowry then gesticulated and pointed animatedly at a nearby cameraman, later admitting that he had - no pun intended - \"lost his train of thought\" after becoming \"a little distracted\" while stood over his shot.\n\n\"There was a cameraman there, and he was walking up. I asked him to stop or move back, and he just kind of stayed there,\" Lowry told reporters on his return to the clubhouse.\n\n\"As it was over, he put his camera up. I kind of saw it out of the corner of my eye, and I should stood off it, (it was) my own fault.\"\n\nThe drama continued when Lowry struck a \"great\" provisional shot - taken when a ball is presumed lost outside a penalty area or out of bounds - to within 12 feet of the hole, only for one eagle-eyed fan to subsequently find his original ball and void his provisional effort in the process.\n\nAfter a lengthy discussion with a rules official regarding where to take a drop from, the 37-year-old golfer eventually left with a double bogey - enough to erase his two-shot cushion, but \"not a disaster\", he later reflected.\n\nIf Lowry had lost his cool, he quickly found it in abundance. After rebounding with four steady pars, the Irishman signed off with his second birdie in three holes to restore the gap to English duo Justin Rose and Daniel Brown heading into the weekend.\n\nAs he seeks to turn back the clock to his dominant triumph at Royal Portrush in Northern Ireland five years ago, Lowry has no intention of throttling the passion that helped him clinch his sole major to date.\n\n\"I can get a bit down on myself and a bit hot headed at times, but I really feel like that's why I've had the career I've had,\" Lowry, who has nine combined wins on the PGA Tour and European Tour, said.\n\n\"If I go out there and try to be somebody I'm not, you're just not going to be successful ... [But] If I go out there and be myself, I feel like I can do very well. So allowing myself to do that, without getting in your own way.\"\n\nIt was an entirely contrasting day for Northern Irishman Rory McIlroy, as the world No. 2 capitulated to become the highest profile casualty of a host of big names that failed to make the cut.\n\nThe 35-year-old star had been out to exorcise the demons of his latest heartbreaking major near-miss at the US Open last month but found only more woe at Royal Troon, finishing 11-over par overall to fall well short of the top-70 players and ties that progressed to the weekend.\n\nNeeding a fast start after a grueling first round 78, McIlroy's hopes of making the cut were effectively extinguished by the end of the sixth hole after a nightmarish stretch. Having bogeyed the third, McIlroy triple bogeyed the following par-five hole before back-to-back bogeys.\n\nA solid back nine saw him go two-under par down the stretch but the damage was done, his closing 75 ensuring his wait for a fifth major will continue into an 11 year.\n\nOnce I made the eight on the 4th hole, that was it. 22 holes into the event and I'm thinking about where I'm going to go on vacation next week,\" McIlroy admitted to reporters.\n\n\"It was a pretty meaningless 14 holes after that, but at least I played okay and at least feel like, when the wind dropped, my game felt a little more comfortable and I hit some good shots.\"\n\nTiger Woods will also be absent from the weekend, resigning him to a third consecutive missed major cut for just the second time in his career.\n\nThe 48-year-old shot 79 and 77 to finish on 14-over par, the joint-highest 36-hole score he has ever recorded at a major, but insisted he still enjoyed the challenge.\n\n\"I've always loved playing major championships. I just wish I was more physically sharp coming into the majors,\" Woods, who added he will \"definitely\" compete at next year's Open at Royal Portrush in Northern Ireland, told reporters Friday.\n\n\"Obviously it tests you mentally, physically, emotionally, and I just wasn't as sharp as I needed to be. I was hoping that I would find it somehow, just never did. Consequently, my results and scores were pretty high.\"\n\nOther big names that failed to survive the cut included last month's US Open winner Bryson DeChambeau, and last year's US Open champion Wyndham Clark.\n\nWith McIlroy, world No. 4 Ludvig Aberg and world No. 7 Viktor Hovland also missing out, only half of the world's top-10 ranked players - Scottie Scheffler, Xander Schauffele, Collin Morikawa, Patrick Cantlay and Jon Rahm - will tee up Saturday.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-426479636", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:59:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:59:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:45:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://golfweek.usatoday.com/lists/british-open-2024-daniel-brown-leads-shane-lowry-royal-troon/", "title": "Daniel Brown, the golfer, not the 'DaVinci Code' author, cracks the code at Royal Troon and Shane Lowry's scouting trip pays off at 2024 British Open", "body": "TROON, Scotland - Mother Nature has a sense of humor and on Thursday she threw the field at the 152nd British Open for a loop at Royal Troon. No one seemed ready for the wind to blow from an entirely different direction.\n\n\"Hitting driver on 1 in the practice round wasn't really great prep for today,\" said Xander Schauffele, who needed 3-iron, 6-iron instead, \"but that's just kind of how links golf is, and that's the beauty of it.\"\n\nPlaying into an opposite wind was a puzzle that few players had the answers to unless your name happened to be Daniel Brown, not the Da Vinci Code author, but the golfer making his major championship debut, who shot 65 and leads by one over 2019 Open champ Shane Lowry. PGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele (69) and Masters champ Scottie Scheffler (70) are lurking as they attempt to win a second major this season while U.S. Open champ Bryson DeChambeau struggled (76).\n\n\"It's funny like the practice days, the course couldn't have played any easier. Then it's the start of the tournament, and it's just playing, I guess, how you in some ways expect an Open to play,\" said Tyrrell Hatton, who made 16 pars and two bogeys and complained about his game afterward.\n\nTroon's victims included 2022 Open champ Cameron Smith (80), three-time Open champ Tiger Woods (79), Rickie Fowler (79), 2023 U.S. Open champ Wyndham Clark (78) and 2014 Open champ Rory McIlroy (78).\n\nBRITISH OPEN: Leaderboard | Photos | How to watch\n\n\"It was brutal. It really was a good test of golf, and you needed to be on your A+ game to shoot under par, and I witnessed it,\" said Smith, who played in the same grouping with Lowry. \"He played good.\"\n\nHere are five things to know from the first round of the 2024 British Open.\n\nDaniel Brown the golfer, not the novelist, leads in major debut\n\nDaniel Brown watches his iron shot from the 17th tee on the opening day of the 152nd British Open Golf Championship at Royal Troon on the south west coast of Scotland on July 18, 2024. (Photo by ANDY BUCHANAN / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE (Photo by ANDY BUCHANAN/AFP via Getty Images)\n\nFor the second year in a row, a golfer making his major championship debut leads at the British Open. Last year, it was amateur Christo Lamprecht; this time, Daniel Brown, a 29-year-old English golfer who plays on the DP World Tour, grabbed the lead with an 8-foot birdie on 18 to shoot 6-under 65.\n\n\"Yeah, amazing, isn't it?\" said Brown, who had his brother, Ben, on the bag. \"I was nervous on the 1st tee, obviously it being my first major, but I hit a few nice shots early, so I kind of got settled into the round pretty quick.\"\n\nRanked No. 272 in the world, Brown won his maiden title last year ISPS Handa World Invitational. In all three of his PGA Tour starts in his career, he's opened with 65. But even Brown probably didn't see a round like this coming: His last eight DP World Tour starts included six missed cuts, a WD and a 61st-place finish.\n\nAt the par-3, fifth hole, with the wind howling, Brown was asked if he tried to cut his 3-iron to the flag, which ended 2 feet from the hole. \"No, I pulled it,\" he admitted, but it was a tap-in birdie.\n\nBrown took advantage of more benign conditions playing late in the day. At No. 11, he drained a 42-foot birdie. \"I felt good all day, really, with the putter,\" he said.\n\nFrom the deep rough at 16, he tacked on another birdie and then broke a tie with Lowry with his birdie at the last.\n\n\"He took advantage of the conditions coming home,\" Golf Channel's Notah Begay III said. \"After missing so many cuts and not playing great golf coming in, you know this game can come up at any moment and bite you. We've all been there. He knows he put up a great round, celebrate it for a very brief moment, but I promise he will show up ready to play tomorrow, knowing that he hasn't been on the greatest streak of golf coming in.\"\n\nShane Lowry locked in on the greens\n\nShane Lowry hits his tee shot on the 14th hole during the first round of the Open Championship golf tournament at Royal Troon. Mandatory Credit: Jack Gruber-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFive years removed from winning the Open at Royal Portrush in Northern Ireland, Irishman Shane Lowry rode a hot putter to a bogey-free 66, his lowest opening-round score in 46 career major appearances and one better than his start en route to victory in 2019.\n\n\"Lucky I watched a lot of golf this morning and I saw that the golf course was not playing easy,\" he said.\"Just tried to go out and play my game and hit some good shots and hole a few putts, and I did that, and I'm pretty happy.\"\n\nLowry was hot with the putter, especially from the 10-foot range, sinking three birdies on the front nine, including at the Postage Stamp, and a 21-footer at No. 11.\n\n\"I feel like links greens when you start to see your lines, the hole feels quite big, so it felt like that today, and long may it continue,\" he said.\n\nLowry may have been better prepared for the change in wind direction after playing some rounds at Troon two weeks during a scouting trip.\n\n\"I played this wind on the second day that I played here,\" he said. \"I saw the golf course in every wind possible I could see it.\"\n\nLowry held the opening-round lead when he won in 2019, and said getting off to a fast start should serve him well, but there's a long way to go.\n\n\"Look, I'd give anything to win this tournament again,\" he said. \"I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again, and that's why I'm here this week. This is obviously a great start to do that.\"\n\nJustin Rose knows no thorns with clean card\n\nJustin Rose hits from the fairway on the 1st hole during the first round of the Open Championship golf tournament at Royal Troon. Mandatory Credit: Jack Gruber-USA TODAY Sports\n\nDespite being a past major winner, Olympic gold medalist and Ryder Cupper last year, Justin Rose wasn't exempt into the 152nd British Open. But with rounds of 66 and 68 at the Burnham & Berrow qualifying site, Rose finished in a tie for first and earned his spot in the field to secure his 22nd appearance in the game's oldest major.\n\nThe Englishman started well in chasing that elusive Claret Jug, signing for a bogey-free 2-under 69 on Thursday.\n\nRose noted that he switched last week to a Scotty Cameron putter for the slower greens on this side of the pond and the early returns have been good.\n\n\"Just for a change of feel,\" Rose said. \"Just changed it up for a different visual for a period of time and see if we can find some magic.\"\n\nAdam Scott's shaft switch\n\nAdam Scott after putting on the 18th green during the first round of the Open Championship golf tournament at Royal Troon. Mandatory Credit: Jack Gruber-USA TODAY Sports\n\nAdam Scott is coming off his best result of the season - finishing second at the Genesis Scottish Open - and picked up where he left off, posting 1-under 70 on Thursday.\n\n\"My game is finally in some decent shape where I feel like I'm controlling the ball well,\" he said. \"That's what you need to do out here, especially if you're going to give yourself a lot of chances.\"\n\nAsked to explain what he's found in his game, Scott credited an equipment change. He swapped out the shafts in his irons to the True Temper Project X LZ, a shaft he used back in 2016.\n\n\"I don't know why I changed from it,\" he said. \"I played good that year, so of course I changed it.\"\n\nScott said he made the change leading into the Scottish Open after a nice pattern started emerging in his swing after making the adjustment.\n\n\"It's incredible. It's one of those things I've been looking for, like it just started feeling easy again whereas I feel like it's been hard work and I don't know why,\" Scott said. \"I couldn't quite figure it out.\"\n\nThe Postage Stamp stumps McIlroy and others\n\nRory McIlroy of Northern Ireland looks on from the 18th green on day one of The 152nd Open championship at Royal Troon on July 18, 2024 in Troon, Scotland. (Photo by Ross Kinnaird/Getty Images)\n\nIt's 123 yards of pure terror, especially if you miss the green and find one of its diabolical bunkers as Rory McIlroy did. He left his first attempt to splash out in the bunker and wasn't alone. Justin Thomas, Adam Scott and Shane Lowry were among the players under par in Round One who made a birdie at the famed pint-sized par 3. For more on the Postage Stamp, click here.\n\nHere's a look at the stats at the hole on Thursday.\n\n32 birdies\n\n33 bogeys\n\n20 doubles or worse\n\n51 percent greens in regulation\n\n36 percent {"uri": "8233898904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:10:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:10:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:09:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/07/19/sports/shane-lowry-didnt-let-11th-hole-disaster-stop-british-open-march/", "title": "Shane Lowry didn't let 11th hole disaster stop march atop British...", "body": "TROON, Scotland -- Shane Lowry put himself in the driver's seat to win a second career British Open with a gritty second-round performance Friday at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry, who began the day one shot out of the lead, shot a 2-under-par 69 to get to 7-under for the tournament and hold a two-shot lead over first-round leader Daniel Brown as the afternoon groups were teeing off for their respective second rounds.\n\nThe 37-year-old, who won the 2019 Open at Portrush, was in cruise control at 2-under-par through 10 holes in the round, until he reached the difficult par-4 11th.\n\n\"I was in control of my ball, did all the right things for a lot of the round and then when I got in a bit of trouble,'' Lowry said of a second shot he tugged into a thick gorse bush on 11.\n\nThat cost him a double bogey, dropping him back to 5-under par, but he rallied with a birdie on the par-5 16th and another on 18 to close.\n\n\"I feel like I really finished the round well,'' Lowry said. \"I'm pretty happy with the day. To be leading this tournament after two days, it's why you come here, it's why we're here.\n\n\"I'll sit back and watch a bit of golf in the afternoon and see where it leaves me come the end of the day, and get out there tomorrow. The job tomorrow as well is to try to put myself in a position to win this tournament on Sunday, and that's what I'll try and do.''\n\nLowry's issue on the 11th ironically occurred after he'd hit the most difficult shot on the hole -- the tee shot -- with the railway just a few yards to the right of the hole. His tee shot came to rest in the right rough and his second shot went way left into the bush.\n\n\"I did the hard part; I hit my drive where you could find it, which is obviously a hard thing to do on that hole,'' Lowry said. \"I got a little bit distracted on the right just as I was over the shot, and I kind of lost a bit of train of thought. You're so afraid of going right there that I just snagged the club and went left.\n\n\"Then from there, I hit a great provisional. The referee asked me going down, 'Did I want to find my first one?' And I said, 'No.' So, I assumed that was OK. Then we get down there, and somebody had found it.\n\n\"So, apparently we have to find it then, or you have to go and identify it, which I thought, if you declared it lost before it was found, that you didn't, you didn't have to go and identify it. I felt like through that whole process of that 20 minutes of taking the drop, seeing where I could drop, and I felt like I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a 6. It was not like it wasn't a disaster. I was still leading the tournament.''\n\nLowry called the 12th hole \"a key'' to his round because it \"was playing very difficult, straight into the wind.''\n\n\"I hit driver, 4-iron there, too, the best shots I've hit all week, to about 30 feet and made par there,\" he said. \"From then on, I felt like (wind) down out of the left coming in, it was playing quite difficult, but I felt like you could give yourself chances on the way in, and that's what I did.''\n\nLowry lauded how calm he was in the windy conditions.\n\n\"I get to conditions like this, and I know I can do it, I know I can deal with that,'' he said. \"There's an art (to it). It's quite difficult to stand up there from 190 yards and make yourself hit a 4-iron as low as you can. It's quite difficult to tell yourself that.''\n\nLowry credited the time he spent around home in Ireland in the lead-up to this week playing links golf with his buddies as a help.\n\n\"The golf I've played in Ireland, coming here and doing my (preparation) here a few weeks ago, I feel like that's all helped,'' he said. \"I have felt quite calm and composed the last couple of days. I've felt really in my comfort zone. Yeah, I'm pretty happy with how things have gone.''\n\nTo his credit, Brown, who had the 36-hole lead at 6-under, hung in there and dropped only one shot on Friday, standing on 5-under par.\n\nThis is a 29-year-old journeyman who entered the week having missed seven of his previous eight cuts on the DP World Tour and making it into the field after draining a 20-foot putt on the final hole of {"uri": "2024-07-426980190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "10:08:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T10:08:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T09:29:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1146794/golf-british-open-lowry-round-one", "title": "British Open: Shane Lowry shines, Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods struggle", "body": "Day one of the 152nd British Open saw Shane Lowry card the lowest opening round of his major career while McIlroy and Woods experienced nightmare starts at Royal Troon.\n\nIt was English major debutant Daniel Brown who took a surprise overnight lead at five under par after the first round of the 152nd British Open sitting one ahead of Shane Lowry. Lowry shot three birdies in five holes around the turn before bagging another at the 18th on the opening day putting him on -5 and in an excellent position to challenge for a second Open victory.\n\nFor big names Rory McIlroy and Tiger Woods, on the other hand, it was a start to forget as the two struggled in the wet and windy conditions posting a seven over par and eight over par respectively. It is a particular blow for McIllroy who painfully missed out on the US Open last month missing two short putts and handing Bryson DeChambeau his second major by the narrowest of leads.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" said McIlroy. \"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance.\"\n\nTwo-time major winner Justin Thomas sits on the tails of Lowry and Brown at three under with recently crowned USPGA Championship winner Xander Schauffele one of five close behind at two under.\n\nWith four birdies and three bogeys, Scottie Scheffler finished day one at one under par but is still in the mix despite cutting a frustrated figure during the opening round on Scotland's west coast.\n\nOn the back of his second US Open and some fantastic performances in the majors this year, DeChambeau's start was far from ideal as he carded six over par in the windy conditions of day one.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today,\" he said. \"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home'. But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. {"uri": "8234099596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:16:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:16:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:15:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/open-championship-hot-headed-shane-lowry-shrugs-off-cameraman-clash-to-roar-ahead-but-rory/article_bd0cd4a7-ba17-5405-88a3-471afffe8c68.html", "title": "Open Championship: 'Hot headed' Shane Lowry shrugs off cameraman clash to roar ahead but Rory McIlroy flames out", "body": "(CNN) -- Rivals and cameramen, make way - Shane Lowry is coming through at the Open Championship.\n\nThe Irishman lifted the red mist that momentarily descended upon him at Royal Troon in Scotland to wrestle control of the major, as his second round two-under 69 on Friday sent him into the weekend with a two shot lead.\n\nAfter opening with a bogey-free 66 on Thursday, 2019 champion Lowry had been motoring along smoothly at the summit before his advantage was derailed by a disastrous 30-minute saga on the notorious par-four 11th \"Railway\" hole.\n\nHaving narrowly survived sending his tee shot onto the train tracks that run alongside the 488-yard hole, the world No. 33 went from frying pan to fire as his subsequent effort from the rough went careening left into the thick gorse across the other side of the fairway.\n\nA visibly disgruntled Lowry then gesticulated and pointed animatedly at a nearby cameraman, later admitting that he had - no pun intended - \"lost his train of thought\" after becoming \"a little distracted\" while stood over his shot.\n\n\"There was a cameraman there, and he was walking up. I asked him to stop or move back, and he just kind of stayed there,\" Lowry told reporters on his return to the clubhouse.\n\n\"As it was over, he put his camera up. I kind of saw it out of the corner of my eye, and I should stood off it, (it was) my own fault.\"\n\nThe drama continued when Lowry struck a \"great\" provisional shot - taken when a ball is presumed lost outside a penalty area or out of bounds - to within 12 feet of the hole, only for one eagle-eyed fan to subsequently find his original ball and void his provisional effort in the process.\n\nAfter a lengthy discussion with a rules official regarding where to take a drop from, the 37-year-old golfer eventually left with a double bogey - enough to erase his two-shot cushion, but \"not a disaster\", he later reflected.\n\nIf Lowry had lost his cool, he quickly found it in abundance. After rebounding with four steady pars, the Irishman signed off with his second birdie in three holes to restore the gap to English duo Justin Rose and Daniel Brown heading into the weekend.\n\nAs he seeks to turn back the clock to his dominant triumph at Royal Portrush in Northern Ireland five years ago, Lowry has no intention of throttling the passion that helped him clinch his sole major to date.\n\n\"I can get a bit down on myself and a bit hot headed at times, but I really feel like that's why I've had the career I've had,\" Lowry, who has nine combined wins on the PGA Tour and European Tour, said.\n\n\"If I go out there and try to be somebody I'm not, you're just not going to be successful ... [But] If I go out there and be myself, I feel like I can do very well. So allowing myself to do that, without getting in your own way.\"\n\nMcIlroy among big stars to crash out\n\nIt was an entirely contrasting day for Northern Irishman Rory McIlroy, as the world No. 2 capitulated to become the highest profile casualty of a host of big names that failed to make the cut.\n\nThe 35-year-old star had been out to exorcise the demons of his latest heartbreaking major near-miss at the US Open last month but found only more woe at Royal Troon, finishing 11-over par overall to fall well short of the top-70 players and ties that progressed to the weekend.\n\nNeeding a fast start after a grueling first round 78, McIlroy's hopes of making the cut were effectively extinguished by the end of the sixth hole after a nightmarish stretch. Having bogeyed the third, McIlroy triple bogeyed the following par-five hole before back-to-back bogeys.\n\nA solid back nine saw him go two-under par down the stretch but the damage was done, his closing 75 ensuring his wait for a fifth major will continue into an 11th year.\n\nOnce I made the eight on the 4th hole, that was it. 22 holes into the event and I'm thinking about where I'm going to go on vacation next week,\" McIlroy admitted to reporters.\n\n\"It was a pretty meaningless 14 holes after that, but at least I played okay and at least feel like, when the wind dropped, my game felt a little more comfortable and I hit some good shots.\"\n\nTiger Woods will also be absent from the weekend, resigning him to a third consecutive missed major cut for just the second time in his career.\n\nThe 48-year-old shot 79 and 77 to finish on 14-over par, the joint-highest 36-hole score he has ever recorded at a major, but insisted he still enjoyed the challenge.\n\n\"I've always loved playing major championships. I just wish I was more physically sharp coming into the majors,\" Woods, who added he will \"definitely\" compete at next year's Open at Royal Portrush in Northern Ireland, told reporters Friday.\n\n\"Obviously it tests you mentally, physically, emotionally, and I just wasn't as sharp as I needed to be. I was hoping that I would find it somehow, just never did. Consequently, my results and scores were pretty high.\"\n\nOther big names that failed to survive the cut included last month's US Open winner Bryson DeChambeau, and last year's US Open champion Wyndham Clark.\n\nWith McIlroy, world No. 4 Ludvig Aberg and world No. 7 Viktor Hovland also missing out, only half of the world's top-10 ranked players - Scottie Scheffler, Xander Schauffele, Collin Morikawa, Patrick Cantlay and Jon Rahm - will tee up Saturday.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros.
