{"uri": "8232400803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "20:22:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T20:22:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T20:21:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/shane-lowry-sets-pace-bogey-200914841.html", "title": "Shane Lowry sets the pace with bogey-free round to move into outright lead at Royal Troon", "body": "Shane Lowry made the ideal start to his bid for a second Open title as Rory McIlroy effectively wrote off his chances of doing the same at Royal Troon.\n\nLowry carded a flawless 66 to hold a two-shot lead over former world number one Justin Thomas after McIlroy struggled to an opening 78.\n\nIt was a contrast which immediately brought to mind the 2019 Open at Royal Portrush, when Lowry started with a 67 on his way to the Claret Jug and McIlroy's chances were blown away with a 79.\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" Lowry, who made birdies on the fourth, seventh, eighth, 11th and 18th, told Sky Sports.\n\n\"I got off to a bit of an iffy start and holed a couple of nice par putts early on and then I was off and running.\n\n\"I try not to think about it [2019] too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years'.\n\n\"No matter what I do that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nA downbeat Rory McIlroy had earlier dismissed his chances of mounting a challenge for a fifth major title after a costly run of holes around the turn.\n\nMcIlroy was level par after seven holes before running up a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth, the Northern Irishman's first attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp coming back to his feet.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind McIlroy was hopeful of repairing the damage, only to drive out of bounds on the 11th to run up another double bogey and eventually finish seven over par, 12 shots behind Lowry.\n\nAsked if he could make up the ground he had conceded, there was a lengthy pause before McIlroy said: \"I mean, all I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on.\"\n\nThe 35-year-old, who agonisingly missed out on an overdue fifth major title in last month's US Open, added: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\n\n\"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple of shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\n\"Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst to win his second US Open, also found himself well down the field following a 76, although the American did at least hole from 55 feet for an eagle on the 16th.\n\nSweden's Alex Noren, who only secured his place in the field via a tie for 10th in the Scottish Open on Sunday, was a shot off the pace alongside American Russell Henley and Ryder Cup team-mates Justin Rose and Nicolai Hojgaard. AP\n\nRose, who had to come through a 36-hole qualifier to make it to Troon, carded two birdies and 16 pars in his bogey-free 69.\n\nFew groups left out there. Dan Brown is in one of them, he's on the 15th at the moment and he's still on four-under. To find out how he finished read the report which will land above here soon.\n\nOn the round...\n\nOn whether he's playing as well as he did when he won at Portrush...\n\nAnd the conditions are currently as good as they have been all day. Good news for those late starters, one of whom is Dan Brown on four-under.\n\nSo the world No.1 walks off the 18th with a one-under 70. He was solid rather than spectacular today but that was the order of the day. He's lurking with intent only four off the lead.\n\nSpieth also cards a level-par 71.\n\nAs expected he drains the five-foot birdie putt to card a five-under 66. Michael Hendry has teed off at The Open this morning having recovered from a serious Leukemia diagnosis, a diagnosis that put him out of action for Royal Liverpool last year. Now he's back, swinging well again and ready to take on the might of Royal Troon. Find out more about his story in the video below.\n\nFamous announcer Ivor Robson is remembered before tee off. Winner at Royal Troon in 1997, Justin Leonard steps up to the tee. He stripes it out the par 4 1st with an iron to get things under way. 2004 champion Todd Hamilton, also using an iron, fades one out onto the fairway and debutant Jack McDonald follows suit with a beautifully rhythmic drive, placing on the short stuff. We're off at the 152nd Open Championship.\n\n7:41 a.m. - Francesco Molinari, Justin Rose, Jasper Stubbs (a)\n\n2:15 p.m. - Padraig Harrington, Davis Thompson, Matthew Jordan\n\n2:26 p.m. - Wyndham Clark, Hideki Matsuyama, Brooks Koepka\n\n2:37 p.m. - Tiger Woods, Xander Schauffele, Patrick Cantlay\n\n3:10 p.m. - Jordan Spieth, Scottie Scheffler, Cameron Young\n\nGood morning to those bleary-eyed of you who have raised in time to catch the early starters at the opening of The 152nd Open Championship at Royal Troon.\n\nSandwiched between the European Championship and the Olympic Games, this year's tournament has a chance to breathe in what is a short week-long hiatus between those two major sporting events.\n\nIt is unquestionably the marquee event of the week and with a mix of wind, sun and rain forecast in Ayrshire, this promises a classic links challenge to the finest players in the world.\n\nAmong them, of course, is Rory McIlroy, who is playing his second tournament since his meltdown during the closing stages of the US Open at Pinehurst last month.\n\nA fourth-place finish at last week's Scottish Open suggests his game remains in good shape but whether he is ready mentally for the cauldron of a The Open, so soon after throwing away a fifth major championship, remains to be seen.\n\nThe Northern Irishman is out at 10.09 this morning alongside Max Homa and Tyrell Hatton in what looks like the headline group among the early starters. Click here for full round one tee times.\n\nLater in the day, Tiger Woods gets underway at 2.47pm on a course at which he has played three times during The Open. A three-time winner of this event, Woods has struggled here, with his ninth-placed finish in 2004 his best showing.\n\nPay close attention to Hole 8 this morning - named Postage Stamp. What looks like an easy 123-yard Par 3 is perhaps the hardest of its kind played at any Open venue.\n\nSharp slopes all around the green are ready to take errant tee shots into the penal greenside bunkers, while the putting surface itself is, at most, 11 paces wide.\n\nWith the wind set to touch 30mph around midday, Postage Stamp could yet bare its teeth to the very best in the world. It just might make you all feel a touch better about your games to see a pro take seven from 123 yards.\n\nGrab a coffee and let's enjoy a superb morning of action from Royal Troon.", "source": He began the first round on Thursday with a 3-under 68 that set an early target and left him satisfied.\n\nNever mind that 62 he had a week ago in the Scottish Open. Royal Troon required hard work, and with just enough rain and plenty of wind the links along the Ayrshire coast showed it was capable of punishing players without notice.\n\nU.S. Open champion Bryson DeChambeau kept missing par putts, wound up with a 76 and was headed to the range to figure out his equipment and why his golf ball didn't leave the club the way he expected.\n\n\"It was a weird day,\" he said.\n\nRory McIlroy, hopeful of bouncing back from his U.S. Open collapse, took a double bogey on the famed \"Postage Stamp\" eighth hole, and piped a driver out of bounds on the 11th for another double bogey. It added to a 7-over 78, his worst start to a major in five years.\n\n\"The conditions were tough on that back nine, and I just didn't do a good enough job,\" he said.\n\nThomas was not immune.\n\nHe was one of three players who reached 4 under among the early starters and had the wind at his back for the inward nine at Troon. And then his tee shot landed in a bush that required a penalty drop and he missed a 4-foot putt and made double bogey. His next drive took a wild hop into grass so deep his caddie called out to the gallery, \"Last call. Anyone see the other ball to the right?\" They eventually found it, but it led to bogey.\n\n\"A little bit of a hiccup in the beginning of the back nine but stayed patient and kept plugging,\" Thomas said.\n\nIndeed, Thomas managed to keep it together. He avoided another bogey with a 12-foot par putt, and finished with a 6-iron to 8 feet for birdie on the 17th and a birdie on the 18th that showed how much wind was helping -- 4-iron off the tee, wedge into 25 feet on the 458-yard closing hole.\n\nJustin Rose, who had to go through final qualifying to get into the Open, was equally impressive by playing bogey-free for a 69, joined by a group that included Nicolai Hojgaard of Denmark and Alex Noren, who only qualified through the Scottish Open.\n\nMatt Wallace was one of those at 4 under early in his round, only to take triple bogey on the ninth hole. He finished at 69, along with Adam Scott.\n\nJustin Leonard, a winner at Royal Troon in 1997, returned for the first time since 2016 and was given the honor of the opening tee shot with the shiny claret jug positioned nearby on a podium. He had an 80, one of already five rounds of 80 or higher. That list included John Daly, who made an 8 on the final hole for an 82.\n\nMasters champion Scottie Scheffler, the world's No. 1 player, and Tiger Woods were among those who played late in the afternoon.\n\nWoods's 8-over 79 left him in danger of missing the cut for a third straight time at the Open.\n\n\"I didn't do a whole lot of things right today,\" he said. \"I need to shoot something {"uri": "8232968783", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:39:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:39:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:39:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/golf/open-day-two-shane-lowry-not-getting-carried-away-despite-flawless-start/a1040549354.html", "title": "Open day two: Shane Lowry not getting carried away despite flawless start", "body": "Shane Lowry insisted he would not get carried away by the prospect of a second Open title despite making a flawless start at Royal Troon.\n\nThe 2019 champion carded a five-under-par 66 on Thursday to lie just a shot behind English qualifier Daniel Brown, the world number 272 making a birdie on the 18th in near-darkness to snatch a shock lead on his major debut.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy, but it's only one day,\" Lowry said. \"We've got three more.\n\n\"I kept telling myself that out there because for some reason I felt like the crowd were getting very excited. It was late in the afternoon and a few pints of Tennent's were had out there. It felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\n\n\"The walk down 18 was actually pretty cool. I said to Billy Foster [Matt Fitzpatrick's caddie] that it's the greatest walk in golf and I got to do it on a Sunday afternoon with a full house. That's the plan, to try to get to do that again.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again. I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again and that's why I'm here this week.\"\n\nLowry's friend and Ryder Cup team-mate Rory McIlroy faced an uphill struggle simply to make the cut on Friday, the world number two carding double bogeys on the eighth and 11th in a first round of 78.\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst last month to win a second US Open title, also had work to do following a 76 which was matched by England's Tommy Fleetwood, while 15-time major winner Tiger Woods looked destined for another early exit following a 79.\n\nShot of the day\n\nSpanish amateur Jaime Montojo had a fairytale start to his maiden Open when he holed out from 132 yards for an eagle on the first.\n\nRound of the day\n\nQualifier Daniel Brown also enjoyed a dream Open debut with a flawless 65 rounded off by a birdie on the 18th at 9.33pm to take the lead.\n\nQuote of the day\n\nMin Woo Lee apologies to the volunteer tasked with raking bunkers on the famous eighth hole after he and many others found sand at the Postage Stamp.\n\nStatistic of the day\n\nTop statistician Justin Ray highlights how impressive Brown's round was.\n\nEasiest hole\n\nThe par-five 16th, which played downwind, was unsurprisingly the easiest hole, yielding four eagles, 39 birdies, 25 bogeys and just one double bogey for an average of 4.872.\n\nHardest hole\n\nThe 450-yard 12th hole is not as well known as the eighth or 11th, but played the most difficult with just nine birdies, 44 bogeys, seven double bogeys and three \"other\" scores leading to an average of 4.397.\n\nSelected tee times\n\n0925 - {"uri": "8233937977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:42:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:42:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:40:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3023576-shubhankar-sharmas-battle-to-keep-hopes-alive-at-the-152nd-open", "title": "Shubhankar Sharma's Battle to Keep Hopes Alive at The 152nd Open | Sports-Games", "body": "Indian golfer Shubhankar Sharma fought back with birdies on the 15th and 16th holes in the second round of the 152nd Open. Despite bogeys that pushed him to 6-over, he remains in contention. Shane Lowry leads at 7-under, while legends like Tiger Woods made early exits.\n\nIndian golfer Shubhankar Sharma was hanging by a thread after fighting back with birdies on the 15th and 16th holes during the second round of the 152nd Open on Friday.\n\nSharma, turning 28 on the final day of this edition, had two bogeys on the seventh and the ninth holes, pushing him to 7-over for the tournament. With the cut looking likely at either 5-over or 6-over, a birdie on the 12th followed by a bogey on the 14th tested his resilience.\n\nHe birdied from 20 feet on the 15th and added another on the Par-5 16th to get to 5-over. However, he lost a shot on the 17th, dropping back to 6-over and tied 71st with one more hole to go. With the cut line at 70 and ties, Sharma was still in the game.\n\nAs Sharma battled on, Shane Lowry moved into pole position for a second Open title, having won his first five years ago at Portrush. Lowry (66-69) was 7-under, leading Justin Rose (69-68) and Dan Brown (65-72) by two shots.\n\nWorld No. 1 Scottie Scheffler (70-70) was in tied fourth, alongside Billy Horschel (72-68) and Dean Burmester (71-69) at 2-under 140 for 36 holes.\n\nSeveral big names made early exits, swept aside by the southerly wind at Royal Troon. Tiger Woods, shooting 79-77 for a 14-over total, acknowledged he wasn't physically sharp but looked forward to future events. Indian-Americans Akshay Bhatia and Sahith Theegala also headed home early.\n\nShane Lowry led the field as he gunned for a second Open title, his sole PGA Tour win this season coming in the company of McIlroy. {"uri": "8233879879", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:56:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:56:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:54:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/shane-lowry-fumes-cameraman-double-165107423.html", "title": "Shane Lowry fumes at cameraman as he double bogeys 11th hole", "body": "Shane Lowry was involved in a furious bust-up with a cameraman during the second round of the Open Championship, but recovered his poise to stay in the upper echelons of the leaderboard.\n\nLowry shot a 69 to move to seven-under after battling back from a double-bogey on the 11th. It was on the treacherous par four where the Irishman snapped in four-lettered fury.\n\nThe 2019 champion hit his tee shot into the rough on this brutal driving hole with a train track on one side and thick gorse on the other, but when he tried to extricate himself from the cabbage his ball flew left into a bush.\n\nImmediately, Lowry swivelled and let the cameraman have it. \"As I was over the ball I could just see you putting your f------' camera up,\" Lowry said. \"Just get outta the way. Just get back there. F--- sake!\"\n\nLowry's contention was that the man moved in the middle of his backswing and was clearly incensed. But later the 37-year-old played down the incident. \"There was a cameraman there, and he was walking up, and I asked him to stop or move back, and he just kind of stayed there,\" Lowry said. \"As it was over, he put his camera up. I kind of saw it out of the corner of my eye, and I should stood off it - my own fault.\"\n\nLowry believed he had \"done the hard part\" by putting his drive in play. As it proved, he was unlucky that his ball was found in the bush, because he had hit a provisional to 10 feet to give himself the opportunity to limit the damage to a bogey. But a spectator located the first ball, meaning it was still in play and after a 20-minute wait to ascertain where he could drop the ball, the best Lowry could escape with was a six.\n\nDavid Howell, the former Ryder Cup player who is working for Sky this week as an on-course commentator, revealed that the fan who found the ball was \"a little sheepish\" when he realised Lowry did not want that to happen. \"He's feeling awful,\" Howell said.\n\nNevertheless, Lowry birdied the 16th and 18th to claw back the shots and is pleased with how he reacted. \"Sometimes you are in a frame of mind where you get on with it better than other times,\" he said. \"This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. I just have to deal with it and try and make the best of it and see where it leads me.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy with how things have gone. The job tomorrow is to try to put myself in a position to win this tournament on Sunday, and that's what I'll try and do. If I give myself a chance on Sunday I know I can do it and that's as good as a position to be in as any.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, trap.\n\nThings got worse when he bogeyed the 10th and he emerged with a double bogey at the 11th after hitting his tee shot out of bounds over the railway track skirting the course.\n\nDefending The Northern Irishman made a double bogey on the iconic Postage Stamp 8th hole, and his issues continued when he knocked his tee shot OB on the 11th to card his second double of the day.\n\nTiger Woods also struggled to find any form, finishing the day eight over. Having not played much competitive golf in the lead-up to today, expectations were low, but by his own high standards, it was a very disappointing day for the 15-time major champion.\n\nDespite its short length, Troon's famous Postage Stamp 8th hole dished out some serious scorecard damage today. McIlroy, Clark, and Morikawa all walked off with a double bogey, proving that par threes don't have to be long to be tough.\n\nAs conditions began to get easier in the afternoon, there were birdies to be had, and Lowry was the key benefactor.\n\nBrown, Xander Schauffele, and Russell Henley also enjoyed productive rounds. {"uri": "2024-07-426765028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:41:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:41:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:09:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/open-championship-news-rory-mcilroy-gets-real-disheartening-start", "title": "Rory McIlroy gets 100% real after disheartening start", "body": "Shane Lowry surged to the top of the leaderboard at five under par, taking advantage of the calmer late afternoon conditions at Royal Troon. In contrast, Rory McIlroy and Bryson DeChambeau had a rough start, with McIlroy carding a seven-over-par 78 and Woods shooting a 79.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" McIlroy remarked via Kieran Canning.\n\nRory McIlroy's struggles\n\nRory McIlroy was even par after the first seven holes but then faltered with a double bogey on the signature par-three eighth. His attempt to escape a bunker on the Postage Stamp hole ended up with the ball returning to his feet.\n\n\"I need to go out there and play better and try to shoot something under par and at least be here for the weekend, if not try to put myself up the leaderboard a bit more and feel like I have half a chance,\" McIlroy continued.\n\nWith the back nine playing downwind, McIlroy hoped to make up for his earlier mistakes. However, he drove out of bounds on the 11th hole, resulting in another double bogey. He ended the day at seven over par, trailing clubhouse leader Justin Thomas by 10 shots.\n\nThe 35-year-old, who narrowly missed out on securing his long-awaited fifth major title at last month's US Open, said: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and made a double.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau also didn't fare well\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who narrowly defeated McIlroy at Pinehurst to secure his second US Open title, also struggled in the field after shooting a 76. However, the American managed to salvage his round with a 55-foot eagle on the 16th hole.\n\nDeChambeau's front nine of 42 featured a double bogey on the 612-yard sixth hole, where his second shot advanced only a few yards from the heavy rough before he had to hit his next shot onto the adjacent 13th fairway.\n\nThe morning conditions, marked by light rain and gusty winds of up to 23 miles per hour, created chaos for the golfers.\n\nJustin Thomas rising to the occasion\n\nDespite the challenging weather, Justin Thomas managed to secure a 3-under round, bolstered by two birdies at the end of his round, allowing him to hold a strong position on the leaderboard for much of the morning.\n\nThomas started strong with a chip-in birdie on the par-4 second hole and added three more birdies while making just one bogey to reach the turn at 3-under 33. However, his momentum faltered on the back nine. A poorly pulled tee shot on the 12th forced him to take a penalty drop, resulting in a double-bogey. He further struggled on the 13th, where he pushed his drive into the high rough on the right, leading to another bogey.\n\nThomas ended his round strong, sinking birdies on the last two holes, including a 25-footer on No. 18. This finish brought him back to 3 under par, placing him one stroke ahead of Alex Noren, Nicolai H\u00f8jgaard, Justin Rose, and Russell Henley.\n\nCameron Smith, the 2021 champion at St. Andrews, struggled with an 80. {"uri": "8233545254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "13:00:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T13:00:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:59:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/sport/golf/jason-day-makes-troon-open-move-with-fine-second-round-c-15412013", "title": "Jason Day makes Troon Open move with fine second round", "body": "Jason Day makes Troon Open move with fine second roundIan ChadbandAAPFri, 19 July 2024 8:56PM\n\nJason Day has moved powerfully into contention on the second morning of the British Open at Royal Troon, shooting a flawless three-under par round of 68 to race up the leaderboard.\n\nThe Australian No.1 started Friday eight shots adrift of leader Dan Brown, but with the pacesetters struggling to consolidate their advantage on another gusty morning at the Ayrshire links, Day's bogey-free second round ensured he had cut the deficit in half by the time of his lunchtime finish.\n\nIt could have been even better for the 36-year-old, who missed a 12-foot birdie putt at the last, yet his round was still the joint-best among the early Friday starters alongside American Billy Horschel, whose own 68 left him the early second-round clubhouse leader at two under.\n\nDay was just a shot behind and in a top-10 spot, which looked potentially even more promising with the worst weather conditions forecast for later in the afternoon.\n\nTwo over after his first round, a 30-foot birdie putt at the second hole, followed by another six footer at the next, got the Queenslander back to level par. Another 25-foot birdie effort at the 13th put him into red figures.\n\nAfter last year's runner-up's spot at Royal Liverpool which completed his set of second-place finishes at all the majors, former world No.1 Day is now looking to go one better at Troon and add a second big-four crown to the PGA Championship he won nine years ago.\n\nHis cause was helped when both the overnight pacesetters stuttered while trying to consolidate their advantage.\n\nShane Lowry grabbed the outright lead, then had it torn away from him in his roller-coaster round.\n\nThe 2019 champion recorded three more birdies before the turn to move to seven under and open up a two-shot advantage over England's overnight leader Dan Brown.\n\nLowry had dropped his first shot of the tournament after 23 holes when finding the bunker at the par-three fifth, but otherwise looked in complete control as he sank birdie putts from nine feet at the first, tap-in range at the long fourth and 11 feet at the ninth.\n\nBut the Irishman had a calamity at the 11th when he pulled his second shot into the gorse, took a penalty drop and hit his fourth on to the green, only for his original ball to be found by a spectator.\n\nThat meant it was still in play and, after a long delay while it was determined where he could best take a drop, Lowry hit his approach just short of the green and eventually completed a double-bogey six to fall back to the joint-lead on five under.\n\nLowry was playing alongside Australia's 2022 champ Cam Smith, whose miserable Open continued following his first-round 80, his worst ever round in a major.\n\nThree more bogeys in the first six holes were offset by the blessed relief of a rare birdie at the seventh but at 11 over after 13 holes the 30-year-old was sure to miss the cut, which was projected to be at four over.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": "thewest.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8232978791", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:48:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:48:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:48:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/uksport/2024/07/19/open-day-two-shane-lowry-not-getting-carried-away-despite-flawless-start/", "title": "Open day two: Shane Lowry not getting carried away despite flawless start", "body": "Shane Lowry insisted he would not get carried away by the prospect of a second Open title despite making a flawless start at Royal Troon.\n\nThe 2019 champion carded a five-under-par 66 on Thursday to lie just a shot behind English qualifier Daniel Brown, the world number 272 making a birdie on the 18th in near-darkness to snatch a shock lead on his major debut.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy, but it's only one day,\" Lowry said. \"We've got three more.\n\n\"I kept telling myself that out there because for some reason I felt like the crowd were getting very excited. It was late in the afternoon and a few pints of Tennent's were had out there. It felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"The walk down 18 was actually pretty cool. I said to Billy Foster [Matt Fitzpatrick's caddie] that it's the greatest walk in golf and I got to do it on a Sunday afternoon with a full house. That's the plan, to try to get to do that again.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again. I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again and that's why I'm here this week.\"\n\nLowry's friend and Ryder Cup team-mate Rory McIlroy faced an uphill struggle simply to make the cut on Friday, the world number two carding double bogeys on the eighth and 11th in a first round of 78.\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst last month to win a second US Open title, also had work to do following a 76 which was matched by England's Tommy Fleetwood, while 15-time major winner Tiger Woods looked destined for another early exit following a 79.\n\nShot of the day\n\nSpanish amateur Jaime Montojo had a fairytale start to his maiden Open when he holed out from 132 yards for an eagle on the first.\n\nRound of the day\n\nQualifier Daniel Brown also enjoyed a dream Open debut with a flawless 65 rounded off by a birdie on the 18th at 9.33pm to take the lead.\n\nQuote of the day\n\nMin Woo Lee apologies to the volunteer tasked with raking bunkers on the famous eighth hole after he and many others found sand at the Postage Stamp.\n\nStatistic of the day\n\nTop statistician Justin Ray highlights how impressive Brown's round was.\n\nEasiest hole\n\nThe par-five 16th, which played downwind, was unsurprisingly the easiest hole, yielding four eagles, 39 birdies, 25 bogeys and just one double bogey for an average of 4.872.\n\nHardest hole\n\nThe 450-yard 12th hole is not as well known as the eighth or 11th, but played the most difficult with just nine birdies, 44 bogeys, seven double bogeys and three \"other\" scores leading to an average of 4.397.\n\nSelected tee times\n\n0925 - Tiger Woods, Xander Schauffele, Patrick Cantlay\n\n0947 - Shane Lowry, Cameron Smith, Matt Fitzpatrick\n\n1242 - Francesco Molinari, Justin Rose, Jasper Stubbs\n\n1253 - Justin Thomas, Sungjae Im, Matthew Southgate\n\n1448 - Ludvig Aberg, Bryson DeChambeau, Tom Kim\n\n1510 - Rory McIlroy, Max Homa, Tyrrell Hatton\n\nWeather forecast\n\nCloudy with a chance of some early drizzle before turning brighter and breezier as the day progresses. {"uri": "8232856884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "05:04:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T05:04:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T05:03:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.tennisworldusa.org/other_news/golf/146670/shane-lowry-hopes-for-another-claret-jug-is-it-too-much-to-ask/", "title": "Shane Lowry hopes for another Claret Jug: Is it too much to ask?", "body": "\"The Open Championship is the biggest tournament in the world.\"- Lowry said.\n\nShane Lowry is a well-known name in the world of golf. He has had many brilliant moments behind him, but many nostalgically recall the moment when the Irishman lifted the trophy five years ago, winning the Open Championship. It remains the only Major on Lowry's resume.\n\nDespite being close to winning Majors many times as a 37-year-old, slight differences meant that Lowry returned home without a trophy.\n\nJudging by his success five years ago, this tournament suits him well, and Lowry has high ambitions. Ahead of another edition of the Open Championship, Lowry reflected on the words of his compatriot Harrington, who often advises him. Padraig revealed to him that when he was 37, it was also one of his best years in golf. Lowry hopes for the same.\n\n\"I remember saying that to Padraig at the start of the year and he said when he was 37 he had one of his bets years so I'm still holding on to that,\" -Lowry said, as reported by Irish Golfer.\n\nBuilding a career as an athlete and as a golfer involves always dreaming of winning trophies, leading the way, and leaving a mark in history. When you see yourself succeeding in these aspirations, your appetite grows. Lowry has realized many times in his career that he has the potential for great things, and his hunger for victories is becoming greater and greater. During the press conference, he was visibly upbeat and smiling, ready to win Majors once again.\n\n\"I feel like when you've tasted success, you just want it even more. That's just the way it is. I feel like I wanted so bad to win another one. Just give me one more and I'll be happy. (Laughing) That's all I want. It is too much to ask for.\"- Lowry continued.\n\nShane Lowry has had his best season yet on the PGA Tour. He stresses the unpredictable nature of golf, having experienced both highs, like shooting two 62s, and lows, such as an 85. Despite setbacks, he emphasizes the transient nature of success and adversity in the sport.\n\nReflecting on recent tournaments, he faced challenges but remained competitive, highlighting his satisfaction with his current form and performance this season. Looking ahead, he remains focused on the upcoming opportunities to excel in major championships, aware of their importance following his 2019 Open victory.\n\nThe Irishman points out that it is imperative in every tournament to reach the very end and win the trophy. However, there are differences in winning some other tournaments and Majors, especially the British Open. As a boy, Lowry heard stories about the claret jug, desiring to lift it. He considers this tournament the biggest in the world.\n\n\"You drive in here and you see the claret jug when you are registering and the history with it and the golf course and the magnitude of it is just big, I think it is the biggest tournament in the world and it certainly feels like that when you are here and it feels like that when you are preparing.\"- Lowry continued.\n\nShane Lowry strives to maintain a specific mentality of calmness. However, he acknowledges that this tournament is one of the biggest in the world of golf, and winning it holds a special meaning. Lowry emphasizes his desire to play the best golf he can, admitting that he feels anxious and nervous at times. Nevertheless, he finds that once he steps onto the golf course and reaches the first tee, he believes he'll be okay and without nerves.\n\nLowry tries to work on various aspects of his game week by week, with the intention of improving. The Irishman does not want to watch things silently, aware that his competition is training and striving for progress, just like him.\n\nHe feels that he has made significant progress with his putting since the Zurich Classic, even though he wasn't entirely comfortable during that event, despite winning. In the weeks following, he feels he has turned a corner and now feels confident with his putting stroke. Lowry often mentions that his ability to hole putts is crucial for his competitiveness in tournaments, and he remains optimistic about his chances moving forward.\n\nIt will be interesting to follow his performance and see what kind of form Lowry is in at the moment. Playing in this tournament is a special feeling. The fact that he already excelled playing the Open five years ago certainly gives him additional confidence. {"uri": "8232474855", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:33:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:33:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:32:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/golf/news/2024-open-championship-takeaways-justin-thomas-stuns-with-hot-start-scottie-scheffler-lurks-after-round-1/", "title": "2024 Open Championship takeaways: Justin Thomas stuns with hot start, Scottie Scheffler lurks after Round 1 - CBSSports.com", "body": "Thomas hoisting the Claret Jug may still be unlikely, but an early clubhouse lead has him in contention at Royal Troon Getty Images\n\nJustin Thomas is not someone who was anticipated to be near the top of the leaderboard across back to back weeks in Scotland. While obviously a tremendous golfer, his record overall at The Open Championship is sketchy, and he's put together an uneven season to this point. But after serving as the 18-hole leader last week at the Scottish Open, Thomas -- who held the lead out of the morning wave Thursday at Royal Troon -- sits just three shots back of leader Daniel Brown (-6).\n\nPlaying in the slightly more difficult morning wave, J.T. made seven birdies in his round. While his driving got a bit loose at times -- specifically early in his back nine -- his tee to green play overall was terrific, just as it was last week in Round 1 at The Renaissance Club.\n\nThomas is somebody whose Open record is not as good as it likely should be. In seven starts, he has just one top 30 finish to go with three missed cuts. He opened last year's Open with an 82 in the first round. These numbers are especially curious when considering Thomas' game, which is creative and built for the wind and the elements.\n\nThat shined Thursday in a way it has not in past years at this event.\n\n\"I felt like I had great control off the tee,\" he said. \"I hit some great drives, and I felt like I was creative on some of them of just trying to hold it against the winds, off the tees to make the fairways a little bigger and hold it in the fairways. Felt like I had a couple times that I could have maybe been a little bit more aggressive, but I just felt like it wasn't the right time or necessarily didn't need to.\"\n\nThat mindset also represents a maturity J.T. admitted to not always having when it comes to this tournament.\n\n\"I think that's parts of links golf and also just of golf in general that I've gotten better at and matured,\" he added. \"I feel better about this round than I did the one last week [when I led the Scottish Open] just in the sense of, I would say, the quality of play.\"\n\nWhether Thomas can take advantage of a great first round this week (unlike last week when he tumbled to a T62 finish) remains to be seen. He'll have to continue to putt decently -- perhaps not as well as his 3 strokes gained putting Thursday -- but given the trouble lurking off the tee at Royal Troon and how wild Thomas can sometimes be, the putter will have to save some strokes if he wants to truly contend this weekend.\n\nThere is a long way to go, and it's been a few years since Thomas put together four great rounds consecutively at a big event. But Thursday's opening effort continues a small but meaningful trend of good play early in tournaments.\n\nAnd wouldn't it be very golf if the two guys who beat everyone in the world at the U.S. Open a month ago (Bryson DeChambeau and Rory McIlroy) struggled to make the cut while the guy who shot a million (or 82) a year ago at this tournament went on to win the Claret Jug.\n\nThe favorite is lurking\n\nIf I'm J.T. or Shane Lowry or anyone holding the top handful of spots on the leaderboard, I'm quite concerned about Scottie Scheffler. Not because he's the No. 1 player in the world or the first golfer since Arnold Palmer in 1962 to win six times this quickly in a season but because he had a terrifyingly good Round 1 in which he was one of just 17 golfers under par only needing to make three putts outside of 5 feet.\n\n\"It's definitely frustrating when you're watching it 3 feet out and you think it's going to go in and it just doesn't,\" Scheffler said. At the end of the day, I pride myself on preparation and showing up ready to go. If I hit a really good putt from 15, 20 feet -- greens aren't perfect. It's not a perfect surface. You get wind and all kinds of stuff, and I'm lipping out. It's almost like you're just playing a numbers game. If I continue to hit really good putts, then eventually they will start falling in.\n\n\"That's kind of how I felt today. I don't really feel like I made many putts, but I felt like I hit a lot of quality putts, which for me is really good.\"\n\nIn other words: Scottie flushed it Thursday and barely got anything out of the round. His work off the tee was exquisite, holding balls against the wind and controlling everything quite well. His approach play was his usual Scottie Scheffler self. There's a 65 sitting in there if he continues to hit it like this, and I'm not sure this field or this tournament is built to withstand Scottie galloping from out in front with a 65 on his card.\n\nBe prepared; it's coming.\n\nWind golf\n\nIt's just so different. You have to hit it so well and make such great decisions throughout the entire round.\n\n\"We had it close to this yesterday,\" Jordan Spieth explained. \"We didn't have much wind the other days, so certainly, I think when you start hitting certain shots off the tee, they just -- like that front nine, all of us were short on everything as everybody was all day. And I think that was not quite being used to, so hopefully make the adjustment for tomorrow.\"\n\nThis was obvious all day but especially in the early wave. Sepp Straka, who shot a 1-under 70 a bit later on, summed it up well: \"You kind of have your mindset that's where it's going to be, and that's kind of part of the tournament. It almost makes it more fun when the conditions are like that, obviously when you're playing well. If you're not playing well, it just makes it annoying. You just got to focus on your shot. It does make it a little bit harder to do that. It's a little easier to kind of get in a funk out there when it's raining and kind of chilly.\"\n\nIt's the one variable in the game that players hate the most, but it also produces the most interesting shots and most thoughtful course management. After a few years of no wind at all, it was refreshing to see it howl a bit on Thursday to start the tournament.\n\nStaying within five\n\nThe last 24 Open winners have been within five strokes of the lead after 18 holes, according to Justin Ray. That means one of the following golfers will win this year's Open\n\nDaniel Brown: -6Shane Lowry: -5Justin Thomas: -3Alex Noren, Nicolai Hojgaard, Justin Rose, Russell Henley, Xander Schauffele, Mackenzie Hughes, Joe Dean: -2Adam Scott, Matt Wallace, Chris Kirk, Sepp Straka, Brooks Koepka, Matt Fitzpatrick, Scottie Scheffler: -1\n\nObviously, there are some fascinating names in that group, including Koepka, who is going for his sixth major. Schauffele is seeking his second in the last three attempts.\n\nThere have been 10 first-time Champion Golfers of the Year starting with Phil Mickelson in 2013 through to Brian Harman in 2023. The all-time record stands at 11 from 1994 to 2004.\n\nZurich Classic flip\n\nDid you think, after watching the Zurich Classic, that there would be a 12-stroke difference between the two guys who won the tournament? I did ... just not in this direction with Lowry at 5 under and Rory McIlroy at 7 over. Truly shocking stuff given how both of them were playing in New Orleans not that long ago.\n\nPostage Stamp fun\n\nThe shortest hole at Royal Troon is also the best hole on the course. The 120-yard par-3 8th hole -- nicknamed the Postage Stamp -- was amazing Thursday, and it is emblematic of what I believe is one of the best parts of the Open. There are easy doubles and triples lurking everywhere.\n\nRory McIlroy missed his spot by a couple of feet the 8th hole and made a 5, which led to a 78 for the round. That doesn't happen at most other events (even at major championships).\n\n\"I completely agree [that short par 3s are the best],\" said Thomas, who made a birdie on the 8th with a nifty spinner. \"I would double down by saying all the worst par-3s in the world are the long ones. I've never played a bad one that's 120 yards. The 8th hole here is a great example of that, especially given certain winds. You're very happy to walk off with a 3. It was nice to make a 2 today.\"\n\nThe Open rules\n\nThe Open can be so unhinged. Dan Brown, who has missed six of his last seven cuts and finished 61st at the Scottish Open last week, beat McIlroy, who has finished in the top five across five of his last seven events (including a T4 at the Scottish Open), by 13 shots. Thirteen!\n\nBrooks Koepka summed this up nicely: \"Look, there's a lot of good players, and when they play well, you can control your ball. Links golf, if you're creative enough, you can find different ways to get it near the hole.\"\n\nBut Adam Scott offered this warning: \"It's sometimes easy to scrap it around the links, but you're not going to hole a lot of 40-footers. So, at some point, you're going to need to hit some really quality iron shots from the fairway to get it in close to some tucked pins and give yourself more realistic chances. They're the guys who are going to be up there at the end of the week.\"\n\nFor 18 holes, anybody can get in the mix. Even Daniel Brown, who has one win as a professional ... ever. That's enough to dream on, even if the likelihood of holding off Scheffler and Co. for 54 more is not realistic. Sometimes, though, you just need a sliver of hope. Still, it will be hitters only come Saturday and Sunday.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kyle_porter@cbssports.com", "name": "Kyle Indian golfer Shubhankar Sharma was hanging by a thread after fighting back with birdies on the 15th and 16th holes in the second round of the 152nd Open here on Friday.\n\nRoyal Troon (Scotland), Jul 19 (PTI) Indian golfer Shubhankar Sharma was hanging by a thread after fighting back with birdies on the 15th and 16th holes in the second round of the 152nd Open here on Friday.\n\nSharma, who turns 28 on Sunday, the final day of this edition of the Open, had two bogeys on the seventh and the ninth, which pushed him to 7-over for the tournament, as the cut looked likely at either 5-over or 6-over.\n\nAlso Read | India Beat Pakistan By 7 Wickets in Women's Asia Cup T20 2024; Bowlers Star as Harmanpreet Kaur and Co Get Off to Winning Start.\n\nA birdie on the 12th was followed by a bogey on the 14th but he then showed his fighting abilities.\n\nHe birdied from 20 feet on the 15th and added another on the Par-5 16th to get to 5-over. Then, he gave back a shot on the 17th and dropped to 6-over and was tied 71st with one more hole to come. With 70 and ties making the cut, Sharma was still in with a chance.\n\nAlso Read | Legends Intercontinental T20 Unveils Trophy Ahead of Inaugural Season.\n\nAs Sharma was fighting hard to stay on for the weekend, Shane Lowry moved into pole position for a second Open title, after having won his first five years ago at home in Portrush.\n\nLowry (66-69) was 7-under and two shots clear of two Englishmen Justin Rose (69-68) and little-known Dan Brown (65-72).\n\nWorld No. 1 Scottie Scheffler (70-70) was lurking around in tied fourth alongside fellow American Billy Horschel (72-68) and South African Dean Burmester (71-69) at 2-under 140 for 36 holes.\n\nMeanwhile, a bunch of bigwigs and legends made an early exit as they were swept aside by the southerly wind across the Firth of Clyde at the Royal Troon.\n\nTiger Woods said he would be back at Portrush, but will not play again this year till his own Hero World Challenge in the Bahamas and the PNC Father-Son tournament.\n\nWoods shot 79-77 and was 14-over but smiled and said, \"I'd like to have played more, but I just wanted to make sure that I was able to play the major championships this year. I got a lot of time off to get better, to be better physically, which has been the case all year.\n\n\"I've gotten better, even though my results really haven't shown it, but physically I've gotten better, which is great. I just need to keep progressing like that and then eventually start playing more competitively and start getting into kind of the competitive flow again.\"\n\nAs for playing Majors and coming back for them, he said, \"No, I loved it. I've always loved playing major championships. I just wish I was more physically sharp coming into the majors.\n\n\"Obviously it tests you mentally, physically, emotionally, and I just wasn't as sharp as I needed to be. I was hoping that I would find it somehow, just never did. Consequently, my results and scores were pretty high.\"\n\nOn returning to Portrush for the 2025 Open, he added, \"Yeah, definitely. Okay, sorry. That's a year away.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Indian-Americans Akshay Bhatia and Sahith Theegala were headed home early.\n\nBhatia (76-73) at 7-over was headed home while Theegala, who was 6-over for first round, was 5-over through the front nine.\n\nAaron Rai, the Englishman with a touch of India in him, shot 73 in the first round and was 3-over through 14 in the second to be 5-over.\n\nLowry, whose sole PGA Tour win this season came in the company of McIlroy, led the field as he gunned for a second Open win. He followed up an opening round of 66 with a 69 and was 7-under 135. He held a two-shot lead over Brown and Rose (69-68).\n\nThe 2019 Open winner Lowry had five bogeys against a bogey and a double bogey on the 'infamous' 11th hole, also called 'Railway'. {"uri": "8233494955", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:25:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:25:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:25:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/golf/news/just-get-back-there-open-leader-shane-lowry-gets-off-rails-at-11-with-lengthy-crazy-double", "title": "'Just get back there!' Open leader Shane Lowry gets off rails at 11 with lengthy, crazy double", "body": "Royal Troon's par-4 11th hole, nicknamed \"The Railway,\" has historically been one of the most difficult holes in the Open Championship rota.\n\nShane Lowry can now attest.\n\nLowry's second round, perhaps fittingly, got off the rails at No. 11 on Friday as Lowry saw his two-shot lead evaporate after a long and crazy sequence that involved a cameraman, a yanked shot into the gorse, a provisional that was later negated and ultimately, a double bogey.\n\nHere's how it all unfolded: Lowry's tee ball found the right fescue, and though it appeared that Lowry had a decent chance to muscle his second shot the 177 yards to the hole, his shot produced a large chunk of grass and a ball shooting out low and left and right into the left gorse.\n\nLowry was suddenly fuming, shouting at a cameraman who apparently distracted the leader.\n\n\"As I was over the ball, I could just see you with the f---ing camera up!\" Lowry told the cameraman. \"Just get back there! F---'s sake!\"\n\nWith his ball likely lost, Lowry reloaded and declared a provisional. That shot, his fourth at the time, ran up onto the green and about 20 feet past the hole. However, soon after a spectator found Lowry's original ball in the prickly stuff.\n\n\"He would've preferred not to have found that ball,\" NBC Sports analyst Paul McGinley said.\n\nWhat ensued was a lengthy process that included Lowry calling in a second rules official and even walking as far back as the adjacent 12th fairway as he sized up where he'd have to take his unplayable drop.\n\n\"You can declare a ball lost, but when it's actually found, it is the ball in play,\" R&A rules official Charlie Maran said. \"The provisional ball that he did play now becomes a wrong ball. So, he has to take his options with his original ball.\"\n\nFinally, after over 20 minutes since he hit his second shot, Lowry dropped and hit his new fourth shot. From about 70 yards, Lowry came up just short of the green. To be leading this tournament after two days, it's why you come here, it's why we're here,\n\n\"The job tomorrow as well is to try to put myself in a position to win this tournament on Sunday, and that's what I'll try and do.\"\n\nLowry carded birdies on the first and fourth before his first dropped shot of the championship on the fifth, a bogey he corrected with another birdie on the eighth.\n\nThe Clara man hit a speedbump on the 11th, however, when he missed the fairway and shanked his second way left into a bush after being distracted by a cameraman.\n\nThis led to a fiery confrontation which went viral on social media.\n\nLowry declared his ball short and, from the drop, put a terrific hot within 10-feet of the hole.\n\nHe would eventually find his way back onto the green and settle for double bogey after an over-20 minute hole.\n\nOnce again, though, he responded to the setback, with a pair of birdies on 16 and 18 cancelling out the double bogey and sending him into the weekend leading by two.\n\nHe added: \"Through that whole process of 20 minutes, of taking the drop, seeing where I could drop - I felt like I was very calm and composed and really knew that I was doing the right thing.\n\n\"To be honest, I was happy enough leaving there with a six. {"uri": "2024-07-427438270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:33:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:33:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:03:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/open-championship-news-shane-lowry-british-pga-tour-royal-troon", "title": "Shane Lowry Leads Open Championship Despite Bizarre Photographer Beef", "body": "Shane Lowry appears likely to hang onto the lead heading into the weekend at the 152nd Open Championship, despite a momentary conflict with a Royal Troon photographer that led to his lone double-bogey of the event.\n\nOn the par-4 11th, the Railway -- one of Europe's toughest holes that trifled Rory McIlroy -- Lowry \"did the hard part\" and bombed his blind tee shot 301 yards onto the narrow fairway. As he set up his second shot, a photographer stood in his line of sight.\n\n\"There was a cameraman there and he was walking up, and I asked him to stop or move back, and he just kind of stayed there,\" Lowry recalled.\n\nNot only that, but the photographer apparently raised his camera in Lowry's backswing. The 2019 Open champ said the movement caused him to pull his approach left into a thick gorse bush.\n\n\"I hit my drive where you could find it, which is obviously a hard thing to do on that hole,\" said Lowry.\" I drew a nice lie in the (right) rough. I got a little bit distracted on the right just as I was over the shot, and I kind of lost a bit of train of thought. You're so afraid of going right there that I just snagged the club and went left.\"\n\nThe bizarre ride through the Railway didn't end there.\n\nLowry's ball was deemed lost. He told the R&A officials he was hitting a provisional shot which he landed within 10 feet of the hole. Only moments later, a spectator found Lowry's original ball. The officials instantly negated his provisional shot, instead forcing him to take an unplayable lie.\n\n\"I hit a great provisional,\" Lowry said. \"The referee asked me going down, did I want to find my first one, and I said no. So I assumed that was OK. Then we get down there and somebody had found it. So apparently we have to find it then or you have to go and identify it. I thought if you declared it lost before it was found, you didn't have to go and identify it.\"\n\nBefore settling on a new spot, Lowry appealed to a second rules official -- a process that took about 20 minutes. He ended up dropping his ball in the rough about 10 feet from his original approach, chipped it to 33 feet, then two-putted for a double-bogey 6.\n\nAfterward, Lowry gave himself and his caddie, {"uri": "8232475505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:34:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:34:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:32:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/aap/article-13649341/Lowry-lights-152nd-Open-terrific-Troon-turn.html", "title": "Lowry lights up 152nd Open with terrific Troon turn", "body": "Former champion Shane Lowry and surprise packet Dan Brown have delivered a brilliant late-evening show to warm up the Royal Troon galleries on a windy, squally opening day as they grabbed the early honours at the 152nd British Open.\n\nThe ever-popular, bearded Irishman Lowry completed a bogey-free 66 near the conclusion of a long, testing Thursday, only for major debutant Brown, with the clock ticking past 9.30pm in the Scottish gloom, to eclipse him with another flawless, six-under par round of 65.\n\nIt was a dramatic day that may well have already sunk the hopes of other big names like Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy and US Open champ Bryson DeChambeau.\n\nDouble PGA champion Justin Thomas had grasped the early initiative as the Ayrshire links bared its teeth, and it looked for much of the day as if the American's roller-coaster, three-under 68 could prove enough to be the first-day benchmark.\n\nBut as the winds, which had reached 30kph at some points, began to subside into the evening, it was the 2019 Royal Portrush champ Lowry who made a dramatic move ahead of Brown, a second-year tour pro who was in the day's penultimate group.\n\n\"It was enjoyable,\" reckoned the beaming Lowry.\n\n\"I try not to think about 2019 too much now. I holed a putt to go into the lead and I thought, 'It's the first time I've led The Open in five years!'.\n\n\"No matter what I do, that week in Portrush will always have a special place in my heart. I love that place and I love this tournament.\"\n\nThere were echoes of 2019 as McIlroy, who had been an emotional favourite at Portush but crashed after an opening 79, this time began with a seven-over 78, marked by his failure to deliver on the 'Postage Stamp' eighth hole when his attempt to escape the Coffin bunker rolled back deathlessly to his feet.\n\nMcIlroy, who blew his chance of a fifth major in last month's US Open showdown with DeChambeau, sounded as if he knew his chances were gone as he shrugged gloomily: \"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut.\"\n\nHe's not the only big name in trouble. DeChambeau shot a 76, though his 55ft eagle on the 16th could yet be crucial, but Australia's 2022 champion Cam Smith made 80 and has a mountain to climb.\n\nTiger Woods has his work cut out too after a tired-looking 79.\n\nThird-placed Thomas is a shot ahead of a seven-way logjam for fourth, featuring PGA champion Xander Schauffele , his US compatriot Russell Henley, Sweden's Alex Noren, Denmark's Nicolai Hojgaard, Britain's former US Open champ Justin Rose, Canada's Mackenzie Hughes and England's Joe Dean, all on 69.\n\nUltimately, there were only 17 scores in the red by the end of the day, so Australia's evergreen veteran Adam Scott was also in a good spot, with a splash-in birdie from the greenside bunker at the first proving the launch pad for his one-under 70.\n\nThree birdies in the final four holes also helped another Australian early starter, Min Woo Lee, battle back to level par in his fighting round.\n\nDeChambeau had such a calamitous first nine he reckoned he could easily have walked away halfway through his round.\n\n\"I'm just proud of the way I persevered today. Shoot, man, I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home',\" he said.\n\nIn the afternoon wave, Schauffele, world No.1 Scottie Scheffler and Brooks Koepka (both one under) all flexed their muscles to remain firmly in the picture, but reigning champion Brian Harman had to settle earlier for a two-over 73.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", {"uri": "8228461195", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-16", "time": "15:05:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-16T15:05:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-16T15:04:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/golf/shane-lowry-claret-jug-fever-33258174", "title": "Shane Lowry has Claret Jug fever as he looks for major title repeat", "body": "Shane Lowry's hunger to become a two-time Open champion increases every time he passes the Claret Jug in the Troon players' lounge.\n\nIt is a feeling that will only grow between now and 2.59pm on Thursday, when he steps up to hit the first tee shot of his 12th Open appearance.\n\nLowry famously captured his first major title amidst celebratory scenes in Portrush.\n\nREAD MORE: Shane Lowry and Rory McIlroy tee times and groups set for 152nd Open Championship at Troon\n\nREAD MORE: Rory McIlroy targets Paris gold for Ireland after revisiting controversial Troon comments\n\nThat was five years ago now and the Open is returning to the Dunluce links next summer. There will be a real spotlight on the Clara man when it does, but he isn't content to let that be the highlight of his career, as uniquely special as it was.\n\n\"It's been a while,\" Lowry said, when asked how many times he has watched the footage of his 2019 triumph.\n\n\"Probably not much in the last few years but the first couple of years, I'd certainly watched it a few times, watched the highlights and it's a moment that I'll always have.\n\n\"The great Bo Martin (his caddy at the time) there as well, great times. We're obviously going back there next year so that's going to be very special. But yeah, it was a very special moment.\"\n\nComing back to The Open as a former champion adds a different flavour. That has been his experience over the past few summers, when the last major of the year comes around.\n\n\"Yes, I suppose it does,\" Lowry said. \"You look at the Claret Jug, you walk past it in the players' lounge and you know your name is on it, it's pretty cool.\n\n\"But it makes you want it more, even, I think. People say, 'well, you've got one now', but you always want it because you've tasted that success, it makes you want it even more.\n\n\"The one thing I do know is that I know if I put myself there, I can get it done, so it's all about trying to put myself there for Saturday and Sunday.\n\n\"Obviously it takes a lot of good golf, it takes a lot of resilience. It takes everything. Your whole game needs to be pretty good, especially when you're on a course like this.\n\n\"Royal Troon is probably one of the best lay-outs of a golf course you can get, it's just the most well bunkered golf course I've ever played and to win around a venue like this, you need to be very, very sharp and have to do everything pretty well.\"\n\nSunny conditions on Monday felt like a long time ago as the players acclimatised to a colder, grey day 24 hours later. The feeling on the course early in the week is that the front nine will be the place to make birdies - and that the back nine is entirely a different beast.\n\nLowry said that his game plan will be dependent on the conditions, but also that when the time is right he will play aggressively.\n\n\"I actually think a lot of it is dependent on the wind direction,\" the 37-year-old assessed. \"Today the wind is down on the front nine but the forecast is that we're going to play into the wind on the front nine, which doesn't allow you to be aggressive.\n\n\"If it's playing down wind you can drive a couple of the greens but it doesn't all that if it's into the wind, but obviously things can change on links turf and in links golf.\n\n\"My plan is that yes, if it plays downwind to play aggressive on the front nine and try to make as many birdies as I can because when you turn around on 10, this is where the golf course starts to get tough and you know all about it.\n\n\"I was here a couple of weeks ago and it was really windy and quite tough, it was very difficult.\n\n\"Like I said, it all depends on the wind direction. If you get the back nine a little bit downwind, it's actually not bad. So like every Open championship we play, every time you come here it's all very weather dependent.\"\n\nGet the latest sports headlines straight to your inbox by signing up for free email alerts.", {"uri": "8233944622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:47:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:47:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:46:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/golf/watch-shane-lowry-fumes-at-cameraman-as-he-double-bogeys-11th-hole/a41686962.html", "title": "Watch: Shane Lowry fumes at cameraman as he double bogeys 11th hole", "body": "Lowry shot a 69 to move to seven-under after battling back from a double-bogey on the 11th. It was on the treacherous par four where the Irishman snapped in four-lettered fury.\n\nThe 2019 champion hit his tee shot into the rough on this brutal driving hole with a train track on one side and thick gorse on the other, but when he tried to extricate himself from the cabbage his ball flew left into a bush.\n\nImmediately, Lowry swivelled and let the cameraman have it. \"As I was over the ball I could just see you putting your f------' camera up,\" Lowry said. \"Just get outta the way. Just get back there. F--- sake!\"\n\nLowry's contention was that the man moved in the middle of his backswing and was clearly incensed. But later the 37-year-old played down the incident. \"There was a cameraman there, and he was walking up, and I asked him to stop or move back, and he just kind of stayed there,\" Lowry said. \"As it was over, he put his camera up. I kind of saw it out of the corner of my eye, and I should stood off it - my own fault.\"\n\nLowry believed he had \"done the hard part\" by putting his drive in play. As it proved, he was unlucky that his ball was found in the bush, because he had hit a provisional to 10 feet to give himself the opportunity to limit the damage to a bogey. But a spectator located the first ball, meaning it was still in play and after a 20-minute wait to ascertain where he could drop the ball, the best Lowry could escape with was a six.\n\nDavid Howell, the former Ryder Cup player who is working for Sky this week as an on-course commentator, revealed that the fan who found the ball was \"a little sheepish\" when he realised Lowry did not want that to happen. \"He's feeling awful,\" Howell said.\n\nNevertheless, Lowry birdied the 16th and 18th to claw back the shots and is pleased with how he reacted. \"Sometimes you are in a frame of mind where you get on with it better than other times,\" he said. \"This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. I just have to deal with it and try and make the best of it and see where it leads me.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy with how things have gone. The job tomorrow is to try to put myself in a position to win this tournament on Sunday, and that's what I'll try and do. Justin Rose and Scottie Scheffler also moved into contention with strong rounds, while many favorites struggled in challenging conditions.\n\nIreland's Shane Lowry led the Open from English qualifier Dan Brown after a masterful second round at Royal Troon, with world number one Scottie Scheffler and England's Justin Rose moving into contention on Friday. Lowry, the 2019 champion, rolled in a superb 20-foot birdie putt on the 18th green to complete a two-under 69, reaching seven under, two shots clear of overnight leader Dan Brown who impressed again with a one-over 72.\n\nFormer U.S. Open champion Rose, who had to qualify this year, put together a magnificent three-under 68 in the toughest afternoon conditions to join Brown on five-under. Rose went bogey-free for 29 holes and finished by sinking a 40ft birdie putt on the 18th green to raise hopes of a first English winner at the Open since Nick Faldo in 1992.\n\nOn the Ayrshire coast, Scheffler was warming to the task of lifting the Claret Jug for the first time, despite a bogey at the 18th that jolted his progress. {"uri": "8232469671", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:27:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:27:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:26:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/jul/18/mcilroy-golf-open-brown-lowry", "title": "McIlroy misery as world No 272 Brown forges unlikely lead", "body": "Yorkshireman Brown ends day as leader six under parDeChambeau admits course 'a difficult test'\n\nFor the majority of this first day of the 152nd Open Championship, it felt impossible to rationalise what had come before. The scale of fireworks on the final day of the Open at Royal Troon in 2016 left every onlooker grasping and gasping for superlatives. Henrik Stenson versus Phil Mickelson felt like golf's equivalent of the rumble in the jungle.\n\nBack in dreich Ayrshire - amid an infrequent wind and occasional squall - carnage ensued. The undeniable clubhouse leader after round one is the venue itself. It is for others to assess the entertainment value attached to that. Troon terrorised.\n\nTiger Woods's latest humbling came as no shock but there were eyebrows to be raised elsewhere. Rory McIlroy, 78. Bryson DeChambeau, 76. Tommy Fleetwood, 76. Ludvig \u00c5berg, 75. Cameron Smith played the front nine in 43 while en route to an 80. Collin Morikawa, Viktor Hovland, Patrick Cantlay and Hideki Matsuyama could not break par. Step forward the world No 272 Daniel Brown, who as darkness fell strode to the summit of the leaderboard. It was that sort of weird day.\n\nOn a par 71 course, the scoring average at one point touched 75. A 73 from Jon Rahm and Tyrrell Hatton's 72 felt decent in scoring context. Hatton did not come anywhere close to a rant or a rave yet did articulate what had made the environment such a grisly one.\n\n\"I don't think you can put it down to one thing, I think it's a combination,\" Hatton said. \"The conditions are difficult anyway. There's a few holes that are just obviously playing really long. Unfortunately that's where it's going at the moment, where they just seem to try to make it longer to make it harder, which I think doesn't make it the most enjoyable test.\n\n\"They didn't put any tees forward. You can't reach the par fives on the front nine [in two]. On 16, a par five, you're hitting a four iron. Tell me a good par five where you're hitting a four iron off the tee. There isn't one.\"\n\nSmith, who lifted the Claret Jug in 2022, was even more candid. \"It was brutal,\" said the Australian. The counter-argument would be that modern golfers should be able to handle the stern challenge.\n\nNobody read the script of torture to Shane Lowry. As other illustrious names licked their wounds, the 2019 champion charged - briefly, as it transpired - to the head of proceedings. Lowry did not drop a single shot during his opening round of 66. His putting was especially majestic until the final hole, when the Irishman arced a glorious iron from the middle of the fairway to just 5ft from the cup. \"I'm pretty happy, but it's only one day,\" Lowry cautioned. The last time he was sub-par at the end of Open Thursday, he won.\n\nMost surprising is the identity of the player who overtook Lowry. Brown had missed six cuts in his eight starts prior to arriving at this major. He laughed in the face of reputation while piecing together a bogey-free 65. Now for the hard part, of course, but he should relish the spotlight.\n\nJustin Thomas sits at minus three. Alex Noren, Nicolai H\u00f8jgaard, Mackenzie Hughes, Justin Rose, Russell Henley and Xander Schauffele are two under. Adam Scott and Brooks Koepka are among the contingent a stroke further back. So, too, is Scottie Scheffler after two birdies in his last three holes. Scheffler's presence will trigger anxious glances from the rest of the field.\n\nMcIlroy's troubles began at the Postage Stamp. Having taken a bolder line than was advisable towards the flag at the iconic par three, the Northern Irishman watched his ball trickle into a horrible lie in a greenside bunker. His first attempt from sand rolled back to his feet. By the time McIlroy tapped in, it was for a double bogey five.\n\nThere was further woe at the 11th. McIlroy cut his drive to the point where his ball was last reported rattling around a carriage of the 11.35 Scotrail service from Ayr to Glasgow Central. Cue another two shots dropped. By this point, McIlroy looked as though he would rather be undergoing root canal treatment than walking a links in Ayrshire.\n\nMcIlroy's demeanour upon signing for seven over par tally was more telling than what words fell from his mouth. He was asked if past recoveries meant he retains hopes of glory. Writ large upon his face was: NO. McIlroy's Friday battle here involves survival for the closing 36 holes.\n\nDeChambeau, who pipped McIlroy to the US Open last month, was in an identical predicament before holing out from a different postcode for an eagle at the 16th. DeChambeau is yet to handle the vagaries associated with British seaside golf, which to be fair he readily admits.\n\n\"It's a difficult test,\" DeChambeau said. \"Something I'm not familiar with. I never grew up playing it. I finished eighth at St Andrews; I can do it when it's warm and not windy.\n\n\"I could have thrown in the towel after nine and could have been like, 'I'm going home.' But no, I've got a chance tomorrow. I'm excited for the challenge.\"\n\nWoods limped and laboured his way to a 79. This proved the latest spell of unedifying viewing for those who recall the greatness of the 15-time major champion.\n\nThe end is surely nigh for Woods as a competitor. In specific context of this tournament, he may be in fine company.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": He birdied two of the last three holes Thursday in the British Open, giving him a 6-under 65 with just enough spectators still left in the twilight of Royal Troon to celebrate with him.\n\nIt gave him a one-shot lead over Shane Lowry, who played bogey-free for a 66 and his best start in 46 majors.\n\nLowry at least knew what to expect with an opposite wind that seemed to catch just about everyone off guard. He came to Troon two weeks ago and knew what to expect, and it paid off handsomely for the Irishman.\n\nThe surprise was Brown.\n\nA one-time winner on the European tour, he arrived at Royal Troon having failed to make the cut in seven straight tournaments dating to March until a couple of good events. {"uri": "8232770837", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:35:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:35:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T03:34:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/sport/golf/open-day-two-shane-lowry-not-getting-carried-despite-flawless-start-at-troon-XCHEYB4SLNOLVBZAFCWGOAQ4F4/", "title": "Open day two: Shane Lowry not getting carried despite flawless start at Troon", "body": "The 2019 champion is a shot behind surprise leader Daniel Brown following the opening day.\n\nShane Lowry insisted he would not get carried away by the prospect of a second Open title despite making a flawless start at Royal Troon.\n\nThe 2019 champion carded a five-under-par 66 on Thursday to lie just a shot behind English qualifier Daniel Brown, the world number 272 making a birdie on the 18th in near-darkness to snatch a shock lead on his major debut.\n\n\"I'm pretty happy, but it's only one day,\" Lowry said. \"We've got three more.\n\n\"I kept telling myself that out there because for some reason I felt like the crowd were getting very excited. It was late in the afternoon and a few pints of Tennent's were had out there. It felt more like the weekend.\n\n\"I just kept on telling myself there's a lot more to do so I just kind of stayed in my lane and hit some good shots, and I was pretty happy with how I handled myself.\n\n\"The walk down 18 was actually pretty cool. I said to Billy Foster [Matt Fitzpatrick's caddie] that it's the greatest walk in golf and I got to do it on a Sunday afternoon with a full house. That's the plan, to try to get to do that again.\n\n\"I'd give anything to win this tournament again. I'd give anything to give myself a chance to win this tournament again and that's why I'm here this week.\"\n\nLowry's friend and Ryder Cup team-mate Rory McIlroy faced an uphill struggle simply to make the cut on Friday, the world number two carding double bogeys on the eighth and 11th in a first round of 78.\n\nBryson DeChambeau, who edged out McIlroy at Pinehurst last month to win a second US Open title, also had work to do following a 76 which was matched by England's Tommy Fleetwood, while 15-time major winner Tiger Woods looked destined for another early exit following a 79.\n\nShot of the day\n\nSpanish amateur Jaime Montojo had a fairytale start to his maiden Open when he holed out from 132 yards for an eagle on the first.\n\nRound of the day\n\nQualifier Daniel Brown also enjoyed a dream Open debut with a flawless 65 rounded off by a birdie on the 18th at 9.33pm to take the lead.\n\nQuote of the day\n\nMin Woo Lee apologies to the volunteer tasked with raking bunkers on the famous eighth hole after he and many others found sand at the Postage Stamp.\n\nStatistic of the day\n\nTop statistician Justin Ray highlights how impressive Brown's round was.\n\nEasiest hole\n\nThe par-five 16th, which played downwind, was unsurprisingly the easiest hole, yielding four eagles, 39 birdies, 25 bogeys and just one double bogey for an average of 4.872.\n\nHardest hole\n\nThe 450-yard 12th hole is not as well known as the eighth or 11th, but played the most difficult with just nine birdies, 44 bogeys, seven double bogeys and three \"other\" scores leading to an average of 4.397.\n\nCloudy with a chance of some early drizzle before turning brighter and breezier as the day progresses.
