{"uri": "2024-07-426379423", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "19:20:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T19:20:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:18:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/golf/rory-mcilroy-the-open-abyss-3178689", "title": "'I didn't adapt well enough': Rory McIlroy on the brink of the Open abyss", "body": "McIlroy is battling to make the cut after a first-round 78 at Royal Troon\n\nROYAL TROON -- Three questions only, advised the media officer. You can infer from that instruction this was not the best day in the career of Rory McIlroy. An opening round of 78, including an out of bounds at 11 and a double at the par-three 8th, left him fighting to stay in the championship.\n\nA month ago he allowed the US Open to slip from his grasp over the closing four holes at Pinehurst. That was a no-question day, so maybe there is still hope. McIlroy went straight from the scorer's hut to a waiting car and was not heard from again until he sent out a congratulatory note to winner Bryson DeChambeau on his social channels.\n\nSome might tie the two events together and conclude that the tail-spin from Pinehurst was still a factor in McIlroy's head on the first day at Royal Troon. Except that this was not that kind of meltdown. Rather, it felt more like an old trope with which McIlroy has grappled before at this tournament.\n\nAt Royal St George's 13 years ago after a Saturday going backwards in similarly filthy conditions, McIlroy vented his spleen, declaring he would not be adjusting his game to fit the needs of a challenge that he felt was unrepresentative of the discipline in which he was engaged. In other words, what transpired in Kent that day was not golf but a perversion of it, an experience so corrupted by the weather as to bear little resemblance to the game he played every other week of the year.\n\nInterestingly, his fellow Northern Irishman, Darren Clarke, stood tallest that week, winning his only major. Here Clarke shot a 75, two better than McIlroy with whom he played on Tuesday.\n\nIt was sunny then, and all was well in McIlroy's world.\n\nIn 2010 at St Andrews, McIlroy followed up an opening 63 posted in favourable conditions with an 80 in winds gusting at 40mph plus.\n\nThere have been other shockers too, notably in 2013 at Muirfield, where he opened with a 79 and admitted he needed help with the mental side of the game. Five years ago he confessed that the pressure of playing before a home crowd at Royal Portrush was a factor in registering a quadruple bogey eight on the first hole of the tournament.\n\nHe rallied with a 65 on the second day but it was not enough to make the weekend.\n\nIf we were to connect all his bad stuff at the Open there appears to be a failure of will in conditions that don't suit his game. He seems incapable of rousing himself, his body language telling its own miserable tale.\n\nThis is not to say McIlroy lacks resilience per se, only that there is something unique to this event that has the potential to bring him low, to drag him into an all-consuming fug.\n\nThough he started with a bogey, matters did not turn evil until Royal Troon's signature hole, the shortest on the Open rota affectionately known as the Postage Stamp. McIlroy's ball appeared to hold on the putting surface yet such is the wicked nature of links golf, appearances are frequently deceiving.\n\nThere was in McIlroy's ball an unseen half-roll left in it, and, with it, the fatal call of gravity. Off it rolled with inexorable consequences into the greenside bunker. His first attempt to escape saw the ball fall back to his feet. The second found the green but too far from the pin to avoid a double-bogey.\n\nHe scrambled a par at the 9th before letting another shot go at the 10th. By the time he stood on the 11th tee, there was a look of desperation about him. The cheeks were puffing big time when the arc of his ball began to trace to the right, destined, as it were, for the wrong side of the railway tracks.\n\nWe have seen this look before, a combination of frustration and despair. When you hit a ball as prodigiously as McIlroy, processing outcomes as inexplicably bad as the tee shot at 11 becomes a kind of trauma.\n\nHe took a moment to reload then split the ether with a bullet of a strike that split the fairway, begging the question, why could he not do that moments before?\n\nThis was his attempt at an answer: \"I felt like I did OK for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp, left it in and made a double. But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\n\"Then hitting the ball out of bounds on 11, making a double there. Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. I thought we were going to get it a little bit easier than we did. The course was playing tough. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens, you play your practice rounds, you have a strategy that you think is going to help you get around the golf course, but then when you get a wind you haven't played in, it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Just one of those days where I didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nMcIlroy finished 10 behind clubhouse leader Justin Thomas, his hitting partner at the Bears Club in Florida. Though the forecast is kinder for today, McIlroy is on the edge of the abyss in Troon.\n\n\"Try to make the cut, that's all I can focus on,\" he said. That and pray for sunshine next year.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kevin_garside@inews.co.uk", "name": "Kevin Garside", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Troon_Golf_Club", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Royal Troon Golf Club"}}, {"uri": "label": {"eng": "Darren Clarke"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinehurst,_North_Carolina", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Pinehurst, North Carolina"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Pinehurst, North Carolina"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryson_DeChambeau", "type": "person", {"uri": "8233401459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:25:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:25:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/golf/rory-mcilroy-open-nick-faldo-33281333", "title": "Rory McIlroy told his major drought may never end after Open horror show", "body": "Sir Nick Faldo has poured doubt on Rory McIlroy's chances of winning another major after his dismal start to The Open Championship at Royal Troon on Thursday.\n\nMcIlroy's chances of lifting the Claret Jug on Sunday are all but over after he carded a seven-over-par opening round on the Ayrshire coast, leaving him languishing in 126th place and facing an uphill battle to make the cut.\n\nThursday's performance marked a miserable return to the major stage for the Ulsterman one month on from his Pinehurst heartbreak, blowing a two-shot lead over the final four holes to prolong his 10-year wait to win a fifth major championship.\n\nREAD MORE: Dustin Johnson left to regret four-hole stretch as Open hopes in the balance\n\nREAD MORE: Shane Lowry reaction to rowdy Open crowd sums him up after racing into early contention\n\nFaldo, the most successful European golfer of all time with six major wins, says with each passing tournament, he is increasingly unsure that McIlroy, 35, will taste major glory again.\n\n\"I would love him to but it is a big but now,\" Faldo told BBC Radio 4. \"It really is a big but. People say flick a switch and go and make it happen. It is just not that easy, is it? You lose your trust, a bit of self-belief and that doubt creeps in some small percentage. And you can't quite play how you used to play\n\n\"Rory is only 35, fit as a fiddle, strong, hitting the golf ball great but an awful lot of scar tissue and damage. And then of course he put himself in an unbelievable position at Pinehurst and then it all went wrong. Amazing how one putt from two feet on the 16th, you suddenly doubt yourself and you think 'Oh my goodness'. You can see how his mind got scrambled.\n\n\"That unfortunately is another moment where he was so close, like St Andrews. He was leading by, what, three? Had a great putt over on the ninth, missed it and of course, Cam Smith goes birdie-birdie. And then all of a sudden he could have been four ahead and you are only one. Little things like that.\n\nFor all the latest on news, politics, sports, and showbiz from the USA, go to The Mirror US .\n\n\"On the technical side, as we know with his short game, anything from a 9-iron in, he doesn't trust it 100 per cent. He knows occasionally he pulls some left and then you guard against that. It is a brutal game between their ears.\"\n\nMcIlroy wore a pained expression as he faced the media in the immediate aftermath of Thursday's opening round, knowing that his realistic hopes of contending for the win this week were over.\n\n\"Difficult day,\" he said. \"I felt like I did okay for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and left it in and made a double.\n\n\"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through 9, thinking that I could maybe get those couple shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\n\nThen hitting the ball out of bounds on 11, making a double there. Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. I thought we were going to get it a little bit easier than we did.\n\n\"The course was playing tough. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week. I guess when that happens, you play your practice rounds, you have a strategy that you think is going to help you get around the golf course, but then when you get a wind you haven't played in, it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Yeah, just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nMcIlroy will need to navigate Troon under par in his second round, which begins at 3.10pm. {"uri": "8234090251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "20:06:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T20:06:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T20:05:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4039215743541718, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/golf/arid-41440270.html", "title": "Shane Lowry doing it his own way as he leads the Open pack", "body": "He had profited from a draw that had twice sent him out onto the Old Course at times when the elements were less mischievous. No doubt about that. Eight of the top ten after two rounds teed off on Friday before 10am here. That's no coincidence.\n\nJustin Rose, who started at lunchtime, was a one-man chasing pack through much of the afternoon. The difficulties involved through the day were such that there were less players under par by close of play than when it began.\n\nStill, none of the playing conditions here have been anything like easy. Lowry had thumbed his nose at all of them, fashioned his golf around them, but a time had to come when the gods would test him. Or a photographer.\n\nOne camera moving at the wrong time was all it took. Lowry saw it in the corner of his eye, lost his focus and sent his approach from the rough flying sideways, over the fairway and the gallery opposite and into the gorse.\n\nWhat followed would have tested Job himself. His original was lost and found, there were rulings debated and confirmed, a penalty drop and, eventually, a blind chip of about 125 yards to the front of the green on the way to a double bogey.\n\nThe whole episode took over 20 minutes but, while he let the snapper have it with some choice words, there was a noticeable calming of what could have been boiling waters by the time he hit what turned out to be an unnecessary provisional.\n\nLowry closed his eyes, cranked his neck skywards and uttered a few silent words. This is what we call a reset these days. Sports psychologists preach this stuff so that players have roadmaps to follow when the temptation is to snap a club over the knee.\n\nIs that what he was doing? Was he leaning on this modern method?\n\n\"No. Sometimes you are in a frame of mind that it works better for... You know, you get on with it better [sometimes] than other times. This week in my head feels like that, where I think I'm ready to take what comes, take what's given to me out there.\n\n\"Almost ready for - I don't want to be negative - anything that's thrown at me, I feel like I'm ready to take it on the chin and move on. I just have to deal with it and try and make the best of it and see where it leads me.\" This is part of what draws us to him.\n\nA world-class sportsman, Lowry has managed to reach that high plateau by climbing without some of the safety harnesses packed by so many others. It leaves him susceptible to spectacular falls but it is rarely short of required viewing.\n\nAnd there's more to come.\n\nOffaly's finest sits two shots clear at the halfway stage on seven-under with Rose his closest pursuer after his superb three-under 68. Of the ten players better than even par, five of them have won majors. Other 'names' lie a couple of shots further back.\n\nLowry is comfortable in that company.\n\nHe left Carnoustie in tears after missing the cut at the 2018 Open and reflected later about how the game wasn't his \"friend\" at the time. He was visited by self-doubt the Sunday morning at Portrush before winning in 2019.\n\nLetting the 2016 US Open slip on the back of a four-shot, 54-hole lead took an age time to process. It's only a matter of weeks since he was left \"close to tears\" after carding an 85 at the Memorial. It's a cruel game.\n\nHe said once that his scorecard wouldn't matter to his daughter Iris - this was before her sister Ivy was born - and that perspective held on a more mundane level after his testing chapter at the 'Railway' 11th.\n\nHe made for the 12th tee happy enough to have signed for a six, then lashed driver and a four-iron into the teeth of the wind. They were his two best shots of the week under the circumstances and utterly key to his round.\n\nBirdies at 16 and 18 left him on seven-under and in the outright lead, the second of those prompting yet another fist pump from a player who has managed to balance that sort of raw emotion with a calm when the occasion requires it.\n\n\"Like, I can get a bit down on myself and a bit hot-headed at times, but I really feel like that's why I've had the career I've had. I've spoken to people, my coach and my team about this at times. If I go out there and try to be somebody I'm not, you're just not going to be successful.\"\n\nHe approaches the weekend with the field at his back and with a proven ability to handle the pressure at the summit. He did it in Portrush and as far back as that Irish Open win as an amateur 15 years ago. Are you a good front-runner, he was asked?", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "brendan_o_brien@irishexaminer.com", "name": {"uri": "8232362263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "19:44:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T19:44:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:43:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4039215743541718, "url": "https://thewillnews.com/mcilroy-struggles-in-opening-round-of-british-open/", "title": "McIlroy Struggles In Opening Round Of British Open", "body": "July 18, (THEWILL) - Rory McIlroy faced a challenging start at the British Open, carding a seven-over-par round on Thursday at Royal Troon.\n\nThe world number two now finds himself fighting to make the cut after a difficult day in windy and rainy conditions on Scotland's west coast.\n\nMcIlroy's troubles began at the par-three eighth hole, where he found a bunker and made a double bogey. His struggles continued with another double bogey at the 11th after hitting out of bounds. The Northern Irishman also dropped shots at the 10th, 15th, and 18th holes.\n\nThe 35-year-old golfer attributed his poor performance to the challenging weather conditions and his inability to adapt quickly enough. McIlroy explained that cross-winds coming from a different direction than he had experienced in practice earlier in the week caught him off guard.\n\nOther top players also found the course demanding. US Open champion Bryson DeChambeau posted a five-over 76, while world number four Ludvig Aberg shot a 75. The combination of tough conditions and a challenging course proved difficult for many competitors.\n\nLooking ahead, McIlroy's focus has shifted to making the cut. He emphasised the need to play better in the second round and shoot a score under par to ensure he stays for the weekend. McIlroy last missed the cut at the British Open in 2019 at Portrush, where a strong second-round performance could not overcome a poor opening day.", "source": {"uri": "thewillnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8232553707", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "23:03:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T23:03:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T23:02:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4000000059604645, "url": "https://golf.com/news/2024-open-championship-biggest-surprise-thursday/", "title": "What was the biggest surprise on Day 1 of the Open Championship?", "body": "Rory McIlroy reacts to a shot during the first round of the 2024 Open Championship on Thursday at Royal Troon Golf Club in Troon, Scotland.\n\nCheck in every week for the unfiltered opinions of our writers and editors as they break down the hottest topics in the sport, and join the conversation by tweeting us at @golf_com.\n\nThe first round of the 2024 Open Championship had everything it should have -- rugged Scottish weather, unpredictable winds and, of course, players scratching their heads trying to get out of those pesky pot bunkers. Daniel Brown (six under) holds the lead after an eventful Day 1. What was the biggest surprise on Thursday at The Open?\n\nJosh Sens, senior writer (@JoshSens): I'll pluck the low-hanging fruit and go with Rory McIlroy's seven-over opening round. No doubt he drew some of the worst of the weather, but a few of his stumbles -- the OB tee shot on 11, the indifferent wedge on 13 and so on -- seemed as much mental glitches as anything. I'm not sure that anything in links golf counts as a true shocker -- we're supposed to expect the unexpected -- but often what's even harder to get a handle on these days is what's going on in Rory's head.\n\nJosh Berhow, managing editor (@Josh_Berhow): Daniel Brown is 29 years old and making his first major start, and before his 61st-place finish at the Genesis Scottish Open, he had missed six cuts and withdrew from another tournament in a seven-event span. So of course he leads! He birdied two of the last three and didn't make a bogey for a brilliant major debut. But other than Brown's surge up the leaderboard, the answer has to be Rory. Like so many others I thought he'd really bounce back this week, but we didn't see that today.\n\nJack Hirsh, assistant editor (@JR_HIRSHey): It's Justin Thomas' late-round recovery. He took the lead at four under, which, despite his opening-round 62 last week, is surprising on its own. But then his round could have gone off the rails when he couldn't do anything with the best drive of the day on 11, doubled 12 and bogeyed 13. I thought we were heading for a 75 and eventually another missed cut in what's been a long streak of bizarre play from the two-time major winner. But he righted the ship, knocked it stiff on 17, one of the toughest holes all day, and made a solid birdie putt at the last to grab the best round of the morning wave.\n\nRyan Barath, equipment editor (@rdsbarath): Rory's first round was truly shocking, and to be fair so was Bryson DeChambeau's. Both of these players handled tough conditions at Pinehurst extremely well, and today I was hoping to see them jockeying for position atop the leaderboard at Royal Troon -- not sitting well below the potential cutline. If I had a second pick, I agree with Jack in that Justin Thomas' recovery was not what I was expecting after his mid-round troubles. He still continues to struggle with consistency, and after the double bogey I was half expecting a full ejection.\n\nDylan Dethier, senior writer (@dylan_dethier): The biggest surprise, for me, was a delightful one: Troon played tough! I know the fellas snuck a couple low ones through at the end (shoutout Dan Brown) but the fact that only 17 pros are under par after the first round means good scores were well earned. The only thing better than an Open is a tough Open. {"uri": "2024-07-426307808", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "17:44:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T17:44:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T16:16:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3960784375667572, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/golf-mcilroy-facing-open-cut-after-dismal-opening-round/2180501/", "title": "Golf-McIlroy facing Open cut after dismal opening round", "body": "His real problems began at the par-three eighth, the notorious Postage Stamp, where McIlroy found sand with his tee shot and then his recovery rolled back into the bunker.\n\nHe walked off with a double-bogey five and made another double at the 11th after going out of bounds over the railway tracks that run alongside the course.\n\nThe 35-year-old dropped further shots on the 15th and 18th and now faces a huge job to make the cut, as he did at Royal Portrush five years ago after an eight-over opening round.\n\n\"Yeah, a difficult day. I felt like I did okay for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and left it in and made a double,\" McIlroy told reporters.\n\n\"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine, thinking that I could maybe get those couple shots back, try to shoot even par.\n\n\"Then hitting the ball out of bounds on 11, making a double there. Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played.\"\n\nMcIlroy looked like ending his wait for a fifth major when he led the U.S. Open last month but three bogeys in his final four holes, including two where he missed putts inside four feet, meant he lost to American Bryson DeChambeau by one stroke.\n\nHe received warm support on Thursday but again it was a frustrating day as conditions caught him out.\n\n\"The course was playing tough. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week,\" McIlroy said. \"You play your practice rounds, you have a strategy that you think is going to help you get around the golf course, but then when you get a wind you haven't played in.\n\n\"Yeah, just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nAt Portrush, McIlroy almost made amends as he carded a second-round 65, just missing the cut.\n\nHe is likely to need a similar response on Friday.\n\n\"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut. That's all I can focus on,\" McIlroy, who won the 2014 Open at Hoylake, said.\n\n\"The conditions look like they're going to be pretty similar again tomorrow. I need to go out there and try to shoot something under-par and at least be here for the weekend.\"\n\n(Reporting by Martyn Herman; Editing by Toby Davis)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "https://static.theprint.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/theprint_default_image_new.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9745035", "eventUri": "eng-9745035", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1215686274509804, "wgt": 101, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8232340034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "19:25:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T19:25:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:23:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3882353007793427, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/rory-mcilroy-only-mercy-did-190844461.html", "title": "Rory McIlroy's only mercy was that he did not hit the 13:00 train from Glasgow", "body": "It was on Troon's 11th hole, appropriately named The Railway, that Rory McIlroy's hopes of lifting his major curse this week really veered off track. Until that point, the Northern Irishman had just about held things together.\n\nEven a double-bogey at the 8th, Troon's fabled Postage Stamp, which sent him to two-over-par for his round, could be put down to an aberration; McIlroy's tee shot finding the green and seemingly coming to a rest before catching the downslope and slowly, agonisingly, rolling into the right greenside bunker from which he took two shots to escape.\n\nIt was unfortunate. But McIlroy bounced back from that misfortune with a good par save on nine and was hanging in there. \"I felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through nine,\" he said later. \"I was thinking that I could maybe get those couple of shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that.\"\n\nFor McIlroy, it never rains but it pours. Another bogey on 10 sent him to three-over, and perhaps that was the problem. Irritated, he lined up with driver on 11. With the wind coming from behind, left to right, he did not need to take the risk, but either way he got it horribly wrong, his ball not only finishing out of bounds but the other side of the Glasgow-Ayr train line entirely. McIlroy was lucky not to hit the 1300 service from Glasgow Central which had just left Barassie. Naturally, he then reloaded and striped a brilliant drive down the middle.\n\nMcIlroy would eventually trudge off that hole, shoulders slumped, with a second double bogey on his scorecard, while behind him fans swarmed over the track, looking for a ball they could sell on eBay.\n\nSuffice to say, this seven-over-par 78 was not the round McIlroy wanted or needed after his heartbreak at Pinehurst last month, where he spurned that golden opportunity to win his first major in over a decade by missing two tiddlers in his last three holes. McIlroy said on the eve of this championship he was confident he could put himself in contention.\n\nOne day in and you would have to say, his hopes of lifting the curse here in Troon are over. McIlroy could go low today, of course. He has been known to follow up poor rounds with great ones. At Portrush in 2019, he followed up an opening round 79 with a 65 on day two (it still wasn't enough to make the cut). At St Andrews in 2010 he shot a second round 80 but bounced back to shoot 69-68 and finish in a tie for third. It would surprise no one if he shot in the low 60s today.\n\nBut even McIlroy was not sounding overly confident at the finish. Asked afterwards whether he felt he could still pull this back, he paused for what seemed an eternity. \"All I need to focus on is tomorrow and try to make the cut,\" he eventually replied. \"That's all I can focus on.\" As ever with McIlroy, the body language spoke volumes.\n\nA few hours earlier, as he got his round under way in the Ayrshire rain, he looked happy enough. Chatting merrily with playing partner Tyrrell Hatton, McIlroy played the opening holes conservatively, eschewing driver off the tee, punching irons into the wind.\n\nHe bounced back from a bogey at the first with a birdie at the third. And while the double at the Postage Stamp clearly rocked him, he did not fold. An excellent up-and-down on nine kept him at two-over-par. McIlroy's wife, Erica Stoll, and father, Gerry, followed behind, mixing with the crowds.\n\nMcIlroy actually scrambled pretty well all day. He might well have had a treble on 11 had he not got down in two from off the green. He saved par with an excellent up-and-down from a bunker on 17. And it looked as if he would save par again on 18 despite finding a fairway bunker with his drive. McIlroy splashed out of that trap, then hit a glorious approach. His putting once again let him down.\n\nIt came as no surprise to media waiting in the mixed zone that McIlroy would be taking \"three questions only\". By the 18th, the friendly chat with Hatton had long since dried up and he looked to have the weight of the world on his shoulders again.\n\nPerhaps McIlroy will bounce back on Friday. Perhaps not. Every time he tees it up in a major, it feels as if mentally the challenge gets more difficult. Naturally, McIlroy denied he was suffering any sort of US Open hangover.\n\n\"No, I wouldn't say so,\" he insisted. \"I just think that your misses get punished a lot more this week than even last week [at the Scottish Open]. The rough, the balls that I hit in the rough today, the lies were pretty nasty. It was just one of those days where I didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\"\n\nThe problem for McIlroy is that 'those days' are magnified more than for any other player. Two of the other big favourites for this Open, the man who pipped him to last month's US Open, Bryson DeChambeau, and Englishman Tommy Fleetwood, also had difficult days, posting 76s.\n\nNeither will get anything like the column inches. That is McIlroy's curse. It is going to require something extraordinary to get his Open back on track now.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": In 2023 he played some decent stuff at the Scottish Open and then went and missed the cut at Hoylake a week later, so the Renaissance Club was a no-no.\n\nThe alternative was four days of peace and quiet playing Hog's Head with a few friends in pitch perfect 15-mph wind conditions and he made time to pop over to Wimbledon with his wife Wendy too.\n\nThe Royal Box, to be exact, and he took his seat having met with Novak Djokovic before the round of 16 clash with Holger Rune and an aftermath in which the Marmite Serb admonished the fans for their \"disrespectful\" 'Ruuuuuune' chants.\n\nDjokovic had spent time with the European team before last year's Ryder Cup win in Rome and Lowry was well impressed with the way the controversial tennis legend spoke to Luke Donald's men before their clash with Team USA.\n\n\"To be honest, I said to Luke, 'the speech he gave us would nearly be better for Bethpage next year'. When you watch him play it feels like the whole stadium is against him but he turns the other way where he feels like everyone is cheering for him. That's how he does it.\"\n\nLowry will hardly turn to that speech for inspiration for encouragement here on Scotland's west coast this week given the Ayrshire region is already sprinkled lightly with a spread of fans with Irish accents long before the first tee approaches.\n\nThese early-week days make for the toughest of times.\n\nThis is Lowry's 46th major, he has claimed eight top tens including that one title and made his debut in the big leagues as far back as 2010 but he still admits to a tightening of the stomach now at the age of 37.\n\nWinning that Open in 2019 hasn't insulated him from the nerves. If anything, it has left him more exposed.\n\n\"I think it adds more pressure. I feel like when you've tasted success, you just want it even more. That's just the way it is. I feel like I wanted so bad to win another one. Just give me one more and I'll be happy,\" he laughed.\n\n\"That's all I want. Is it too much to ask for?\" He's in and around 25/1 in the odds and you can see why. His one cut in 15 starts was his first of the year, there was the win at the Zurich Classic of New Orleans with Rory McIlroy and four other top tens and a tie for 19th at the US Open and tie for sixth at the US PGA.\n\nHe's 15th in the FedEx rankings and way ahead of the field average in strokes gained overall, off the tee and on his approaches. The figures aren't as impressive on the greens but Lowry feels he turned a corner with his putting at that Zurich win in late April.\n\nIt's been anything but dull with a 62 at the US PGA in May followed less than a month later by an 85 at the final round of the Memorial Tournament but his penchant for digging in was there again with a tie for ninth at the Travelers late last month despite a period of illness.\n\n\"It has been good. Don't get me wrong, it is my best season on the PGA Tour, so far. Golf is a funny game, isn't it? In the last two months I have shots two 62s and an 85, and it is just funny. I feel like that is just golf, that's what it is just like.\n\n\"You never take anything for granted. The good times don't last forever and the bad times don't last forever. You just have to get on with it when you can and ride the wave when you are playing well. Look, I feel like I am playing okay now.\"\n\nAs Marisa Tomei would say, the biological clock is ticking. Lowry has spoken before about the sands of time and he is 37 now but Padraig Harrington made the point to him a few months back that he was the same age when putting together one of his best seasons.\n\nThe Dubliner was only weeks out from his 37th birthday when he retained his Open title at Royal Birkdale and standing at a career high of third in the global rankings. Ultimately, none of those things matter. Or his form, as Lowry said himself.\n\nThis is about the here and the now. {"uri": "2024-07-426363031", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "18:59:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T18:59:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T18:52:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3450980484485626, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/rory-mcilroys-rough-beginning-at-the-open-after-reuniting-with-erica-stoll/", "title": "Rory McIlroy's rough beginning at The Open after reuniting with Erica Stoll - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Rory McIlroy's major misery picked up where it left off as his trek around treacherous Troon Thursday morning was as turbulent as both his professional and personal life.\n\nThe Northern Irishman headed to the 152nd Open Championship at Royal Troon with the aim of brushing off his US Open heartbreak and sealing his first major victory in ten years.\n\nHowever, McIlroy's opening round of the final major of 2024 did not go according to plan with a score of seven-over plundering his hopes.\n\nThe 35-year-old, playing in his first major since his brief sabbatical amid US Open implosion and divorce U-turn drama, suffered agony in Ayrshire.\n\nMcIlroy opened his quest to end his major drought with a bogey five - an omen of what was to come. He managed to claw a shot back at the third but disaster struck at the eighth.\n\nHe was one of the early victims of the infamous Postage Stamp hole, Royal Troon's calling card.\n\nDespite only playing 123 yards, the tiny green at the short par-three is fatal. Miss and you're in trouble - something McIlroy learnt the hard way.\n\nThe four-time major winner found one of the lethal, steep-sided bunkers to the right of the green and paid the price with his first attempt to escape finding the putting surface - albeit briefly - before it trundled all the way back to its sandy grave. The error marked a double bogey for McIlroy and the beginning of the death of his round.\n\nFrom there, there was no redemption. The links courses of the British Open are notorious for rarely offering up shots, and devastatingly harder to claw back from.\n\nBogeys at the tenth and 15th along with another double at the 11th followed, sinking McIlroy further down the leaderboard.\n\nMore bunker trouble at the 18th, this time in the form of the sandy traps lining the fairway, sealed his sentence of seven-over.\n\nAfter falling excruciatingly short to Bryson DeChambeau last month, McIlroy stepped away from the spotlight to expel the painful memories of his Pinehurst nightmare. Yet if his opening round is anything to by, it clearly still haunts him.\n\nHolding a two-shot lead during the final round of last month's major, McIlroy carded three bogeys across the final five holes - missing two putts from a combined distance of seven feet.\n\nHe fled the course a matter of minutes after DeChambeau wrapped up victory in North Carolina, not to be seen again until he stood on the tee at The Renaissance Club last week - this time with wife Erica Stoll in tow.\n\nMcIlroy's US Open heartbreak may have been soothed by the rekindling of his romance with his briefly-estranged wife.\n\nOn the eve of the US Open, he announced he was calling off the divorce from his wife of seven years and mother of his daughter, Poppy.\n\nIt was only a month prior, before the PGA Championship in May, that McIlroy announced that he and Erica were to split due to their marriage being 'irretrievably broken'.\n\nDuring their short-lived separation, rumors linked the PGA Tour star to CBS Sports reporter Amanda Balionis, 38, whom he was seen hugging after the pair did an interview at the RBC Canadian Open at Hamilton Golf and Country Club in Hamilton, Ontario.\n\nBut on the Tuesday before the tournament, McIlroy said in a statement: 'There have been rumors about my personal life recently, which is unfortunate. Responding to each rumor is a fool's game.\n\n'Over the past weeks, Erica and I have realized that our best future was as a family together. Thankfully, we have resolved our differences and look forward to a new beginning.'\n\nMcIlroy's attorney Thomas Sasser filed a Notice of Voluntary Dismissal on his behalf on June 11 in Palm Beach County Courthouse after he and Erica reportedly held secret meetings at their $22m Florida home for a month in a bid to salvage their marriage.\n\nLast week, the couple were spotted in a rare sighting on a London dinner date with his Ryder Cup teammates and their spouses. The dinner marked one of the rare occasions that McIlroy and Erica have been sighted together since reuniting.\n\nYet, while the four-time major winner may have smoothed out his marital woes, it hasn't extended to the golf course.\n\nWith Stoll expected to join her husband at a major championship for the first time since the reunion, she may find herself offering up a shoulder for him to cry on.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)", "type": "loc", {"uri": "8232447488", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "21:06:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T21:06:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T21:05:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3372549116611481, "url": "https://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/24461768.rory-mcilroy-surprised-play-royal-troon-back-nine/", "title": "Rory McIlroy 'surprised' by the way the back nine played at Royal Troon", "body": "The Northern Irishman struggled at Royal Troon with a final-round score of +7 par 78.\n\nIt was far from vintage from the world ranked number two as he gave himself a stringent second-round task, with little to no margin for error if making the cut is to be achieved.\n\nOne stat he'll definitely not want to see if that, since 2000, only 5.6 percent of players who shoot 78 or higher in round one of The Open have come back to make the cut. Sorry, Rory.\n\nHe'll not go down without a fight though, with four-time major champion proving in the past that he can claw things back.\n\n\"I felt like I did okay for the first part of the round and then missed the green at the Postage Stamp there and left it in and made a double,\" said the 35-year-old. \"But still, felt like I was in reasonable enough shape being a couple over through 9, thinking that I could maybe get those couple shots back, try to shoot even par, something like that. Then hitting the ball out of bounds on 11, making a double there.\n\n\" Even though the wind on the back nine was helping, it was a lot off the left. I was actually surprised how difficult I felt like the back nine played. I thought we were going to get it a little bit easier than we did. The course was playing tough. The conditions are very difficult in a wind that we haven't seen so far this week.\n\n\"I guess when that happens, you play your practice rounds, you have a strategy that you think is going to help you get around the golf course, but then when you get a wind you haven't played in, it starts to present different options and you start to think about maybe hitting a few clubs that you haven't hit in practice. Yeah, just one of those days where I just didn't adapt well enough to the conditions.\n\nRead more:\n\n\"I just think that your misses get punished. Your misses get punished a lot more this week than even last week or even, geez, any weeks, whether you miss it in a fairway bunker or even the rough. The rough, the balls that I hit in the rough today, the lies were pretty nasty. I think it's more you just get penalised more for your misses.\"\n\nBryson DeChambeau also suffered an opening round to forget. The American was five over for the day.\n\nThe 30-year-old got off to a nightmare start with four bogeys and a double-bogey on the front nine. He recovered well enough to finish strongly with a -1 score on the back nine, giving him a total of 76 for the day.\n\nHe commented on his early issues: \"It was in and off the right and I was trying the draw the ball and the ball was knuckling a little bit. It was a really difficult challenge, and I should have just cut the ball.\n\n\"It's a completely different test (from practicing). I didn't get any practice in it, and I didn't really play much in the rain. Yeah, it's a difficult test out here.\n\n\"Something I'm not familiar with. I never grew up playing it, and not to say that that's the reason; I finished eighth at St Andrews.
